title: 50 million Yuan loan
description: In 2005, China offered Namibia a 50 million Yuan interest-free loan to implement small industrial projects and small-scale farming units in the country. In a December meeting, it was resolved that Namibia would use this loan of approximately N$44.9 million (RMB 50 million) to implement small industrial projects and small-scale farming units in the country. The loan agreement was signed on December 18 by Finance Minister Saara Kuugongelwa-Amadhila and the Chinese Ambassador to Namibia Liang Yinzhu. It is unclear how the funds were used. The project appears to be untied.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-140570102/china-construct-namibian-military.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.afrika.no/Detailed/13162.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/200701250458.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: 50 million yuan grant
description: In 2009, China signed an agreement with the Namibian government for a 50 million Yuan grant (approximately N$65 million). According to Chinese Ambassador Ren Xiaoping, how the new grant will be used is yet to be decided. The project is untied.
sources: http://www.namibian.com.na/index.php?id=28&tx_ttnews%255Btt_news%255D=86785&no_cache=1, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/200902100783.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: 500 million yuan ($67.36 million) soft loan
description: In 2006, China Import-Export Bank signed a CNY 500 million soft loan with Eritrea. The loan was given so that the GSE (Government of the State of Eritrea) could have the capital necessary to purchase a 40% share in the Nevsun-owned (Canadian company) Bisha Mining Corporation, through the Eritrean National Mining Corporation (ENMC). The market value of purchasing the shares could exceed 130 million USD. Supposedly, even with the Chinese loan, the GSE is having a hard time coming up with the rest of the funds. The latest media report did not confirm that the agreement has been signed yet.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LBA0000020071116e3bg001b6&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=07ASMARA907&version=1314919461, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://er.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200712/20071205285175.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: 500,000 EUR Grant for Public Works Projects
description: In December 2003, China gave Morocco a EUR 500,000 grant to finance several small-scale projects and the purchase of Chinese equipment. The status of the project is uncertain.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020031231dzcv000on&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: 500,000 NAD grant to University of Namibia
description: In 2012, East China Mineral Exploration and Development Bureau donated 500,000 NAD to the University of Namibia. The money will support capacity building at the university in science and engineering-related fields at the postgraduate level. The funds will be used through the Sam Nujoma Science Scholarship Scheme. The East China Mineral Exploration and Development Bureau donated money through Namibia East China Non-Ferrous Investments (Pty). STAFF_NOTE: Possibly a recurring donation, see project ID# 25491.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120123e81n0012a&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

donor_agency: East China Mineral Exploraiton and Development Bureau, State-Owned Company
contacts: Kenneth Matengu, Director of External and International Relations (University of Namibia)

title: 500,000 USD grant for e-learning laboratory
description: On January 10, 2012, the Rwandan Prime Minister Pierre Damien Habumuremyi inaugurated the 500,000 USD E-learning Laboratory at the Kigali Institute of Science and Technology with Li Yuanchao, a member of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China. The money that funded the lab was from a Chinese donation promised in July of 2007. The lab is designed for students to follow a professor teaching numerous classes at once, reducing costs while enhancing the educational experience for students.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120111e81b000ba&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.primature.gov.rw/rw/internal-events/events-details.html?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=370&cHash=67571bf685dfad31ea46f0b8caf61675, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kist.ac.rw/kist/index.php/archive-news/158-kist-e-learning-laboratory-inaugurated, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.ubumenyi.com/?p=231, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs
contacts: Li Yuanchao, Member ; Pierre Damien Habumuremyi, Prime Minister

title: 50m CNY economic aid
description: On December 26, 2005, Chinese Ambassador to Kenya Guo Chongli, on behalf of the Chinese government, signed several agreements with Somali President Abdulahi Yusuf Ahmed, providing over $6 million of economic aid to Somalia. The agreements included a CNY 50 million grant to the Somali government for financing the provision of goods or projects to be agreed upon thorugh consultations between the Chinese and Somalian governments. The status of the projects is uncertain
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020051226e1cq0076e&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: 524 million USD loan for the expansion of Dar es Salaam Port
description: In 2012, China Exim Bank and the Tanzanian Government negotiated a concessional loan that would finance a 524 million USD expansion of Dar es Salaam Port. According to subsequent sources, the China Communications Construction Company (CCCC) was able to secure this loan in 2012 and the Tanzania Port Authority began seeking construction companies to execute the expansion. Most recently, CCCC has sought litigation against the Tanzania Port Authority over the contract. CCCC contends that the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Transport decided to call for new tenders before termination of the contract and awarded the tender to contractors other than the CCCC on grounds that the ministry had been directed by the Public Procurement Regulatory Authority not to deal with the company as it was among those banned by the World Bank. CCCC argues that it secured funding for the project from China Exim Bank and China and had invested a total of 523,131,015.97 USD in the contract. This litigation has stalled the process of the port renovation.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120326e83p0006l&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020130103e913000mx&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ippmedia.com/frontend/index.php?l=40806, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.worldcargonews.com/htm/n20121028.340558.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201302040633.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://worldmaritimenews.com/archives/64923/tanzania-cccc-announces-plan-for-dar-es-salaam-port-expansion/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: 5M CNY Emergency Humanitarian Aid
description: On February 25, 2004, China offered 5 million yuan worth of material to Morocco as emergency humanitarian aid for the earthquake-shaken areas, according to a spokesman for the Ministry of Commerce, including tents, generators, water purification and lighting equipment. The aid was sent by plane to Morocco on February 28, 2004, according to the Ministry of Commerce.

title: 5MW power station
description: In 2002, China donated the EAGB 5-MW power station to Guinea Bissau. Further details about the project are uncertain.
sources: http://www.irinnews.org/Report/47194/GUINEA-BISSAU-No-water-or-electricity-in-capital-for-three-days, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: 7.4 million economic, technical cooperation agreement
description: In 2008, Ghanaian President Kufuor signed a series of seven agreements with China. Ghanaian Finance Minister Kwadwo Baah Wiredu and Chinese Deputy Minister of Commerce Fu Ziying initiated for their respective countries. An agreement worth $7.4 million USD for technical cooperation was signed. The projects will be determined by the two governments. This agreement does not appear to be tied. Among the other agreements were another $7.4 million USD agreement (ID 1878), a $270 million USD concessional loan for the Bui Hydro Power Dam, a $292 million USD agreement for the dam also from the Exim Bank of China, and an $8.2 million agreement for an ICT based distance learning program at the University of Ghana. China is also providing Ghana 250,000 dollars for Anti Malaria Drugs. STAFF_NOTE: Due to ambiguities in the project document, financial amount has been deactivated for this project. It is unclear whether both this economic and technical cooperation project and #1878 had an amount of 7.4 million USD or whether the total amount for both projects was 7.4 million.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-188009334/ghana-china-sign-seven.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://gh.mofcom.gov.cn/article/slfw/200809/20080905767940.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: 7.4m dollars technical cooperation
description: In 2008, Ghanaian President Kufuor signed a series of seven agreements with China. Ghanaian Finance Minister Kwadwo Baah Wiredu and Chinese Deputy Minister of Commerce Fu Ziying initiated for their respective countries. An agreement worth $7.4 million USD for technical cooperation were signed. The projects will be determined by the two governments. This agreement does not appear to be tied. Among the other agreements were another $7.4 million USD agreement (ID 21604), a $270 million USD concessional loan for the Bui Hydro Power Dam, a $292 million USD agreement for the dam also from the Exim Bank of China, and an $8.2 million agreement for an ICT based distance learning program at the University of Ghana. China is also providing Ghana 250,000 dollars for Anti Malaria Drugs.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-188009334/ghana-china-sign-seven.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: 70 million CNY Grant for Construction of 60 Bed Hospital
description: In 2009, during a signing ceremony on an agreement between China and Namibia for economic and technical cooperation, the Chinese ambassador to Namibia, H.E. Ren Xiaoping, announced that the Chinese government would provide a grant worth 70 million CNY for the construction of a 60-bed hospital in the town of Omuthiya in the Oshikoto Region. During the groundbreaking in 2009, the Namibian President said the hospital would have a medical building, an emergency department, a pharmacy, a laboratory, an operating theater, a central sterile supply department, maternity, paediatric and tuberculosis wards. It would also have a kitchen, laundry facilities, administrative buildings, a mortuary, an incinerator and doctors' and nurses' living quarters. The hospital was finished in 2011, but the work was not to Namibian standards. An estimated 13 million NAD would be required to renovate it before it could be opened to the public.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120328e83r000c6&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.namibian.com.na/indexx.php?archive_id=100143&page_type=archive_story_detail&page=684, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201206211043.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/ce/cena/eng/zngx/t536130.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://allafrica.com/stories/201207041004.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.namibian.com.na/indexx.php?archive_id=95823&page_type=archive_story_detail&page=912, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: China Jiangsu International, State-Owned Company
donor_agency: China Jiangsu International, State-Owned Company
contacts: Loide Kasingo, Deputy Speaker of the National Assembly

title: 700 MW power project in Niger State
description: In May 2012, China announced it would invest 927 million USD in Nigeria's power sector. China stated that it would provide 75 percent of the required funds to build a 700 megawatt hydropower station on the Northern Zungeru River. The Exim Bank is to provide funding. Nigeria would be responsible for the remaining 25 percent. The power plant will be built by two Chinese firms, Sinohydro Corporation and China National Electrical Equipment Corporation. STAFF_NOTE: Earlier media sources reported that the expected completion date for the power plant was 2014. However, later reports expect the power plant will be completed four years after its start date in May 2013.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020121212e8cc001p5&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020121211e8cb000nx&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201305290202.html?viewall=1, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201306050432.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XHBUSW0020130603e9630000k&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://fmi.gov.ng/we-shall-revolutionize-the-nations-power-sector-jonathan/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://citizensplatform.net/2012/12/china-to-invest-927m-in-nigerias-power-sector/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.thetidenewsonline.com/2012/11/19/fg-signs-mou-with-chinese-firms-â€¦terminates-manitobaâ€™s-hydro-power-contract/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: 8.9 million euros for sports, cultural and sanitation projects
description: In January of 2009, China agreed to provide Senegal with $11.5 million USD in aid for sports, cultural, and sanitation projects. It is unclear whether or not the funds were successfully disbursed or implemented. The project appears to be untied. STAFF_NOTES: This project could be related to ID#2085, at 2010 loan of $4M USD 'toward the cultural, sports, agricultural, and health sectors'.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020090129e51t007n1&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: 800,000 doses of Artequick for Malaria
description: On April 21, 2012, the Chinese Embassy donated 800,000 doses of Artequick, two motocycles, laboratory equipment, and office equipment to the Comoran Ministry of Health. This donation is planned to help eradicate malaria in the country and better prevent the disease in pregnant women and children under five years old. This donation was made as a part of the 2007 program initiated by the Guangzhou University of Chinese Medicine (GZUCM) for the island of Moheli in the Comoros to eliminate malaria. Since the start of the program, the persistence of malaria has been significantly decreased. Linked to project ID #409
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020120422e84m0030e&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Wang Leyou, Chinese Ambassador to Comoros

title: 9 Million USD Loan
description: On December 10th, 2012, the Rwandan and Chinese government signed an economic and technical cooperation agreement for an interest-free loan worth 9 million USD that would be repaid within 10 years. The agreement was signed by the Rwandan Minister of Foreign Affairs and cooperation, Hon Louise Mushikiwabo, and the Chinese Vice Minister of commerce, Chen Jian. The loan is intended to be used for trade and investment between the two countries.
sources: http://www.minaffet.gov.rw/index.php?id=886&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=50&cHash=2b51bd62d465eea399db610f292b96c9, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

donor_agency: China Ministry of Commerce, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Rwandan Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Government Agency
contacts: Chen Jian, China's Vice Minister of Commerce ; Hon Louise Mushikiwabo, Rwanda's Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation

title: 9.4 million USD cooperation agreement loan
description: On September 22, 2012, Mozambique and China signed two cooperation agreements worth about 25 million USD in total. The first agreement was for an interest-free loan of 9.4 million USD that would be used for projects that would identified later but dealing with infrastructure development. The Mozambican government was represented by Victor Borges, Minister of Fisheries, and the Chinese government by Li Rongcan, the Assistant Minister of Commerce. The other agreement was for a 14.3 million USD monetary grant (project ID #30381).
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020120923e89n005ei&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201209230446.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: 90 seminars and training sessions
description: In 2011, the two governments agreed to hold 90 seminars and training sessions between China and Senegal in sectors like commerce, diplomacy, administration, education, and health. It is unclear exactly when these sessions were held and what the details of the events are.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020110808e7880033n&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: A 45 km electricity distribution line between Quifangondo and Mabubas
description: In 2006, the China-Exim bank funded the construction of a 45 km, 60 kv electric transmission substation from Quifangondo to Mabubas for approximately $14.59 million. A PPIAF source reported that China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) was involved in implementing the project, however an Angolan source reported that it was owned by Guangxi Hydroelectric Construction Bureau (GHCB), which later worked on the rehabilitation of the Mabubas hydroelectric dam. This project was completed in 2006. PPIAF-ID:39 STAFF_NOTES: Quifangondo is an extrapolation of a Chinese translation of the location's name. Project #28218 was discovered and coded as connected to these transmission lines.
sources: http://wiredspace.wits.ac.za/bitstream/handle/10539/10452/Chapter%25252525201.pdf?..., Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.angolahub.com/index.php/en/angola-news/1120-barragem-das-mabubas-em-angola-foi-de-novo-inaugurada-segunda-feira, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://222.161.60.122/department/gjgs/gcdt.html, Other

donor_agency: Guangxi Hydroelectric Construction Bureau (GHCB), State-Owned Company; Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency; China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC)

title: ADDIS-ADAMA express way
description: On June 27, 2009, the Director-General of Ethiopian Roads Authority (ERA) Zaid Woldegebriel and the Chinese Communication and Construction Company (CCCC) manager signed a deal to construct a new eight-lane asphalt expressway stretching 80 km from Addis Ababa to Adama, Ethiopia's first expressway. It will reduce the transportation time on Ethiopia's main import-export route from three hours to one hour. The project, an estimated total cost of $612 million, will be financed by a $350 million Export-Import Bank of China loan, and the Ethiopian government covering the balance. Construction began in April 2010. According to Samson Wondimu, Communication Director of ERA, construction was more than 30% complete in April 2012. This project has provided the groundwork for the use of innovative technology via tolls and creates local employment opportunities. It is also expected to contribute to the development of roadways between capital and regional locations, such as Hawassa and Bale. Construction is expected to be completed in early 2014. Terms of the loan are uncertain, but Deborah Brautigam reports tolls will help repay the loan over 20 years. PPIAF-ID:131

title: Abidjan-Grand Bassam Motorway construction
description: On October 3, 2011, the Ivory Coast announced that the Export-Import Bank of China offered the Ivory Coast a $114 million loan at two-percent interest over 20 years to finance a motorway construction project linking Abidjan to Grand-Bassam, 30 km to the east. Finance Minister Charles Koffi Diby said the project was aimed at developing the tourist sector along Ivory Coast's south coast and helping ease congestion in Abidjan. The project will be implemented by China National Machinery and Equipment Company (CMEC), and the contract will last 30 months. Construction on the project began in August 2012. STAFF_NOTES: Concessionality is determined assuming equal principle payments and 2 payments per year. Also, a transcript of the Council of Minister's meeting on June 27, 2012 stated the President signed a loan with the Ex-Im Bank for $144.7 million USD.

title: Accord for commercial, economic and technical cooperation
description: On August 31, 2002 Prime Minister Zhu Rongji and President Biya signed five accords including one for commercial, economic and technical cooperation. No further information about this project is known, including its financial amount, sector, start and end date, and implementing agencies.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcapp0020020831dy8v0025t&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.eastday.com/epublish/gb/paper148/20020831/class014800004/hwz756862.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Accord signing
description: On April 4, 2003 the Chinese Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Wenchang and Cameroonian Minister delegate the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in charge of Commonwealth Affairs Dion Ngute signed an accord for a grant worth 200 million CFA. The grant was not attributed to a specific project at the time of the accord signing. Instead, the countries would each agree on suitable projects and continue talks. Follow up about the grant does not reveal any evidence of how it was used. It is possible that the grant was later allocated to major projects in Cameroon, particularly a 30 billion CFA project to build 3 hydroelectric dams #289, which was decided upon in November 2003.
sources: http://www.scribd.com/doc/12824989/CRS-Report-China-and-SubSaharan-Africa, Other; http://allafrica.com/stories/200304070761.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Accra-Kumasi trunk road rehabilitation
description: (PPIAF) In 2003, China agreed to sponsor the reconstruction of the Ofankor-Nsawam dual carriage-way. The Chinese vice minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Wenchang and President John Agyekum Kufuor signed the agreement. In April of 2006, the Ofankor-Nsawam dual carriage-way was completed at opened to vehicular traffic after two years of construction. Work started in June of 2004 under an interest-free loan agreement worth $28 million USD between Ghana and China. The terms of the loan were that it would be repaid in annual installments by the Ghanaian government over a period of ten years from November of 2012 to October of 2022 with export commodities of Ghana or convertible currencies to be agreed upong by the two governments. The road, 17.4 km in length, has no restrictions to vehicular traffic. The road is part of the Accra-Kumasi trunk road rehabilitation project. The contracting firm for the project is China Railway Engineering Corporation. The project includes the construction of a 20 meter fly-over bridge over the rail line near Ofankor. The design can handle 13 tons. The construction of the road was started by the New Patriotic Party administration under former president Kufuor via Internally Generated Funds. There is a discrepancy between financial values; sources say that the cost of the project was possibly $23.190001 million USD. PPIAF-ID:143
sources: http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200606/20/eng20060620_275468.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.orange.mu/kinews/afp/business/126197/china-paves-way-to-economic-ties-with-africa.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/newscenter/2006-06/19/content_4716312.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/newscenter/2006-06/20/content_4716824.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.modernghana.com/news/46336/1/parliament-approves-loan-for-ofankor-nsawam-road.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.modernghana.com/news/98036/1/ofankor-nsawam-dual-carriageway-opened-to-traffic.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://ghanaweb.com/mobile/wap.small/news.article.php?ID=71860, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-19859918_ITM, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.presidency.gov.gh/agenda/transport, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://news.peacefmonline.com/social/201108/63844.php, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.africawindows.com/html/feizhouzixun/feizhouxinwen/20080806/19426.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://web.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=c9c78b97-1fcd-46d4-b0d2-0a1b12439c55%40sessionmgr115&vid=4&hid=127, Other

title: Adams-Karen-Ngong-Bomas road construction
description: In 2012, the China Exim Bank extended a preferential loan to Kenya for the construction of the southern by-pass road project. The loan is for up to 85% percent of the cost of the project. It was expected that construction would begin in early 2013 and be finished by 2016. According to the Kenya Urban Roads Authority, the project is currently under design.

title: Additional Medical materials to Tappita Hospital
description: A delegation including the Deputy Minister of Commerce of the People's Republic of China, Fu Ziying carried out a four-day official visit from April 22 to 25, 2010. Followng Bilateral Discussions a signing ceremony between the Governments of the Republic of Liberia and the People's Republic of China where six agreements were signed, including one for the provision of 10 million RMB Yuan by the Chinese Government for additional medical materials to the Tappita Hospital to support the operation of the hospital. The materials may have been donated when the hospital was completed in July of 2010 (see project #1673)
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020100428e64s000q4&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://finance.sina.com.cn/roll/20111207/061010947868.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201004220802.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.emansion.gov.lr/2press.php?news_id=1531&related=7&pg=sp, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Additional loan for government complex
description: In 2009, the China Exim Bank loaned the Zambian government 25 million USD for the completion of the Government Complex in the Kamwala area of Lusaka originally started in 2002 with a grant from the Chinese government (see Project ID #2126). The original grant in 2002 was only for 8.4 million USD, but the complex proved to need additional funds. In 2009, the Zambian government acquired a 25 million USD concessional loan from the China Exim Bank to complete the project. The loan carried the terms of 2 percent interest rate and a 15 year maturity with a 5 year grace period for a total of a 10 year repayment schedule. There was a .5 percent commitment fee and .75 percent service charge added to the loan. As reported in Project #2126, the project was 85% complete as of 2011.
sources: http://www.mofnp.gov.zm/index2.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=194&Itemid=152, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Administrative Structure Aid
description: In 2006, China agreed to provide financial aid for Benin's administrative structure. It is unclear what the total value of the project is, and what the details of the project are. The project is affiliated with agreements on debt forgiveness, a 30 million Yuan loan, and others. (ID#24, ID#26, ID#11699).

title: Agreement MoU for geological development
description: On December 5, 2011, Ethiopia and Chongqing Bureau of Geology and Mineral Exploration and Development of China signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) that enables the two sides to cooperate on geological and mineral development. Sinknesh Ejigu, Ethiopian Minister of Mines, and Wang Li, Director General of Chongqing Bureau of Geology and Mineral Exploration and Development signed the agreement on behalf of their institutions respectively. From this collaboration, the Ministry of Mines is working with the Mines Bureau of Chongqing State to prepare maps for mining investment covering 120 square kilometers in the southern and southwestern portions of Ethiopia. The Chinese experts presented a project proposal on March 28, 2012, which went under Ethiopian review. The mapping would take 5 years to finish (would start in 2013) and cost 10 million dollars, coming from the Chinese Bureau. Three million dollars will be a part of upfront costs incurred in the first year of the project. They will also send 40 experts to assist. The geological maps and drilling tests that result will help encourage international and local companies to invest in mineral development and exploration. Overall, the project would help Ethiopia reach its plan to increase coverage of mapping from 50pc to 100pc, increase areas for industrial exploration from 48 sites to 77, and thus have a better bargaining position with the generous supply of minerals specified.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNHA000020111206e7c60002y&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://addisfortune.com/Vol_12_No_622_Archive/Chinese%20to%20Help%20Map%20Mining%20Potential%20of%20Ethiopia.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Chongqing Geology, Mineral Exploration, and Development Bureau, Government Agency
donor_agency: Chongqing Geology, Mineral Exploration, and Development Bureau, Government Agency

title: Agreement With Chinese University
description: On July 10, 2007 Eduardo Mondlane University, represented by Vice-Chancellor Filipe Couto, and the Sichuan Agricultural University of China signed a memorandum of understanding, under which the Chinese university would provide support to training students in rural development, agronomy, veterinary science, and engineering. The new school will begin operations in the Vilankulo district in February of 2008, and will initially accommodate 300 students. The new school opened in 2008.

title: Agreement for Medical Assistance at John F. Kennedy Medical Center
description: On June 1, 2011 Chinese ambassador to Liberia Zhao Jianhuo and Health Minister Dr. Walter Gwenigale signed a partnership agreement aimed at strengthening Liberia's health sector. Under the agreement, Chinese medical doctors will continue to help Liberia's largest referral hospital, the John F. Kennedy Medical Center, in the provision of medical services to the needy. The agreement provides that the Chinese government will continue to bring Chinese medical doctors to the country to take up various assignments in the health sector of the country.

description: In 2005, China and Lesotho signed a 20 million LSL economic and technical cooperation agreement to be used in projects agreed upon by both governments. Lesotho Minister of Foreign Affairs Monyane Moleleki and Chinese Ambassador Qiu Bohua signed on behalf of their governments.

title: Agreement for economic and technical cooperation
description: On December 16, 2008, China and Lesotho signed an Agreement on Economic and Technical Cooperation worth 20 million CNY. The Lesotho Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Relations, Mohlabi Tsekoa and the Chinese Ambassador to Lesotho, Gao Deyi, signed the agreement for their governments.

title: Agreement for hospital construction
description: In October of 2012, China signed an aid agreement with Niger to provide 25.6 million USD to build a national referral hospital in Niamey. At the same time, they also signed an aid agreement for the acquisition of 30 vehicles worth 1.9 million USD (project ID #30416).

title: Agreement for ministerial offices, research center
description: On September 3, 2008, the Chinese Vice-Minister of Commerce and the Ivory Coast Minister of Foreign Affairs signed an agreement worth 26 million CFA for rehabilitate ministerial offices and to rebuild a Research Center to fight malaria. Anti-malaria medicines were also provided by the Chinese government. The status of the agreement is uncertain.
sources: http://vlex.cn/vid/deeply-fighting-poverty-cote-ivoire-323722219, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020080903e4930000b&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agreement for provision of broadcasting van
description: On April 5, 2012, the Chinese government signed a 31.5 million CNY agreement with the Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation for the provision of a broadcasting van. The ZBC received the van on February 19, 2013. The van and equipment will enable ZBC to shift from analog to digital broadcasting as mandated by the International Telecommunications Union whose compliance deadline is June 15, 2015. This project is possibly linked to an MoU signed between Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation and CCTV (Project ID#30285).

title: Agreement in gas and oil
description: On February 3, 2004 Algeria and China signed five cooperation agreements. One agreement featured a framework cooperation agreement in gas and oil between the minister of energy and mining and the Chinese State Committee for Development and Reform. Results did not reveal further information about the status or details of the project, including project dates or flow type (if any). Other agreements include a programme for the implementation of exchanges in teaching and research, an agreement for economic and technical cooperation, a framework agreement according to which China will offer Algeria a preferential loan of about 48m dollars, and a memorandum of understanding for economic cooperation between the Ministry of Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises and Handicrafts and the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. The signing ceremony was attended by President Bouteflika and President Hu Jintao.

title: Agreement on Education Cooperation
description: In 2004, China and South Africa signed an agreement on cooperation in the realm of education. It is unclear what the terms of the agreement are or how it was implemented.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020040630e06u002jp&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/world/2004-06/29/content_1555120.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
recipient_agencies: Ministry of Education, Government Agency

title: Agreement on Technical and Scientific Cooperation
description: On September 4th, 2012, the Deputy Prime Minister of the Council of State Affairs of the People's Republic of China, Hui Liangyu, signed seven cooperation agreements with Congo. One of the seven agreements included an agreement on economic and technical cooperation. Also signed at this meeting were an interest-free loan of 50 million RMB (Project #30497), a donation of 50 million RMB, a memorandum on financing the reconstruction of the affected areas at a cost of one billion USD, a financing agreement for the nationwide telecommunications project's Phase III at 68,411,003.85 USD, an individual loan agreement for the road project on the border with Gabon at 76,894,549.60 USD, a convention on the proposed construction of social housing in Mont Mambou at 69,689,969 USD (Project #30499), and an agreement on technical and scientific cooperation between the Academy of Tropical Agriculture of China (ACLS) and the center of research and initiation of technology projects of the Congo (CRIPT).
sources: http://www.congo-site.com/La-Chine-octroie-plus-de-600-milliards-FCFA-a-la-Republique-du-Congo_a13364.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.panapress.com/Congo,-China-sign-cooperation-agreements--13-841438-0-lang2-index.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
donor_agency: Academy of Tropical Agriculture of China (ACLS), Academic, Training and Research
recipient_agencies: center of research and initiation of technology projects of the Congo (CRIPT), Government Agency
contacts: Hiu Liangyu, Deputy Prime Minister of the Council of State Affairs (China)

title: Agreement on cooperation
description: In 2000, Chinese President Jiang Zemin met with South African President Thabo Mbeki to sign a series of agreements, including one on trade and economic technical cooperation. It is unclear what the terms of the agreement were or how it was implemented.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=chndly0020010805dw4p003dx&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agreement on economic and cultural cooperation
description: In 2003, China and Ethiopia signed cooperation agreements on visas, economic and cultural cooperation. The agreements were signed by Ethiopian Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin, Youth, Sports and Culture Minister Ambassador Teshome Toga, State Minister for Finance and Economic Development Dr Mulu Ketsela and their Chinese counterparts. The status of the agreement is uncertain.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020031215dzcf0008d&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/world/2003-12/15/content_1232494.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Teshome Toga, ; Seyoum Mesfin, ; Dr Mulu Ketsela,

title: Agreement on economic and technological cooperation
description: In 2006, China signed an agreement with Sierra Leone regarding economic and technological cooperation. The agreement was signed between Chinese VP Zeng Qinghong and Sierra Leonian VP Solomon Berewa. The two countries would maintain various forms of close contact, including high level exchanges. Both sides should also expand exchanges and cooperation between various governmental departments, parliaments and political parties. Secondly, the two countries should further explore the complementary nature of their specific advantages, expand trade and economic cooperation and seek common development. Thirdly, the two countries should advance consultation and cooperation on regional and international affairs. Fourthly, Zeng said the two countries should push forward cooperation in such fields as human resources development. It is unclear if the document has been implemented.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AFNWS00020060509e259001kd&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/newscenter/2006-04/24/content_4469135.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agreement on investment, economic and technological cooperation, finance and diplomacy
description: Following his visit to China in 2005, Equatorial Guinea's President Teodoro Obiang Nguema announced that he had signed agreements on investment, economic and technological co-operation, finance and diplomacy with China. It is unclear what the terms of the agreements are and how they are being implemented in Equatorial Guinea.
sources: http://www.gov.cn/jrzg/2009-03/28/content_1271090.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=WDAN000020051031e1av0002f&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agreement on joint economic/trade commission
description: In 2000, Chinese President Jiang Zemin and South African President Thabo Mbeki signed an agreement to create a joint economic and trade commission between the two countries. It appears that the Commission was established in 2001.
sources: http://english.people.com.cn/200112/11/print20011211_86422.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=chndly0020010805dw4p003dx&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agreement on loan
description: In 2009, China and Mauritania signed a series of agreements at Nouakchott, including one for a 60 million yuan interest-free loan. Chinese assistant foreign minister Zhai Jun participated in the signing of the agreements. The project appears to be untied, and it is unclear how the funds were used.Separate from #13189.
sources: http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-215348171.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agreement on media cooperation with Sierra Leone News Agency
description: In 2001, China's state-owned Xinhua News Agency signed an agreement on media cooperation with Sierra Leone News Agency (SLENA). Xinhua's Editor-in-Chief Nan Zhenzhong and the visiting SLENA president, Abdul Karim Jalloh, signed the agreement at the headquarters of Xinhua. Under the deal, the two news organizations will exchange their English news reports and Xinhua will provide SLENA with news-receiving equipment. In addition, the two sides will render assistance to their correspondents based in each other's country and visiting press missions.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=xnews00020010720dx7j0001d&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
donor_agency: Xinhua News Agency, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Sierra Leone News Agency (SLENA), State-Owned Company

title: Agreement to build ministerial complex
description: In 2012, China agreed to build a 60 million USD ministerial complex for Liberia within three years, beginning in mid-2012. The ministerial complex will be constructed at the new Defense Ministry site in Congo Town by a Chinese construction company through a bidding process to be done in China.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201201271146.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120918e89i000uo&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120127e81r00172&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.thenewdawnliberia.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7834:editorial-construction-of-the-ministerial-complex-&catid=28:editorial&Itemid=67, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://thenewslib.com/news/634-ministerial-complex-to-be-built-on-peace-island-ministerial-complex-to-be-built-on-peace-island, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofa.gov.lr/press.php?news_id=728, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120918e89i000uo&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120127e81r00172&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Zhao Jianhua, Chinese Ambassador to Liberia

title: Agreement to provide loans to Ghana
description: In 2002, Chinese President Jiang Zemin met with Ghanaian President John Kufuor to strengthen ties between the two countries. The two signed four documents including an agreement to provide loans to Ghana. It is unclear how much the loans were worth or how they will be used.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=xnews00020021101dyb10033a&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agreements after Talks
description: On August 27, 2002, Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji met with King Mohammed VI, and spoke with Prime Minister Abderrahmane Youssoufi on ways to enhance bilateral ties and signed several accords following the talks. The status of the agreements is unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=xnews00020020828dy8t00d9t&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agreements on econ-tech, maritime, aviation, taxation, and cultural cooperation
description: On April 16, 2002 Chinese President Jiang Zemin visited Tunisia and met with Tunisian President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali for talks. After the talks, the two sides signed seven documents on the topics of economic and technological cooperation, maritime transportation, civil aviation transportation, avoidance of double taxation and prevention of evasion with respect to tax, an implementation plan of cultural cooperation for the years of 2002, 2003 and 2004, among two others (see #14020 and #2476).
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=xnews00020020416dy4g005k1&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agricultural Cooperation Agreement
description: In 2001, China's Premier Zhu Rongji met with Equatorial Guinean President Obiang Nguema Mbasogo at Zhongnanhai to sign an agreement regarding agricultural cooperation. It is unclear what the terms of the agreement were. The project does not appear to be tied.
sources: http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/eng/wjb/zzjg/fzs/gjlb/2974/2976/t16501.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=xnews00020011119dxbj00269&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agricultural Demonstration Center
description: In a decision made on June 23, 2006, Wen Jiabao announced a commitment to build a modern center in Tanzania for agricultural training. The center was built on a 62 hectare site at Morogoro in the Mvomero District. Construction and design was completed by the Chongqing Seed Corp. The center was reportedly financed by the Chinese government, as well as the provision of a Chinese team to manage the center and provide assistance for three years. Construction started in October of 2009 and an official handing-over ceremony happened on April 2, 2011. Construction wasn't fully complete until November 2011, however. The finished site has 10 ha of experimental fields, 2 ha of offices, laboratory space, and training space, and 50 ha of outside fields equipped with modern irrigation. The total cost came to 40 million CNY and was financed with a grant.
sources: http://www.scribd.com/doc/80127952/Brautigam-China-in-Tanzania, Other; http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-147815770/china-gives-tanzania-10m.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agricultural Donation
description: In 2005, China donated 46 containers (960 tons) of agricultural and other inputs worth roughly $1.0003 million USD to Angola. These containers are mainly for farmers of the northern Malanje province. The donation includes 150,000 hoes and handles, 159,000 axes, 218,697 cutlasses, 50 scythes, and 1,000 plows. Chinese Ambassador to Angola, Zhang Beisan, handed over the deal to the Social Welfare Deputy Minister Maria da Luz.
sources: http://books.google.com/books?id=9V6KiGcOsKYC&pg=PA162, Other; http://allafrica.com/stories/200507250201.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mbendi.com/indy/agff/af/an/p0005.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; www.ccs.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2009/04/dfid-3rd-edition.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

title: Agricultural Equipment
description: On April 9, 2001, Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Hou Qingru donated a batch of agricultural machinery worth 2 million CNY. The donation included tractors, maize sowing machines, grain drilling machines, bulldozers, and diving water pumps. At the hand-over ceremony, Zimbabwean Minister of Lands, Agriculture, and Rural Resettlement Joseph Made said the equipment will be given to the Agricultural and Rural Development Authority, District Development Fund, and the Zimbabwe Farmers' Union.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=xnews00020010715dx4900bh5&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Commercial Farmers' Union of Zimbabwe, National NGO; Zimbabwean District Decelopment Fund (DDF), Government Agency; Zimbabwe Agricultural and Rural Development Authority, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Commercial Farmers' Union of Zimbabwe, National NGO; Zimbabwean District Decelopment Fund (DDF), Government Agency; Zimbabwe Agricultural and Rural Development Authority, Government Agency
contacts: Hou Qingru, Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe ; Joseph Made, Minister of Lands, Agriculture and Rural Resettlement

title: Agricultural Experts
description: In 2009, the Chinese government dispatched 3 senior experts in the field of agriculture economy, agriculture equipment and irrigation to provide technical assistance to Botswana and enhance the bilateral cooperation.
sources: http://www.sundaystandard.info/article.php?NewsID=9639&GroupID=2, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020091204e5c4000ph&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://bw.china-embassy.org/eng/xwdt/t785778.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Agricultural Production and Training at Egerton University
description: In 2008, Nanjing Agricultural University held two annual training programs at Egerton University in Kenya: the Quality and Safety of Agro-Products and Crop Greenhouse Production. Over the last few years, the programs have trained over 200 senior agricultural technicians and experts from over 10 African countries.
sources: http://www.chinafrica.cn/english/universities/txt/2012-04/27/content_449513.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinafrica.cn/english/universities/txt/2012-04/27/content_449513.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.njau.edu.cn/?m=article&id=31806, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Nanjing Agricultural University, Academic, Training and Research; Egerton University, Academic, Training and Research
donor_agency: Nanjing Agricultural University, Academic, Training and Research
recipient_agencies: Egerton University, Academic, Training and Research

title: Agricultural Technical Assistance
description: In September of 2007, the Juncao plant technical assistance project began implementation. 763 local farmers and 14 officials of the Ministry of Agriculture have been trained to use the facility and have been familiarized with the Juncao grass. The technical assistance is coming from Fujian Province. In a 2007 speech, the acting Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Relations stated that the agreement was worth 20 million renminbi. Further details have not been found.
sources: http://www.sourcejuice.com/1388740/2010/10/15/Fujian-speed-world-leading-technology-home-abroad-promote/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/chn/gxh/tyb/zwbd/t566499.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.foreign.gov.ls/speeches/Speech_Tsekoa_27_08_07.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.foreign.gov.ls/news/Press_Release_16_December_2008.php, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.gov.ls/articles/2007/CHINA_FUNDS_MUSHROOM.php, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
recipient_agencies: Lesotho Ministry of Agriculture, Government Agency

title: Agricultural Technical Training, Rice Cultivation
description: The graduation ceremony for China's technical training project on rice cultivation was held at the Liberian Vocational and Technical Training Institute on May 23, 2006. Liberian Vice President Boakai, the Liberian Deputy Minister, the Chinese Ambassador Lin Songtian, along with other officials attended the ceremony. Participants of the ceremony also included representatives from the World Food Programme and the FAO; the media reported over 400 participants. Ambassador Lin congratulated the training participants for producing twice the Liberian record of highest per mu yield of rice after five months of training under Chinese experts.
sources: http://www.gov.cn/gzdt/2006-05/24/content_289842.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
implementing_agency: Booker Washington Institute, Academic, Training and Research
recipient_agencies: Booker Washington Institute, Academic, Training and Research

title: Agricultural assistance with FAO
description: During the Beijing summit in 2007, the Chinese government, Gabon, and the FAO signed the South-South Cooperation Tripartite Agreement. China committed and fielded over 30 agricultural experts for this project between 2007 and 2009. Areas of activities and applied technologies involved in this project are grain, vegetable, fruit and crop production, small animals, fisheries, and more.
sources: http://www.fao.org/fileadmin/templates/tc/spfs/pdf/Agri_Interna_Cooperation_China.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020071222e3ci003s5&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fao.org/fileadmin/templates/rap/files/epublications/ChinaedocFINAL.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
implementing_agency: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), Multilateral

title: Agricultural development grant
description: On September 12, 2008, China granted Egypt 1.5 million USD to support Egypt's agriculture sector with Chinese expertise. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.In the same agreement, China gave Egypt a grant to construct a school for the handicapped (See Project ID#620).
sources: http://www.alacrastore.com/storecontent/Intellinews/IntelliNews_MENA_Today-EG188595254, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agricultural donations
description: In March 2011, China granted the Ivory Coast over 200 tons of fertilizers and hundreds of agricultural machines valued at 2 million euros.
sources: http://vlex.cn/vid/deeply-fighting-poverty-cote-ivoire-323722219, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agricultural expert training
description: As part of the FOCAC commitment to send agricultural experts to Africa, China made a commitment to train Senegalese Agriculture experts in September 2007. In November of that same year, it was reported that over 180 local Senegalese farmers received theoretical and practical training. The start date, end date, and value for this project are yet unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020071222e3ci003s5&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020071223e3ca002xn&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://vlex.cn/vid/focus-agricultural-reaches-heights-198698935, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://thechina.biz/china-economy/future-of-sino-senegalese-relations-bright/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020071222e3ci003s5&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020071223e3ca002xn&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agricultural experts
description: On June 12, 2008, al-Zubayr Bashir Taha, Minister of Agriculture and Forestry and Chinese Minister of Agriculture, Sun Zhengcai, signed an agreement for China to send agricultural experts to Sudan. The ceremony was attended by Ali Osman Mohamed Taha, Sudan's Vice-President and Xi Jinping, China's Vice-President. A news report in August 2010 mentioned the project as having been completed. The amount and exact start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://www.china.org.cn/business/2010-08/13/content_20701948.htm, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCMEP0020080612e46c003e9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agricultural experts and technicians
description: Under the South-South Cooperation program (potentially the SSC Tripartite Agreement), China has sent agricultural experts to Africa. It is unclear how many experts there were or how they helped Ghana, among other countries. One such example of this cooperation was a ten-day training on technology of maize cultivation which opened on August 21, 2003 with the participation of ten African countries including Sudan, Ghana, Kenya, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Uganda, Sierra Leone, Botswana, Tanzania and the host country Ethiopia. The training was jointly organized by the Ethiopian Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MoFED) in collaboration with the Chinese government. During the ten-day training, the participants will be provided with courses that focus on the technical know-how in maize cultivation and field management, and the theory and method in agriculture technology popularization.
all_recipients: Africa, regional, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Mauritania
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BDU0000020030822dz8m0001y&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://gb.cri.cn/1321/2004/07/13/542@229403.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fao.org/newsroom/en/news/2004/48027/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fao.org/fileadmin/templates/rap/files/epublications/ChinaedocFINAL.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

donor_agency: China National Building Material Company (CNBM), State-Owned Company
recipient_oecd_name: Mauritania; Africa, regional; Ethiopia; Mali; Ghana
recipient_iso3: MRT; Africa, regional; ETH; MLI; GHA
contacts: Mulu Ketsela, (Ministry of Finance and Economic Development)

title: Agricultural machinery
description: On November 15, 2005, the Chinese government donated 141 million TZS worth of agricultural machinery to Tanzania, including three tractors, seven power tillers, two milling machines, and two water pumping systems. Tanzanian Agriculture Minister Wilfred Ngirwa praised the donation.
sources: http://www.focac.org/eng/jzdlm/jmhz/t222842.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Wilfred Ngirwa, Permanent Secretary ; Yu Qingtai,

title: Agricultural machinery donation
description: On February 22, 2002, the Chinese government donated a batch of agricultural machinery to Kenya worth 5 million KES. The equipment, including eight walking tractors, 20 diesel engines, and 20 maize crushers, were handed over to Kenyan Deputy Agricultural Minister Joseph Munyao by Chinese Ambassador to Kenya Du Qiwen. The donation was made in accordance with an agricultural cooperation agreement reached by the two governments during Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's visit to Kenya in April 2001.
sources: http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200302/27/eng20030227_112401.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Zhu Rongji, ; Mr. Du Qiwen, ; Joseph Munyao,

title: Agricultural technician training
description: In 2002 it was reported China donated 7 million CNY for the training of agricultural technicians. This project is unconfirmed.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcap00020021125dybp006mx&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agricultural technique mechanization
description: In September 2004, Zhejiang Sifang Group Corporation signed a pact to mobilize funds from the Chinese-Exim Bank for comprehensive mechanization of the farming method by empowering peasant farmers. Minister of agriculture, Bamidele Dada signed on behalf of his ministry, Bello on behalf of the commission, Mrs. Modupe Adelaja on behalf Small and Medium Enterprises Development Agency of Nigeria while Mr. Lin Guangping signed on behalf of SIFANG.The status of this pact is uncertain.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/200409080451.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: Zhejiang Sifang Group Corporation, State-Owned Company
donor_agency: Zhejiang Sifang Group Corporation, State-Owned Company; Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Small and Medium Enterprises Development Agency of Nigeria (SMEDAN), Government Agency
contacts: Nenadi Usman, ; Modupe Adelaja, ; Lin Guangping, ; Bamidele Dada, ; Olusegu Obasanjo,

title: Agriculture Assessment team
description: In August of 2005 the Chinese Ambassador to Liberia Lin Songtian stated that China would empower two teams to train Liberians in rice and other crop production. Amb. Songtian made the disclosure during the graduation exercise of the foundation for African Development Aid (ADA) ex-combatants agriculture skills training program. He further noted that the agriculture assessment team was expected to arrive in Liberia within the month. The Chinese envoy said the Chinese experts would spend enough time in Liberia until Liberian trainees prove themselves competent. A report issued by the Chinese Embassy in Liberia stated that starting in September 2005, a Chinese agricultural team worked in the Booker Washington Institute in Kakata, Margibi County, disseminating high-yielding hybrid rice technology. This team was to be replaced by a second one, which would continue the current work for another two years.
sources: http://lr.china-embassy.org/chn/sghdhzxxx/t197788.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://allafrica.com/stories/200508020433.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Agriculture, Infrastructure and Telecommunications Agreements
description: In February of 2006, Chinese President Hu Jintao and Togolese President Faure Essozimna Gnassingbe signed co-operation agreements focusing on agriculture, infrastructure and telecommunications after talks in Beijing. Faure visited Beijing for a week-long state visit, his first trip to China since assuming the presidency in May 2005.
sources: http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200602/14/eng20060214_242562.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Aid Deal- includes zanzibar IT
description: On February 16, 2009 Chinese President Hu Jintao signed a 150-million-yuan aid deal with Tanzania. Of the total, around one-fifth was set aside for the development of the IT sector on the semi-autonomous island of Zanzibar, with the remaining funds reserved for the main land. No further information can be found for this grant, likely due to its vague nature.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020090330e53u001h6&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=WDAN000020090216e52g0000e&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Aid Grant
description: On December 30 2005, Chinese Ambassador Chen Gonglai and Niger's acting Foreign Minister and Defense Minister Hassane Souley Dit Bonto signed an agreement for a grant of 30 million CNY for projects to be decided upon by both governments. The projects financed with this grant cannot be determined.
sources: http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200512/31/eng20051231_232076.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Hassane Souley Bit Bonto, ; Chen Gonglai,

title: Aid after locust plague
description: In the past five years, the Chinese government provided emergency aid in materials and cash to Guinea-Bissau to combat a locust plague and cholera. These donations are unconfirmed.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=CHNDHK0020110421e74m00014&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Aid and interest free loans
description: In April 2010 during a visit to Libreville, a Chinese delegation signed an agreement to provide aid and and interest-free loans to Gabon. The status of these agreements is uncertain.
sources: http://www.p5w.net/kuaixun/201009/t3193196.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=PLATT00020100527e65r0010e&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

donor_agency: China Petroleum & Chemical Corporation (Sinopec Ltd.), State-Owned Company

title: Aid for drought victims
description: In April 2000, China donated $200,000 to Ethiopia to fight the severe drought.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=afnws00020021107dw4r01ctx&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Aid for voluntary repatriation in Darfur
description: On 25 January, 2008, the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid in Southern Darfur, Adam Ibrahim, took delivery of a batch of Chinese aid meant to support voluntary repatriation for the displaced including water equipment, school furniture, and accommodation facilities worth 60 million CNY. The current status, exact commitment date, and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCMEP0020080126e41q00001&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Aid package
description: In 2007, China pledged to Guinea an aid package worth $5.2 million USD. It is unclear how the funds were used.
sources: http://power.in-en.com/news/intl/2007/07/INEN_108521.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://mascareignas.blogspot.com/2007/07/china-to-fund-1-bln-hydro-dam-in-guinea.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Aid package
description: On September 10, 2004 Chinese President Hu Jintao and the Gabonese President El Hadj Omar Bongo Ondimba attended the signing ceremony of an aid package of $5 million USD granted by Beijing for various development projects in Gabon. An agreement on economic, technological cooperation and #20490 was signed at the same time. Additionally, the Belinga Iron Ore project #630 appears to have been agreed upon at the same time.
sources: http://www.scribd.com/doc/12824989/CRS-Report-China-and-SubSaharan-Africa, Other; http://allafrica.com/stories/200409100513.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Aid package without any political conditions
description: In 2005, China offered Gabon an aid package 'without any political conditions.' Further details of the package are uncertain.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AGEE000020070425e34q0004s&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Aid packages
description: During the 2010 Forum for Economic and Trade Cooperation between China and Portuguese speaking countries in Macau, Wen Jiaobao announced relief packages worth 3.56 billion yuan to Angola, Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, Mozambique, and East Timor. Part of this money (10 million yuan) may go to the poorer nations for medical equipment and infrastructure. This project is linked to ID #s 797, 798 in which the forum also allocated low interest loans for 1.6 billion yuan and a 1 billion fund to boost trade between China and the Lusophone countries.
all_recipients: Africa, regional, Angola, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, Timor-Leste

title: Aid to Interally Displaced Persons Camps
description: On August 25, 2003 in Kampala, the Chinese Ambassador to Uganda, Li Qiangmin, handed over relief aid worth 250,000 USD to the Minister of Disaster Preparedness and Refugees, Lt. Gen. Moses Ali. The donation, which included 840 pieces of tarpaulins, 7,000 pieces of blankets, 100,000 notebooks and 200,000 pens among others, was to go to Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in northern Uganda.

description: On November 9, 2002, Chinese ambassador Sun and the Nigerian Minister of Higher Education, Science and Technology represented their respective countries at the handover ceremony for Niamey University's classrooms and laboratories. Dalian Construction Co. was responsible for the construction project, valued at 3.5 million CNY.

title: Aid to boost north-south unity
description: On November 30, 2008 in Khartoum, Chinese Vice-Minister of Commerce, Gao Hucheng, and Sudanese Finance Minister, Awad al-Jaz, talked about an extension of a grant of 20 million CNY to Sudan for strengthening north-south unity. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.

title: Aid to fight Ebola virus
description: On January 18, 2001, China's Vice President, Hu Jintao, and Uganda's Vice President, Wandira Specioza Kazibwe, signed an agreement for China to give Uganda a grant of 80,000 USD to help fight against the Ebola virus. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.

title: Aid to fight cholera epidemic
description: In July of 2005, China donated $20,000 to support Guinea-Bissau in dealing with a cholera outbreak. The ambassador of China to Bissau, Tiang Guangfeng handed over the grant to health minister Maria Odete Semedo.A report in August of 2005, stated that China had given $100,000 to Guinea-Bissau to help fight the epidemic.
sources: http://www.health.am/ab/more/cholera_outbreak_kills_84_in_guinea_bissau/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.panapress.com/China-helps-Guinea-Bissau-fight-cholera-epidemic--13-570101-18-lang2-index.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020051010e1aa002bl&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Aid to repair tsunami damage
description: In 2005, China donated $50,000 USD to Seychelles to assist with the recovery from the tsunami and heavy rain. It is unclear how the funds were used.

title: Air transport agreement
description: On November 19, 2009, Sudanese Vice President Ali Uthman Taha and the visiting Member of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, Chu Yong Kang, signed an agreement on air transport between the Sudanese and Chinese Civil Aviation Corporations. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://www.sudanvisiondaily.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=51460, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article33188, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gov.cn/ldhd/2009-11/19/content_1468243.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Aircraft MA60 deal
description: On September 16, 2011, a trade agreement was negotiated and signed between AVIC International Society and the Minister of Transport, Public Works, and Infrastructure for Burundi. The agreement provided that China would donate a MA60 aircraft to the country's limited aircraft supply as long as they in turn would buy a second plane from AVIC. MA60 is a turboprop-powered airliner made by Xi'an Aircraft International Corporation. It is the only Chinese-made civil aircraft that has access to both domestic and international aviation markets. On June 18, 2012, a certificate of transfer was signed for the first MA60 plane to arrive which landed on June 29 of that year. This first plane was the gift from the Chinese government. The second plane was expected to arrive in the upcoming months. Training for the Burundian airplane technicians was also provided to ensure plane safety and maintenance in the future.
sources: http://www.burundi-gov.bi/Burundi-Transport-Ceremonies-de, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.wcarn.com/cache/news/19/19873.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Xi'an Aircraft International Corporation (XAIC), State-Owned Company
donor_agency: Xi'an Aircraft International Corporation (XAIC), State-Owned Company

title: Airport Terminal Construction
description: The finalized loan agreement for airport terminal construction was expected to be signed between China and Nigeria a few weeks after other loan agreements were signed on September 12, 2012 (for example, project IDs #1851, #30340). The project consists of four new airport terminals in Abuja, Kano, Port Harcourt, and Enugu and will cost a total of 500 million USD. China's Exim Bank will fund the project through a concessional loan. As planned, the new airport terminals will increase passenger capacity from 20 million to 50 million and will increase jobs from the current 60,000 to 1.5 million employees. The construction project had a projected completion date of sometime in 2015. All agreements signed on this day have loan terms with 2.5% interest, 7 year grace period and 20 year maturity. The project is being implemented by the Messrs China Civil Engineering and Construction Company (CCECC).
sources: http://www.fmf.gov.ng/the-media/press-release/84-abuja-light-rail-new-airport-terminals-to-be-completed-by-2015.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.fmf.gov.ng/the-media/press-release/85-update-on-loan-facility-for-abuja-light-rail-new-airport-terminals-and-galaxy-backbone.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.vanguardngr.com/2012/09/fg-secures-1-1bn-loan-from-china/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=APASENE020130312e93c000dy&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201307110351.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://leadership.ng/news/180513/jonathan-lay-foundation-airport-terminal, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.iwatchlive.org/activities/viewproject/485, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: An overpass project in Cotonou
description: (PPIAF) In 2008, the Chinese government provided a grant to construct an overpass in Cotonou with a total investment of 160 million Yuan. Construction commenced in August 2008, and the project ultimately cost $22.88984263 million USD. The overpass is 5km long. It is unclear if the project was completed. PPIAF-ID:41 Possibly connected to ID #43.
sources: http://news.cctv.com/china/20080827/102146.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gouv.bj/grands-chantiers/echangeurs-routiers, Other
implementing_agency: China Railway Construction Corporation (CRCC), State-Owned Company
donor_agency: China Railway Construction Corporation (CRCC), State-Owned Company

title: Angola Telecom Network Expansion Project, Phase 1
description: (PPIAF) In 2002, a 50-50 Chinese-French joint venture agreed to install a fibre link from the city of Lubango to the coastal city of Namibe. In addition, they agreed to deploy switching equipment, fibre-optic transmission infrastructure and synchronous digital hierarchy (SDH) multiplexers, as well as the deployment of one new satellite earth station and the reconstruction of four others. This project sought to expand optical fiber cable networks and access networks in four provinces in Angola (Namibe, Huila, Cunene and Lunda Norte), and was ultimately completed. It is unknown when the completion date is. The total project cost was $60 million USD, but it is unclear what the Chinese commitment was. China's Export-Import Bank funded the project, while Alcatel Shanghai Bell was the contractor. PPIAF-ID:3
sources: http://books.google.com/books?id=osgRwg1pWKoC&pg=PA240&lpg=PA240, Other; https://publications.worldbank.org/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=22946, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/topic/hwtz/2006/5_02.doc, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: Alcatel-Lucent Shanghai Bell Co., Ltd., State-Owned Company
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency; Alcatel-Lucent Shanghai Bell Co., Ltd., State-Owned Company

title: Annual Cultural Troop
description: The Chinese Embassy in Mauritius has been sending cultural troops and performers from the China Cultural Center to Mauritius on an annual basis. The financial value and commitment year for this project unknown.
sources: www.gov.mu/portal/goc/educationsite/file/sp27jan09.doc, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Annual Scholarships
description: The Chinese government awards scholarships to students from the DRC on an annual basis since 1985. Each scholarship is good for five years of study in China. From 2000 to 2008, over 82 scholarships were awarded to the Congolese. The financial amount for these projects is yet unknown. The scholarships per year are as follow: 1985-2003: 5-8;2004-2006: 11;2007: 23;2008: 32;
sources: http://www.ccs.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2010/03/ENGLISH-Evaluating-Chinas-FOCAC-commitments-to-Africa-2010.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

title: Anti-Corruption Bureau Building and Prison Building
description: The Chinese pledged funding for helping Mozambique develop and build an Anti-Corruption Bureau and new prison in Matola. The money was decided to be a concessional loan. Information regarding commitment year, implementation dates or completion, contact information, organizations, and amount of money contributed are yet to be determined.
sources: http://ruc-dk.academia.edu/JohannaJansson/Papers/1641675/Patterns_of_Chinese_investment_aid_and_trade_in_Mozambique, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://ruc-dk.academia.edu/JohannaJansson/Papers/1641675/Patterns_of_Chinese_investment_aid_and_trade_in_Mozambique, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: Anti-Malaria Drugs
description: In a decision made on June 23, 2006, Wen Jiabao announced a offer to provide anti-malaria medications worth 3 million CNY. The current status of this project is yet unknown, but the reports that since 2006, the Chinese government provides anti-malarial drugs on request from Tanzanian ministries.

title: Anti-Malaria Grant
description: On April 26, 2006, China and Nigeria signed an agreement for a CNY 5 million grant for anti-malaria drugs, training for Nigerians to control malaria and bird flu, and co-operation in technology. According to Nigeria's Minister of State for Petroleum Edmund Daukoru, this grant was decided upon to reciprocate Nigeria and China's formalization of four oil block contracts, which include the maintenance and management of the Kaduna refinery and setting up a power generation station.The status of this grant is uncertain.

title: Anti-malaria Drugs
description: On October 31, 2007, China signed an agreement in Kenya to provide $1.5 million in aid to Somalia. The agreement was signed by Somali President Abdullahi Yusuf and Chinese Ambassador in Kenya, Zhang Ming. It includes anti-malaria drugs worth $132,000.

title: Anti-malaria biological control (needs confirmation)
description: In 2002, the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology agreed to donate equipment worth 1 million USD to Kenya towards the production of a biological insecticide used to fight malaria. The equipment was brought into Kenya by late 2003. The start and end dates are unknown.
