recipient_agencies: Zambia National Broadcasting Corp. (ZNBC), State-Owned Company

title: China provides financial aid to CÃ´te d'Ivoire
description: The Chinese government provided a 100 million CNY loan to the Government of CÃ´te d'Ivoire in December of 2009. The money was free aid with an interest free exchange. The loan was given in order to help promote CÃ´te d'Ivoire in terms of building, economic development, and social gains. The Chinese ambassador gave a gift of 150,000 CNY to CÃ´te d'Ivoire for the purchase of office equipment for the Section Foreign Ministry after the ceremony was over. Organizations and exact dates are yet to be found.
sources: http://cd.qq.com/a/20091224/001550.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.yznews.com.cn/yznews08/yzgl/2009-12/24/content_3060038.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China provides grant
description: In July of 2001, China signed a pledge to provide gratis assistance of 20 million RMB yuan ($2.4 million USD) to Zambia to supplement the deficient construction expenses for some projects sponsored by China. Zambia's Deputy Finance Minister Godfrey Simasiku was present at the ceremony. It is unclear exactly how the funds were used, and the project appears to be untied. In addition, China also agreed to cancel $30 million USD worth of Zambia's debt.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=xnews00020010724dx7o003e9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China provides scholarship to 25 Zambian students per year
description: In 2007, China provide and sent-off d 25 Zambian students with scholarships to study abroad in China. The students will be studying medical science, IT, international trade management, business management, agriculture science, and and law.
sources: http://www.gov.cn/english/2007-08/22/content_724153.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020070821e38l0086i&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China sets up economic and trade zone
description: In 2007, Chinese President Hu Jintao announced that a special economic and trade zone would be set up in Zambia. The zone, to be built between now and 2010, would give companies tax breaks and other incentives. The zone was launched in 2007, and it is unclear when the project was completed. Thus far, the Zone has attracted 17 companies and a total investment of nearly $1 billion USD. STAFF_NOTES: It is unclear how the Chinese government was involved in establishment of this SEZ.
sources: http://www.postzambia.com/post-read_article.php?articleId=25601, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90776/90883/6805436.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CERPDB0020070206e32500008&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to Offer Scholarships to Ghanaians
description: In 2009, the Chinese Ambassador to Ghana Yu Wenzhe announced that the government of China will offer scholarships and training programmes to Ghanaians who want to study medicine in China. This study abroad program will help to reduce malaria and improve the living standards of Ghanaians. It appears that the project was implemented, and largely completed in October of 2009.
sources: http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/ce/cegh/chn/xnyfgk/t578055.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://allafrica.com/stories/200910300901.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to Provide Grant to Liberia for 'agreed upon' Projects
description: The original grant pledged close to 67,600,000 CNY towards construction of a new Ministry of Health and social welfare projects, including anti-malaria drugs. While the social welfare projects are not confirmed, the Ministry of Health has been completed as of January 2012 and is worth US$5 million. On July 11, 2009, Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping and the Liberian Vice President Joseph Boakai signed an unspecified economic and technological agreement document. STAFF_NOTE: Possible duplicate of #1713.
sources: http://finance.qq.com/a/20090711/000998.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201201271234.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/200907140535.html/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Fu Ziyang, ; Amara Konneh, ; Joseph Boakai, ; Xi Jinping, ; Dr. Walter T. Gwenigale, (Liberian Ministry of Health and Social Welfare)

title: China to Release Remaining $1,6bn Grant for Land Reform
description: On October 9, 2003, the Chinese government released the last funds of a US$2 million grant that it extended to the Zimbabwean government for its land reform program in 2002. The first portions of the grant were previously released, although at an unknown date, to help Zimbabwean farmers purchase agricultural equipment; the remaining funds will be used to acquire seeds, fertilizer, and farming mechanisms. The Chinese government was represented by its Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Zhang Xianyi. Additional research into the organizations involved in the funding and implementation of the loan, and status updates on the delivery of purchased goods was unsuccessful. It is noted that this grant was part of a US$8.3 million grant package offered to Zimbabwe over the 2002-2003 period, but the projects that were appropriated with the remaining US$6 million are unknown.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/200310090300.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Zhang Xianyi, Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe

title: China to Restock Zambia's Levy Mwanawasa Hospital
description: On December 29, 2011, China and Zambia signed a series of economic and technical agreements, one of which included an agreement for the provision of extra medical equipment and supplies to the Levy Mwanawasa general hospital worth K7.9 billion. It is unclear if the donations were made. Finance and National Planning Minister, Alexander Chikwanda and Chinese Ambassador to Zambia, Zhou Yuxiao signed these agreements in Lusaka. The other two agreements signed together are projects ID#15507 and ID#15518.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-276087684/zambia-china-signs-economic.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://china.aiddata.org/projects/1866, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://zm.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201201/20120107911975.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://allafrica.com/stories/201112300603.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Alexander Chikwanda, Finance and National Planning Minister in Zambia ; Zhou Yuxiao, Chinese Ambassador to Zambia

title: China to Resume Aid to War-Ravaged Liberia (amount needs confirmation)
description: China pledged US$10 million in aid to Liberia following the resumption of diplomatic ties in 2003. The money was to fund a water reservoir, vehicles, power generators and efforts to improve food production capacity in the country. Since the announcement in 2003, there has been no verification of the mentioned projects in the media. The two officials involved were Lu Guozeng, China's assistant minister for African affairs, and Gyude Bryant of Liberia.
sources: http://news.sina.com.cn/c/2003-11-11/13531098557s.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020031111dzbb001gu&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to Train Locals in Stadium Maintenance
description: In 2011, China offered to train Zambians in specialized fields to help maintain the newly constructed high-tech sports stadium in Ndola. It is said that a maintenance team from China would remain on the site for at least a year after the hand-over of the stadium to the Zambian government, and the Chinese team would train local personnel on maintaining the stadium before leaving the country. It is unclear if the project actually took place. This project is related to ID#25103.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020110822e78m000x2&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://jjhzj.mofcom.gov.cn/article/z/201203/20120308032903.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://allafrica.com/stories/201108080528.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to bankroll construction of government complex in Zimbabwe
description: On September 14, 2010, it was announced that the Chinese government had made a US$300 million pledge to the government of Zimbabwe to help fund the construction of a new government complex in Harare. However, the same media report indicated that this project had yet to proceed beyond the planning stages and that construction had not begun. The project is linked to, but separate from, ID# 21512.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020100914e69e0028n&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.guardian.co.uk/global-development/2011/dec/09/zimbabwe-government-overseas-business-contracts, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to build an elementary school in Zimbabwe
description: On October 26, 2010, the Chinese government announced plans to construct a primary school in Zimbabwe as part of a three-year infrastructure package that includes a number of other unrelated projects. The plan was signed into agreement in by the Chinese Deputy Minister of Commerce, Jiang Zengweni, in July 2010 and was announced by the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020101026e6aq0004p&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to complete a methane project in Zimbabwe
description: On October 26, 2010, the Chinese government announced plans for a 'methane project' in Zimbabwe as part of a three-year infrastructure package that includes a number of other unrelated projects under the auspices of a FOCAC commitment. The plan was signed into agreement in by the Chinese Deputy Minister of Commerce, Jiang Zengweni, in July 2010 and was announced by the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020101026e6aq0004p&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to construct a middle school in Zimbabwe
description: On October 26, 2010, the Chinese government announced plans to construct a middle school in Zimbabwe as part of a three-year infrastructure package that includes a number of other unrelated projects. The plan was signed into agreement in by the Chinese Deputy Minister of Commerce, Jiang Zengwei, in July 2010 and was announced by the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020101026e6aq0004p&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to construct a mini-hydro power station in Zimbabwe
description: On October 26, 2010, the Chinese government announced plans to construct a mini hydro-power station in Zimbabwe as part of a three-year infrastructure package that includes a number of other unrelated projects. The plan was signed into agreement in by the Chinese Deputy Minister of Commerce, Jiang Zengweni, in July 2010 and was announced by the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020101026e6aq0004p&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to fund Grace Mugabe Orphanage School
description: On November 4, 2011 President Robert Mugabe and his wife attended the groundbreaking ceremony for the Grace Mugabe Foundation's Orphanage school in Mazowe. China's Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Group is responsible for the building the complex at a cost of CNY 50 million.The school being built on a 7 720 square metre plot will include 27 classrooms, a library, an art room, music room, computer room and auxiliary equipment rooms.The institution will have four streams of 24 pupils per class from grade one to seven.The school will cater for 900 disadvantaged children from Grace Mugabe Children's Home and surrounding areas.The project, on completion, will include a children's home, hospital, a primary and secondary school, shopping complex and workers' quarters.The children's home, which currently has 38 completed houses, houses 15 abandoned children under the care of foster mother.The project is expected to take 16 months to complete
sources: http://www.afecc.com/en/display.asp?id=706, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.know-health.com/health-67111-China-aided-schools-foundation-orphans-in-Zimbabwe-Photos.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201111040186.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020111104e7b4000hb&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/200805120656.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Grace Mugabe Foundation; Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Group Co., Ltd. (AFECC), State-Owned Company
donor_agency: Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Group Co., Ltd. (AFECC), State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: Grace Mugabe Foundation
location_details: Grace Mugabe Foundation Primary School, Mazowe, Zimbabwe
contacts: Xin Shunkang, Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe ; Grace Mugabe, First Lady ; Xin Shunkang, Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe ; Ignatius Chombo, Minister of Local Government, Urban, and Rural Development ; Martin Dinha, Governor of Mashonaland Central Province; resident minister ; Robert Mugabe, President

title: China to help expand hydropower facilities at Batoka Gorge
description: On April 26, 2010, the governments of China and Zimbabwe reached an agreement to develop an electricity-generation hydro-power facility at Batoka Gorge on the Zambezi River in Zimbabwe. The project was originally on a list of 20 other infrastructure projects submitted by the government of Zimbabwe to the Export-Import Bank of China for funding. The Zimbabwean party that negotiated the agreement was led by the Minister of Finance, Tendai Biti, and the Minister of Transport and Communication, Nicholas Goche.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201004260116.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.hexun.com/2010-04-26/123539774.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA), State-Owned Company; Sinohydro Corporation, State-Owned Company
donor_agency: Sinohydro Corporation, State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA), State-Owned Company
contacts: Tendai Biti, Minister of Finance ; Nicholas Goche, Minister of Transport and Communications

title: China to lend Zimbabwe government $102 million
description: On March 21, 2011, the government of China signed an agreement to provide a US$102 million concessionary loan to the government of Zimbabwe that is to be facilitated by the Export-Import Bank of China. The loan is to be used on projects that are to be decided upon by the two governments in the future. The government of China was represented by Vice Prime Minister Wang Qishan, Vice Minister of Commerce Fu Zi-ying, and President of the Export-Import Bank of China Li Riougu; the government of Zimbabwe was represented by Minister of Finance Tendai Biti.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201103240713.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LBA0000020110321e73l000ob&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://cn.reuters.com/article/chinaNews/idCNCHINA-4007020110322, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://m.news24.com/fin24/Economy/Zimbabwe-China-sign-585m-in-deals-20110321, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
contacts: Wang Qishan, Chinese Vice Premier ; Fu Zi-ying, Vice Minister of Commerce ; Tendai Biti, Minister of Finance

title: China to offer grant to Zimbabwe mobile phone service provider
description: On January 21, 2010, the government of China signed a 50 million yuan (US$7.35 million) grant agreement with the government of Zimbabwe to go support state-owned telecom provider Net*One expand its network coverage and implement projects to be greed upon by the two governments in the future. The Chinese government was represented by its Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang. Additional research into project implementation updates was unsuccessful. It is noted that this agreement was signed at the same time as Project #20924, but the funding for the projects is separate.
sources: http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90776/90883/6875769.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: NetOne, State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: NetOne, State-Owned Company
contacts: Xin Shunkang, Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe

title: China to provide USD$2m-worth of agricultural equipment to Zimbabwe
description: On August 17, 2011, it was announced that the Chinese government would provide US$2 million-worth of agricultural machinery to the Zimbabwean government for distribution to farmers in need of irrigation and mechanization. The deal was announced by the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang. On September 21, 2011 Zimbabwe received the donation of farm equipment which included 10 trucks, 30 handy tractors and 50 water pumps.
sources: http://www.timeslive.co.za/africa/article1906549.ece, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201109220315.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Xin Shunkang, Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe

title: China to provide Zambia with fertilizer
description: In August of 2002, the Chinese government agreed to provide Zambia with 7,780 metric tons of fertilizer valued at 20 million RMB Yuan ( about 2.5 million US dollars). Present at the meeting were Foreign Minister Kalombo Mwansa and Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Peng Keyu. The hand-over ceremony occurred on September 16th, 2003. The project appears to be untied.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020030916dz9g001e4&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcapp0020020814dy8e0038q&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020030916dz9g001e4&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcapp0020020814dy8e0038q&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to provide drugs for Zimbabwe friendship hospital
description: On July 7, 2010, the Chinese government signed an agreement to provide US$1.5 million worth of medical equipment and drugs to the China-Zimbabwe Friendship Hospital in Mahusekwa, Mashonland East. The government of China was represented by Vice Minister Jiang Zengwei and the government of Zimbabwe was represented by Minister of Health and Child Welfare Henry Madzorera.It is noted that the very same hospital receiving the medial equipment and drugs was constructed from 2006 using Chinese funds under Project #20443.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201007080322.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://vlex.cn/vid/roundup-zimbabwe-strengthen-cooperation-212657761, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: China-Zimbabwe Friendship Hospital, Foundation
recipient_agencies: China-Zimbabwe Friendship Hospital, Foundation
contacts: Henry Madzorera, Minister of Health and Child Welfare ; Jiang Zengwei, Chinese Vice Minister

title: China to reschedule Zimababwean company's debt
description: On January 29, 2010, the Chinese government reached an agreement with Zimbabwean state-owned steel company Ziscosteel to reschedule the US$54.684 million in debt owed by the Zimbabwean steel producer ithrough 2013. Under the previous deal of US$5 million dollars per year, Ziscosteel was only able to provide around US$1 million prompting the debt rescheduling. Chinese insurance company Sinosure agreed to insure the debt agreement which is also being overseen by the Export-Import Bank of China. The Zimbabwean government was represented by Minister of Industry and International Trade, Welshman Nucbe, and the Chinese government was represented by the executive president of Sinosure, Zhang Weidong, and officials from the Export-Import Bank of China. Additional research into debt servicing updates was unsuccessful. STAFF_NOTES: Likely a second rescheduling of the same loan in ID #17125, so the amount has been removed.
sources: http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-01/29/c_13156246.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201001290023.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: Zimbabwe Iron and Steel Company (ZISCO), Public Private Partnership
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency; China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure), State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: Zimbabwe Iron and Steel Company (ZISCO), Public Private Partnership
contacts: Joice Mujuru, Vice President ; Welshman Ncube, Minister of Industry and International Trade ; Zhang Weidong, Executive Vice President

title: China to sell airplanes to Zimbabwe
description: On December 13, 2010, Chinese state-owned aircraft manufacturer Xi'an Aicraft announced that it had completed a deal to sell two of its MA-60 turboprop airplanes to the government of Zimbabwe. The aircraft will be financed using preferential loans provided by the Chinese government, even though the delivery dates of the aircraft would not be determined until financing negotiations were completed.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AVD0000020101227e6cd0000a&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Xi'an Aircraft International Corporation (XAIC), State-Owned Company; Air Zimbabwe, State-Owned Company
donor_agency: Xi'an Aircraft International Corporation (XAIC), State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: Air Zimbabwe, State-Owned Company

title: China to send a team of experts to study power plant
description: In 2011, China signed an agreement to dispatch a team of experts to Zambia to undertake a feasibility study on the rehabilitation and upgrading of the Musonda hydropower plant in Luapula and Chishimba hydropower plant in the Northern Province. It is unclear if the project commenced and how many individuals were involved. The other two agreements signed together are projects ID#2337 and ID#15507.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-276087684/zambia-china-signs-economic.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://zm.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201201/20120107911975.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://allafrica.com/stories/201112300603.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Alexander Chikwanda, Finance and National Planning Minister in Zambia ; Zhou Yuxiao, Chinese Ambassador to Zambia

title: China to send agricultural experts, medics to Ghana
description: In 2007, China announced that it will send senior agricultural experts, a medical team, and youth volunteers to Ghana to render various services. It is unclear when the team was dispatched, but they did arrive in Ghana.
sources: http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2011-06/10/content_12670911.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020071109e3b9001xh&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to send agricultural technical team to Zimbabwe
description: On October 26, 2010, the Chinese government announced plans to send an agricultural technical team to Zimbabwe as part of a three-year infrastructure package that includes a number of other unrelated projects. The plan was signed into agreement in by the Chinese Deputy Minister of Commerce, Jiang Zengweni, in July 2010 and was announced by the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020101026e6aq0004p&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China to supply Zimbabwe friendship hospital with equipment worth $10m
description: On October 26, 2010, the Chinese government announced plans to construct and donate US$10 million-worth of medical equipment to the China-Zimbabwe Friendship Hospital in Zimbabwe as part of a three-year infrastructure package that includes a number of other unrelated projects. The plan was signed into agreement in by the Chinese Deputy Minister of Commerce, Jiang Zengweni, in July 2010 and was announced by the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang.It is noted that the China-Zimbabwe Friendship Hospital, located in Mahusekwa, was constructed in Zimbabwe using Chinese funds during 2009 as part of an earlier, separate project. This donation is a supplement to that earlier project (#20443), but is separate from the original cost of the building
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020101026e6aq0004p&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: China-Zimbabwe Friendship Hospital, Foundation
recipient_agencies: China-Zimbabwe Friendship Hospital, Foundation

title: China to train Zimababwe cotton growers
description: On April 27, 2010, the Chinese government, alongside undisclosed Chinese companies, announced that it would begin a program to offer technical advice and assistance to local Zimbabwean cotton growers. Chinese technicians, over a 5 to 15 year period, will assist cotton growers in the management of crops in order to producer greater, more efficient, and better quality crop yields, with the eventual goal of Zimbabwe becoming a major supplier of cotton to China. The proposal was completed by the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang, representatives from the China National Textile and Apparel Council, and the Zimbabwe Minister of Agriculture, Mechanization, and Irrigation Development, Joseph Made.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201004270031.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: China National Textile and Apparel Council, Government Agency
donor_agency: China National Textile and Apparel Council, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Zimbabwe Ministry of Agriculture, Mechanization, and Irrigation Development, Government Agency

title: China writes of 40% debt
description: China in 2007 wrote off 40% of the debt Ivory Coast owed it, amounting to 18 million EUR. The deals were cut by Ivorian Foreign Affairs Minister Youssouf Bakayoko and Chinese officials. The project is untied. This was part of the deal in which the Chinese extended 10 million Euros in grants for Cote d'Ivoire (Project #13025).
sources: http://mg.co.za/article/2007-05-14-china-writes-off-40-of-cte-divoire-debt, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China writes off Ghanaian debt
description: In June of 2002, China agreed to write off 85 percent of the debt owed by Ghana, the equivalent of $53.5 million USD.
sources: http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=24887, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.wenweipo.com/2002/06/19/IN0206190066.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.sohu.com/21/21/news201622121.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.qianzhengdaiban.com/geguogaikuang/4215_6.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=lba0000020020617dy6h0129u&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China writes off debt
description: In 2005, following a visit to China, Equatorial Guinea's President Teodoro Obiang Nguema announced that he had invited China to become the country's main development partner. China had written off a large part of Equatorial Guinea's debt and as a result, Obiang offered China several opportunities in the natural resources sector. It is unclear how much the debt relief was worth.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=WDAN000020051031e1av0002f&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China, Ghana sign an interest-free loan for 5.86 million USD
description: In 2009, China agreed to provide Ghana with an interest-free loan worth $5.86 million USD over the next 10 years to enhance technical cooperation. The agreements were signed between Ghanaian Minister for Finance and Economic Planning Dr. Kwabena Duffuor and Chinese Ambassador to Ghana Mr. Yu Wenzhe. It is unclear how the funds were used. The agreement was signed in addition to a grant worth $8.79 million USD (ID 2002).
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020091231e5cv000un&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020091230e5cu002p9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020091231e5cv000un&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020091230e5cu002p9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China, Ghana sign grant of about 8.79 million US dollars
description: In 2009, China and Ghana signed an agreement for a grant worth $8.79 million USD (60 million Yuan). The agreement was signed between Ghanaian Minister for Finance and Economic Planning Dr. Kwabena Duffuor and Chinese Ambassador to Ghana Yu Wenzhe. It is unclear how the funds were used, but they do not appear to be tied.In another agreement at the same meeting, China will provide an interest-free loan worth approximately 5.86 million USD (40 million Yuan) in the next 10 years.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020091231e5cv000un&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020091230e5cu002p9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020091231e5cv000un&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020091230e5cu002p9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China, Mozambique sign medical cooperation agreements to grant malaria medicine to Mozambique
description: In September of 2010, China agreed to donate medicine for malaria patients in Mozambique. This agreement was reached at the same time as the 18th Chinese medical group was also decided on (Project #1232). Information on the amount of medicine provided, dates the medicine reached the country, and the completion status are yet unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020100921e69l0012y&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China, Zimbabwe sign MOU on rural development
description: On March 22, 2007, the government of Zimbabwe signed a memorandum of understanding with the government of China concerning construction, rural housing, and social amenities in rural underdeveloped portions of the country. The specific projects to be completed under the agreement were undisclosed. The MoU was signed by the Zimbabwe Minister of Rural Housing and Social Amenities, Emerson Mnangagwa, and the Chinese Assistant Minister of Construction, Liu Zhifeng.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020070322e33m008c4&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Zimbabwe Ministry of Rural Housing and Social Amenities, Government Agency; China Ministry of Costruction, Government Agency
donor_agency: China Ministry of Costruction, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Zimbabwe Ministry of Rural Housing and Social Amenities, Government Agency
contacts: Emerson Mnangagwa, Minister of Rural Housing and Social Amenities ; Liu Zhifeng, Assistant Minister of Construction

title: China- Africa friendship primary school
description: In April of 2010, the Chinese Minister of Commerce, Chen Deming, agreed with Mozambican Minister of Industry and Trade, Armando Inroga, that the Chinese would help create a China-Africa friendship primary school. They signed and exchanged notes at this meeting. Information on costs, organizations, and exact dates are yet unknown.
sources: http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/eng/wjb/zzjg/fzs/gjlb/3044/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ccs.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/CCS-Mozambique-Briefing-Paper-October-2009.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/eng/wjb/zzjg/fzs/gjlb/3044/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.cifor.org/publications/pdf_files/WPapers/WP93German.pdf, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy
contacts: Chen Deming, ; Armando Inroga, ; Armando Inroga,

title: China-Africa Development Fund regional office
description: In 2010, the China-Africa Development Fund (CADFUND) decided to establish a regional office in Zambia with an investment outlay of $1 billion USD. This regional office was launched on January 11, 2011.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=MENREP0020111215e7cf0001k&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://china.cnr.cn/gdgg/201101/t20110111_507572696.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
donor_agency: China-Africa Development Fund, Public Private Partnership

title: China-Aided Agricultural Technology Demonstration Center
description: In 2011, China completed the Agricultural Technology Demonstration Center, a facility worth $6 million USD. The center was built using Chinese funds and is located 15 km east of Lusaka. It is unclear what the commitment year is.
sources: http://www.guardian.co.uk/global-development/poverty-matters/2011/jun/30/china-zambia-relationship, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://zm2.mofcom.gov.cn/article/chinanews/201106/20110607608477.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: University of Zambia, Academic, Training and Research
donor_agency: Jilin Agricultural University of China, Academic, Training and Research
recipient_agencies: University of Zambia, Academic, Training and Research

title: China-Congo Friendship Hospital in Brazzaville
description: The Chinese government contributed more than 6 million USD for the construction China-Congo Friendship Hospital located in Brazzaville. The hospital boasts 95 in-patient beds and occupies 20,000 squared meters of land. The hospital was inaugurated in March 30, 2013 during President Xi Jinping's visit to the Republic of the Congo.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020130330e93u007sl&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BCHAFR0020130515e9510005o&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201304011183.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://en.starafrica.com/news/chinese-minister-pledges-funds-for-new-brazzaville-hospital.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.defence.pk/forums/general-images-multimedia/243205-china-congo-friendship-hospital-completed-video.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China-Liberia Malaria Prevention Centre
description: Starting from 30 January, Chinese President Hu Jintao began a tour around Africa, visiting Cameroon, Liberia, Sudan, Zambia, Namibia, South Africa, and Mozambique. The purpose of the tour is to follow up on the China-Africa Beijing summit in November last year. While in Monrovia, Hu talked with Liberian President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf. The two leaders witnessed the signing of seven documents on cooperation in economy, technology, health, education and agriculture, and also attended the inauguration of a malaria prevention and treatment center at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Sinkor, which was supported by China.

title: China-Sierra Leone Malaria Prevention and Treatment Center
description: A malaria prevention and treatment center held an opening ceremony in Freetown on October 30, 2009; the center is called the China-Sierra Leone Malaria Prevention and Treatment Center. This is part of a larger promise from President Hu Jintao in building 30 such centers in Africa made at the African Cooperation Forum Beijing Summit in November of 2006. Information on the amount of money China donated is yet unknown.

title: China-Uganda Friendship Agricultural Technological Demonstration Center
description: In 2006 the Chinese government announced plans for a China-Uganda Friendship Agricultural Technological Demonstration Center. The center trains local farmers in fish raising techniques, and includes a fish hatchery and feed factory. It is located on the outskirts of the capital Kampala. Contacts for this project include the manager of the center, Yi Ronggan.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201208300385.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201208300385.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.ifeng.com/world/news/detail_2011_02/25/4849776_0.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China-Zimbabwe cooperation agreement for financing an agriculture centre
description: On April 19, 2009 Zimbabwe and China signed an agreement to establish an Agricultural Technological Demonstration Center at Gwebi Agricultural College 27 km outside Harase. The 40 million yuan project will be one of eight such centers in Africa that China announced during the 2006 Sino-African Summit in Beijing. Economic and Commercial Counsellor at the Chinese Embassy in Harare Mr Hu Ming said the centre would employ 200 people and enroll 120 students. One source reported the value of this project at 30 million CNY instead of 40 million. On October 15, 2012 the Chinese government opened an Agricultural Technology Demonstration Center at Gwebi College of Agriculture.

title: China-Zimbabwe sign 144m agreement for rehabilitation of sewers
description: In 2010, China and Zimbabwe signed a Memorandum of Understanding for financing projects between the two. Officials from the Ministry of Finance, representatives from China's Eximbank and Sinosure signed the agreement. Sinosure was to provide insurance cover for loans for projects supported by the Eximbank. On March 21, 2011 Zimbabwean Vice President Joice Mujuru signed a $144 million USD loan agreement for the development and rehabilitation of water works and sewers in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare. Specifically the funds would rehabilitate, replace, install and commission equipment at Morton Jaffray and Prince Edward Water Treatment plants and Crowborough and Firle Sewage plants. The project would be implemented by China National Machinery and Equipment Corporation (CNMEC) and funded by the China Eximbank. Some reports also mention the involvement of China Development Bank leaders in negotiations, although the role of the CDB in the project is unclear. Contacts for this project include Chinese Vice Premier Wang Qishan who attended the loan's signing ceremony, Zimbabwean Finance Minister Tendai Biti, and Mr Li Riougu, the president of the Export-Import Bank of China. Later reports in December 2011 say that the Zimbabwean Cabinet had not yet approved the loan. Controversy arose as to whether the Chinese funding agencies had stipulated that the Zimbabwean local authority would have to pay an 8% interest of over USD $11 million in penalties due to delays in taking up the funds. Separate reports in 2012 and 2013 indicate the Harare City Council is yet to receive the funding, due to the government's failure to pay interest on a 1997 loan advanced to the then Zimbabwe Iron and Steel Industries. Other sources, such as town clerk Tendai Machachi, denied that the Chinese were making such demands. Further information regarding the updated status of this project is unknown. This project is linked to project ID#20980 for remaining funding spent on fertilizer supply. As of March 2012, the loan has yet to be received.

title: China-Zimbabwe sign 99.5m deal for medicine
description: On March 21, 2011, the Chinese government and the state-owned Export-Import Bank of China signed an agreement with the Zimbabwean government for a US$99.5 million loan for the procurement of medicine. The Zimbabwean government was represented by Vice President Joice Mujuru, and the Chinese government was represented by the President of the Export-Import Bank of China, Li Riougu. It is noted that although this agreement was signed as part of financing package totaling US$585 million in March 2011. The two other loans signed at the same time, Projects #22041 and #22055, will be implemented separately.

title: China-Zimbabwe sign agreement for drilling of boreholes
description: On October 26, 2010, the Chinese government announced plans for a borehole drilling project in Zimbabwe as part of a three-year infrastructure program in the country. The plan was announced by the Chinese Deputy Minister of Commerce, Jiang Zengweni, and the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Xin Shunkang. Subsequently, on March 24, 2011, the government of Zimbabwe formally signed an agreement with the government of China for the project: the drilling of boreholes for water wells in Zimbabwe. The agreement was signed by the Zimbabwe Acting Minister of Water Resources, Giles Mutsekwa, and the Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce, Fu Zi-ying.

description: On March 24, 2011, the government of China signed an agreement for the provision of a US$7.5 million grant to the government of Zimbabwe to be financed by the Export-Import Bank of China. The purpose of the grant money was not disclosed. The agreement was signed by the Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce, Fu Zi-ying, and the Zimbabwean Minister of Finance, Tendai Biti.

title: China-Zimbabwe sign deal for 342m agricultural machinery scheme
description: On March 21, 2011, the state-owned China Development Bank signed a US$342 loan agreement with the government of Zimbabwe for the provision of agricultural machinery to Zimbabwean farmers. The agreement was signed by the Finance Minister of Zimbabwe, Tendai Biti, and the president of the Export-Import Bank of China, Li Riougu; the signing ceremony was attended by Vice President Joice Mujuru and the Vice Premier of China, Wang Qishan.It is noted that although this agreement was signed as part of financing package totaling US$585 million in March 2011. The two other loans signed at the same time, Projects #22048 and #22055, will be implemented separately.

title: China-Zimbabwe sign loan for telecom infrastructure
description: On June 2, 2010, the government of China signed an agreement for the provision of a US$45 million concessionary loan to the government of Zimbabwe and its state-owned telecommunications provider NetOne to be facilitated by the Export-Import Bank of China. On March 2, 2011, NetOne formally signed the loan agreement with the Chinese government. The purpose of the loan is to modernize and expand NetOne's existing service network across Zimbabwe to reach 7,000,000 subscribers. On the Zimbabwean side of the deal, the funds from the loan are to be disbursed by Stanbic Bank of Zimbabwe while Chinese private telecom firm Huawei Technologies will be responsible for implementing the proposed network upgrades that include wireless broadband stations and coverage in remote geographic areas lacking current service. NetOne was given a five year grace period for the loan during which they are responsible only for interest payments and no principal payments until the end of the five-year term. Multiple media articles from 2012 reported that NetOne had succesfully launched mobile broadband and 3G service in Zimbabwe and had completed construction on a broadband switching center in Bulawayo using the US$45 million loan. The broadband center, officially the Broadband and Ascot Packet Core Switching Centre, was completed with equipment from Huawei on December 7, 2011 at a ceremony presided by President Robert Mugabe. Geographical areas of the country that received upgraded internet service included the Southern Region, Matabeleland Province, Midlands Province; these provinces were able to use the improved internet access to for e-health care, online education, and e-government programs.The Chinese government was represented by its Ambassador to China, Xin Shunkang, and the Zimbabwean government was represented by Finance Minister Tendai Biti and the managing director of state-owned NetOne, Reward Kangai.

title: Chinese Ambassador Donates to Amezu
description: On January 17, 2008 a Chinese envoy made a donation of 5KVA generator, 20 pieces of football and 4 pieces of portable typewriters to enhance the work and operations of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion University (AMEZU). The President of AMEZU praised Chinese Ambassador, Zhou Xiaou, for his worthy donation to the University.

title: Chinese Ambassador donates to Zimbabwe HIV/AIDS home
description: On July 22, 2009 Yuan Nansheng, the outgoing Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe donated $10,000 to Mashambanzou Care Trust, a foundation that helps people suffering from HIV/AIDS.'So far all the Chinese in Zimbabwe have already supported more than 1,200 orphans and President Robert Mugabe and Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai have paid high tribute to Care Action,' Yuan said.Mashambanzou Care Trust was established in 1989 and celebrates its 20th anniversary in October. It provides home-based care, education, orphan outreach and community work among the infected and affected.

title: Chinese Assistance Planned for Liberia's Healthcare System
description: In January of 2007 it was reported that China would help revive Liberia's healthcare sector. According to a report, China would construct 30 hospitals across Liberia and a malaria treatment centre. Financial details regarding the new hospitals were not revealed.The malaria treatment center may be here #1631.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=WDAN000020070131e31v0003f&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Contribution to UN Peacekeeping Mission in Liberia--ALL DEPLOYMENTS HERE
description: China joined the United Nations peacekeeping operations in Liberia in December 2003 by sending supplies transport, engineering and medical units, including civilian police, military observers and staff officers. There are nearly 600 Chinese peacekeepers serving with UNMI in Liberia. Most of the Chinese peacekeepers working in Liberia rotate at an 8-month interval. The Engineering and Medical units are based in Zwedru in UNMIL Sector 4, which covers the southeast region of Liberia. Troop deployments are as follows:-January 2004: initial deployment of 500 troops -December 22, 2004: 'second batch' of Chinese peacekeeping forces deployed to replace the first group-July 11, 2005: a group of peacekeepers return to China, having served six months-February 28, 2006: 'third batch' of Chinese peacekeeping forces deployed -December 2006: 'fifth batch' of Chinese peacekeeping forces deployed -August 30, 2007: the 'fifth batch' of Chinese peacekeeping forces returns home (275 officers and men in total)-August 2007: 'sixth batch' of Chinese peacekeeping forces deployed-April 20, 2008: the 'sixth batch' of Chinese peacekeeping forces returns home (240-member transport battalion; 275-member engineering battalion; 43-member medical team)-April 18, 2008: 'seventh batch' of Chinese peacekeeping forces deployed (558 members)-December 18, 2008: 'eighth batch' of Chinese peacekeeping forces deployed (558 members). More research needed on rest of deployments
sources: http://www.china.org.cn/china/military/2008-12/18/content_16974293.htm, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-04/20/content_8016694.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.chinamil.com.cn/site2/special-reports/2007-08/31/content_956599.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gov.cn/english/2006-03/02/content_215832.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2005-07/12/content_794006.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://lr.china-embassy.org/eng/sbgx/peke/t375763.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/3412317.stm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200412/23/eng20041223_168392.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://africatv1.com/Dawala/?p=2369, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.china.com.cn/chinese/2003/Nov/445059.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020031119dzbj000bb&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Cultural Center
description: On October 29, 2002, Chinese Minister of Culture, Mr. Sun Jiazheng formally inaugurated the Chinese Cultural Center in Cairo, Egypt. The Chinese Culture Center in Cairo is located in the Giza District in Big Cairo and covers an area of 2000 square meters. Inside the main building in the Center, with one floor underground and 5 floors above, there are the multi-function hall, the exhibition hall, classrooms, language lab, library, reception room and dining hall. The amount and commitment and start dates are unknown.
sources: http://eg.china-embassy.org/eng/zaigx/whjl/t76287.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/opinion/2010-07/09/content_10086268.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Donation for Interior Ministry
description: On March 2, 2005 the Mozambican Interior Ministry received a donation from China, valued at three million US dollars, intended to boost the capacity of the police force. The donation included 300 motorbikes, 500 helmets, bullet- proof jackets, and masks for the riot police, 100 large tents, with a capacity ranging from 36 to 100 people, 5,000 police uniforms, 6,000 torches for the traffic police, 25 computers, 15 fax machines, and even equipment for the police band. The donation results from an agreement on economic and technical cooperation signed between the two countries in Beijing in April 2004.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AFNWS00020050302e132001br&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Donation to National Transitional Legislative Assembly of Liberia
description: On March 16, 2005, The People's Republic of China (PRC) provided the Liberian Government with office equipment, including 50 typewriters and 250 rolls of ribbon (5 for each typewriter). Other donations include 80 radio sets and 300 raincoats. The donation to the National Transitional Legislative Assembly of Liberia took place at the Chinese Embassy in Congo Town. A certificate of donation and acceptance was signed by representatives of the Government of the People's Republic of China and the NTGL. Amb. Lin Songtian and Mr. He Meng, head of the Chancery, signed for the PRC, and Foreign Minister Thomas Yaya Nimely and Internal Affairs Minister H. Dan Morias signed for the NTGL.

title: Chinese Embassy Donates to Ghana women's national football team
description: In 2003, the Chinese Embassy in Accra donated 50 footballs to the national women's soccer team, the Black Queens. The donation is to help the team to prepare for the FIFA Women's World Cup scheduled for China later in 2003. The Chinese Ambassador to Ghana, Lu Yongshou, presented the donation. The Ghanaian Minister of Youth, Education, and Sports, Kwadwo Baah-Wiredu, received the donation on behalf of the team.
sources: http://www.modernghana.com/news2/34138/2/chinese-embassy-donates-to-black-queens.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Ghana Ministry of Youth, Education and Sports, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Ghana Ministry of Youth, Education and Sports, Government Agency

title: Chinese Embassy Donates to University of Ghana
description: In 2004, the Chinese Ambassador to Ghana Zhang Keyuan donated 5 computers, 5 printers, and 5 UPSs, totaling $6,500 USD to the Faculty of Science of the University of Ghana, Legon in Accra.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/200411220505.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/200411220505.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Chinese Embassy, Government Agency
implementing_agency: University of Ghana, Academic, Training and Research
donor_agency: Chinese Embassy, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: University of Ghana, Academic, Training and Research
location_details: Faculty of Science of the University of Ghana, Accra
contacts: Zhang Keyuan, ; Professor George Odamtten, ; Kwadwo Asenso Okyere,

title: Chinese Embassy donates sports equipment to Ghana
description: In 2011, China donated a variety of sports equipment to Ghana's Minister for Youth and Sports. The equipment included basketballs, footballs, volleyball posts and nets, table tennis tables and bats and badminton posts and nets.
sources: http://gh.china-embassy.org/eng/xwdt/t833218.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://vlex.cn/vid/chinese-embassy-donates-equipment-ghana-323515679, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Chinese Embassy to Ghana, Government Agency
donor_agency: Chinese Embassy to Ghana, Government Agency

title: Chinese Government Scholarships for 57 Liberian students (2011-2)
description: On August 17, 2011 at a farewell reception for Chinese Scholarship 2011/2012 Students Chinese Ambassador Zhao Jianhua disclosed that 57 people had benefited from the Chinese Government Scholarship for the Academic Year 2011/2012. Out of this number, 21 were for civilian students, while 36 were for military officers.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201108190667.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://lr.china-embassy.org/chn/sghdhzxxx/t849669.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://allafrica.com/stories/201108190667.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Government to Donate Medical Equipment to Kitwe Hospital
description: In 2005, the Chinese government agreed that it would donate medical equipment to Sinozam Friendship Hospital in Kitwe. It is unclear if the project was ever implemented.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/200505230923.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Governmental Scholarship
description: 21 Botswana students won the Chinese Governmental Scholarship for the 2011-2012 academic year. The scholarships were given to students pursing bachelor, master and doctorate degrees in a variety of academic fields.
sources: http://bw.china-embassy.org/eng/wjkj/t842907.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Chinese Governmental Scholarship 2010/2011
description: A report issued by the Chinese Embassy in Botswana in 2010 stated that 28 Botswana students had received the Chinese Governmental Scholarship for the 2010/2011 Academic Year to study in China.
sources: http://bw.china-embassy.org/eng/wjkj/scholarship/t720180.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNHA000020101119e6bj001qd&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Governmental Scholarship 2012/2013
description: 22 Botswana students won the Chinese Governmental Scholarship for the 2012-2013 academic year. The scholarships are given to students pursing bachelor, master or doctorate degrees in a variety of academic fields.
sources: http://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?sid=1&aid=241&dir=2012/January/Tuesday31, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://bw.china-embassy.org/eng/xwdt/t953441.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.dailynews.gov.bw/news-details.php?nid=1581, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Chinese Grant to Liberia for Undecided Use
description: In November of 2006, China and Liberia signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) allowing Chinese engineers to explore for offshore oil and possible mineral reserves. The MOU also outlined the development of a free trade zone at the Atlantic Ocean Port of Buchanan. Lastly, a grant of US$5 million was given to Liberia for uses 'yet to be decided.' Since the initial signing of the MOU there has been little media on these projects. In April of 2010, a domestic Chinese source referred to the free trade zone project at Port Buchanan as a 'serious consideration.'
sources: http://lr.china-embassy.org/eng/sghdhzxxx/t687521.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=DJI0000020061104e2b40000f&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Medical Team
description: In 2005, China and Botswana signed a protocol on sending medical teams. Under this protocol, the Chinese government agreed to send a team consisting of 41 medical staff and 5 support staff for three years. The financial value for this project and current status is unknown.
sources: http://www.focac.org/chn/zfyhj/t229450.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mmegi.bw/2005/November/Wednesday23/5721009251143.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Medical Team Arrives In Liberia
description: On July 28, 2005, a team of Chinese medical experts arrived in Liberia to help train medical doctors and physicians at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Sinkor. Need to find out how long the team stayed in country.
sources: http://mil.news.sina.com.cn/2005-08-01/0145309624.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sxgov.cn/xwzx/gnxw/193229_5.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://allafrica.com/stories/200508020433.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Nanjing District of People, Government Agency
donor_agency: Nanjing District of People, Government Agency
location_details: John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Sinkor

title: Chinese Medical Team Provides Health Service in Awgaro
description: In 2008, an eight-member Chinese medical team provided health services in Awgaro. The head of the Awgaro health center, Mr Girmai Measho, stated that the Chinese doctors gave efficient medical treatment to patients from different areas of Laelai-Gash sub-zone.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020081031e4au0000a&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Medical Team in Sudan
description: In June 2011, Sudan and China signed a deal on medical cooperation to send a Chinese medical mission to operate in Sudan for two years. According to the deal, 37 Chinese doctors will work in Sudan to exchange scientific and academic experiences and maintain the medical devices at the China-Sudan Friendship Hospital in Omdurman and Abu Ushar Hospital in Gezira State. The mission was also allowed to provide medical consultations and participate in the medical education.
sources: http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2012-01/05/c_122535690.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://vlex.cn/vid/roundup-sudan-china-anniversary-cooperation-343251498, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
contacts: Mahjoub Mohamed, Medical Director Abu Ushar Hospital

title: Chinese Parliament Donates To Mozambican Flood Victims.
description: On November 20, 2000, the Chinese Parliament donated $200,000 US dollars to the victims of a Mozambican flood that occurred in February of that year. Veronica Macamo, the deputy chairman of the Mozambican Assembly, presented the offer to the media that week.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=afnws00020021107dwbm01hjp&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese Provision of Boreholes in Accra
description: In 2004, China agreed to provide 350 hand-pump boreholes in six districts of the Greater Accra Region. It is unclear if the project was ever completed.
sources: http://ghanaweb.com/mobile/wap.small/news.article.php?ID=71860, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese bank acquires stake in Zimbabwean financial institution
description: On September 14, 2010, the China Development Bank (CDB) acquired a majority stake in the Infrastructure Bank of Zimbabwe (IDBZ); the Chinese bank will inject long-term capital, notably lines of credit, into IDBZ and subsequently into Zimbabwe's energy, transport, and infrastructure sectors. The deal was announced by the chief executive of the IDBZ, Charles Chikaura.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020100914e69e0028n&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://wap.yicai.com/news/2010/07/379366.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
implementing_agency: Infrastructural Development Bank of Zimbabwe (IDBZ)
donor_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Infrastructural Development Bank of Zimbabwe (IDBZ)

title: Chinese built primary school at Bindura
description: On April 19, 2007, it was announced that through the China-Africa Cooperation Forum, the Chinese government plans to construct two schools in rural areas of Zimbabwe alongside an agricultural demonstration center. On September 28, 2011 the Chinese Embassy handed over two primary schools to the Zimbabwean Government built at a cost of US$1.5 million as part of the bilateral cooperation between the two countries.The two schools, one in Bindura, Mashonaland Central Province and another in Warren Park, Harare, are part of the eight measures announced by Chinese President Hu Jintao at the Forum of China-African. The two schools were built by Chinese companies Gansu Hualong and Jiangsu Nantong.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/200805120656.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://ddi08.wikispaces.com/Country+PICs, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/200911090050.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Jiangsu Natong; Gansu Hualong Overseas Engineering Corporation
donor_agency: Jiangsu Natong; Gansu Hualong Overseas Engineering Corporation
contacts: Joice Mujuru, Vice President ; Xin Shunkang, Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe

title: Chinese company awarded contract financed by ExIm
description: On August 25, 2000, the Zimbabwean government, notably the Ministry of Rural Resources and Water Development, agreed to award a US$420 million construction tender, through the Export-Import Bank of China, to the Chinese company CMAC, to supply equipment to the District Development Fund (DDF) of Zimbabwe for the Msthabezi pipeline. The Zimbabwean government officials taking part in the agreement included the Minister of Rural Resources and Water Development, Ngoni Masoka; the Vice President of Zimbabwe, Joice Mujuru; the Senior Secretary for Finance, Charles Kuwaza; and the Minister of FInance, Mischeck Sibanda. Originally, the February 15, 2000 agreement was for equipment worth only US$366 million, but the value shot up to the government-approved level of US$420 million in the final tender. Additional research into start and finish dates for the delivery of the equipment to the Chinese company was unsuccessful. However, a 2012 media report from the Zimbabwean paper, the Financial Gazette, indicates that construction on the Msthabezi pipeline has yet to even begin in Zimbabwe, suggesting this project probably remains incomplete.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201203310111.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/200008250218.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=afnws00020021107dw6g019gx&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: China Merchants Americold Logistics Company, LTD, State-Owned Company
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency; China Merchants Americold Logistics Company, LTD, State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: Ministry of Rural Resources and Water Development, Government Agency
contacts: Misheck Sibanda, Minister of Finance ; Charles Kuwaza, Senior Secretary for Finance ; Obert Matshalaga, Treasury senior official ; Ngoni Masoka, Minister of Rural Resources and Water Development

title: Chinese company constructing football stadiums in Ghana
description: China agreed to help with the construction and renovation of football stadiums for the 2008 Africa Cup of Nations in Ghana. Two stadiums were built and two others underwent major renovations. [The commitment year is not 2010, but the values given for the construction are in 2010 dollar values]. The Sekondi Takoradi Stadium [capacity: 20,000 people, opened: 2008] and Tamale Stadium [capacity: 21,017 people] both cost 39 million USD to construct, while the Accra Sports Stadium [capacity: 40,000 people] cost 31 million USD to renovate and the Baba Yara Stadium [capacity: 40,500] cost 26 million USD to rehabilitate. The stadiums were funded through a soft loan from China, and Shanghai Construction Co. Ltd. built the stadiums.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020060905e294000va&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ghanasoccernet.com/accra-sports-stadium-regains-its-name/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://wikitravel.org/en/Sekondi-Takoradi, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.playthegame.org/fileadmin/documents/World_Stadium_Index_6_AfricaCup.pdf, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.china-flower.com/paper/papernewsinfo.asp?n_id=199554, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020060617e26h0018h&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

donor_agency: Shanghai Construction Group General Co., State-Owned Company

title: Chinese deliver items to Zimbabwe prior to election
description: Before the election in 2005, China sent gifts to Zimbabwe in terms of agricultural equipment and electrical transformers. The government also sent T-shirts exclaiming support for Mugabe's party. With the criticism of the Zimbabwean government, China's timely gifted showed a powerful international ally for the current regime. Information on amounts of money, dates the gifts were sent, contacts, and organizations involved are yet to be determined.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=FINP000020050711e17b0001u&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
recipient_agencies: Zimbabwe African National Union â€“ Patriotic Front (ZANU-PF), Political Party

title: Chinese design mansion for Mugabe
description: The Chinese got involved with the building and design of Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe's new mansion. The design was from a Chinese architecture company whereas the construction was controlled by a Serbian company. The 25- bedroom mansion was complete with a helipad, blue tiles flown in from Shanghai, and 44 acres of landscaped property. The entire project cost $13 million US dollars, but there is no information on how much the tiles and design cost separately. Information regarding dates, organizations involved, and contacts yet to be determined.
sources: http://www.newzimbabwe.com/pages/palace13.12328.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=NYTF000020050724e17o0002q&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0330/p01s01-woaf.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese dignitary donates technology to Zimbabwe Senate
description: On November 9, 2011, Zhou Tienong, the Vice Chairman of the Standing Committee of China's National People's Congress, visited Zimbabwe and donated 22 laptops, 20 printers, 10 scanners, and 5 television sets worth 1 million CNY to the Zimbabwean Senate.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020111121e7bl008ey&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020111109e7b9000ef&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Zimbabwe Senate, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Zimbabwe Senate, Government Agency
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020111121e7bl008ey&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020111109e7b9000ef&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Zhou Tienong, Vice Chairman ; Edna Madzongwe, Senate President (Zimbabwe Senate)

title: Chinese donation of Malaria treatment hospital and equipment
description: In 2009, The Chinese Ambassador to Ghana donated 55 pieces of medical equipment worth $447,000 USD, contributing to the Anti-Malaria Research Centre at the Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital in Accra. The equipment includes microscopes, ultra-violet flouresce, microwaves, clean benches, centrifuges, and water heaters. The donation took place at the sod-cutting ceremony for the establishment of the research center.
sources: http://www.ghana.gov.gh/index.php/news/general-news/190-china-assists-ghana-, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.scbid.com/zh/news/web_show_280022.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://allafrica.com/stories/200910300901.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
recipient_agencies: Ghana Ministry of Health, Government Agency
location_details: Anti-Malaria Research Centre, Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital, Accra, Ghana

title: Chinese donation to Ghana for the purchase of malaria drugs
description: In 2006, China agreed to donate about $25 million USD for the supply of anti-malaria drugs to Ghana. It is unclear if the funds were used and if the medicine was disbursed. The project is untied.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-147813393/ghana-china-sign-socio.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020060619e26j0038q&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Chinese donation to build a hospital
description: In June of 2002, China agreed to donate $8 million USD to the Dangbe East District constituency to build a hospital. The meeting was held between China's Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Wenchang and Ghana's Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs Alhaji Mustapha Ali Idris. The hospital is located in Ada, about 100 km east of Accra. It appears that the hospital was completed in 2003 and is now in operation, but it is unclear exactly when the project commenced. The project was untied.
sources: http://www.ghanahealthservice.org/region.php?dd=4&region=Greater%25252520Accra%25252520Region, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.china.org.cn/english/international/80304.htm, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=afnws00020020620dy6k000xd&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.china.org.cn/english/international/80304.htm, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: Chinese embassy presents desks and chairs to Zimbabwe College
description: In 2007, the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Yuan Nansheng, donated 100 desks and chairs, worth about 1.5 billion ZWL to the Danhiko Project. This donation will go toward providing a conducive learning environment for more than 600 students within the University of Zimbabwe's Danhiko Project, a program designed to provide education and training for students for students to whom other avenues of schooling and training are not readily available.At the time of the report, 1,500,000,000 ZWL = 5,878,870 USDhttp://www.oanda.com/currency/converter/
sources: http://www.kubatana.net/html/sectors/dan001.asp?sector=DISAB&details=Tel&orgcode=dan001, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://allafrica.com/stories/200707270046.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: University of Zimbabwe, Academic, Training and Research; Danhiko Project, Academic, Training and Research
recipient_agencies: University of Zimbabwe, Academic, Training and Research; Danhiko Project, Academic, Training and Research
contacts: Grace Mugabe, First Lady ; Yuan Nansheng, Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe

title: Chinese finance Investment Center in Zambia
description: In 2000, China committed to establish the Chinese Center for Investment Promotion and Trade in Lusaka. The facility is worth $2.4 million USD and will help screen investors from China in order for Zambia to receive genuine investors. The facility was opened in June of 2001. It is unclear exactly when construction began and what companies are affiliated with the construction.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/200106250051.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=xnews00020010818dw9d00mx2&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Zambia Investment Centre (ZIC), Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Zambia Investment Centre (ZIC), Government Agency

title: Chinese firm to build Kafue Gorge lower power plant (2010 commitment)
description: (PPIAF) In 2010, China agreed to assist with the construction of a 600 mW $1.5 billion USD power plant in Zambia. The project was to be implemented starting in April 2011. The project is known as the Kafue Gorge Lower power project in southern Zambia. A new joint-venture company to be formed by Zesco and China's Sinohydro Company and the China Africa Development Fund will borrow the initial funding of $1 billion USD from China Development Bank to start the project. The Zambian government will put up $250 million for the project, with a comparable sum from private equity. Sinohydro will be constructing the project; work began in July of 2011. The project will entail building new roads, homes, hospitals, and schools, and rehabilitating/expanding existing infrastructure. Minister of Energy and Water Development Kenneth Konga assured that the project would be carried out efficiently. In 2013 it was still in implementation. It is expected to reach completion by mid-2016. PPIAF-ID:316 STAFF_NOTES: This project is related to ID #2244, a 2006 pledge from the China EXIM bank to fund 510 million of Kafue Gorge. A March 2010 report also stated Zambia had 'secured' a concessional $1 billion loan for similar sectors (Project ID #2326).
sources: https://publications.worldbank.org/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=22946, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LBA0000020100813e68d00149&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pennenergy.com/articles/hydro/2011/01/zambia-raises-capacity.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.hydroworld.com/articles/2013/03/zambia-seeks-engineering--transaction-aid-for-750-mw-kafue-gorge.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.postzambia.com/post-read_article.php?articleId=13002, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AER0000020100311e63b0000w&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.postzambia.com/post-read_article.php?articleId=22169, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/world/2011-07/21/c_121697509.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=DJCS000020120511e85b00040&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.hydroworld.com/articles/2010/08/zambia--chinese-firms.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD)
donor_agency: Sinohydro Corporation, State-Owned Company; China-Africa Development Fund, Public Private Partnership
recipient_agencies: Zambia Electricity Supply Corp. (ZESCO), Public Private Partnership
