title: Donation of school materials to Pilar Buepoyo school
description: On April 21, 2011, the Chinese Ambassador Wang Shixiong presided over the delivery of school materials to the Pilar Buepoyo school. The ceremony was attended by the Director-General of Primary Education, Juan Asumu Engonga. The donation consisted of backpacks, notebooks, painting material, pencils, and other study materials.
sources: http://www.guineaecuatorialpress.com/noticia.php?id=1512, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/chn//pds/gjhdq/gj/fz/1206_7/1206x2/t817724.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Juan Asumu Engonga, Director-General of Primary Education ; Wang Shixiong, Ambassador to Equitorial Guinea (China)

title: Donation of school supplies and food to orphange-school
description: On November 8, 2012, the Chinese Embassy in Malabo donated school supplies and food to children in the Orphanage-School Nuestra SeÃ±ora de la Almudena of Malabo. Chinese Ambassador Wang Shixiong and the Counselor of the Presidency of the Ministry of Education and Science, Anselmo Ondo Esono, attended the ceremony.
sources: http://www.guineaecuatorialpress.com/noticia.php?id=3202, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://gq.chineseembassy.org/chn/xwdt/t987482.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Wang Shixiong, Ambassador to Equitorial Guinea (China); Anselmo Ondo Esono, Counselor of the Presidency of the Ministry of Education and Science

title: Donation of solar photovoltaic systems
description: In 2012, the Chinese Ambassador Yu Xuzhong presented the solar photovoltaic systems for public lighting infrastructure to the Minister of Energy and Mines of Burundi, Como Manirakiza. They were being installed by Huawei Technologies and should have been completed by November 1, 2012. The donation was made possible by a Chinese monetary grant given to the country. The ambassador said that the project cost about 8.5 million CNY. The Chinese had promised this type of assistance in the 4th Ministerial Conference on Sino-Africa Cooperation.
sources: http://www.burundi-gov.bi/Burundi-Chine-La-Chine-remet-au, Other; http://en.igihe.com/news/china-gives-us-1-3milion-to-improve-burundi.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd., Private Sector
donor_agency: Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd., Private Sector
contacts: Como Manirakiza, Minister (Ministry of Energy); Yu Xuzhong, Ambassador

title: Donation of sports equipment
description: On June 29, 2011, China donated sports equipment to Morocco within the framework of bilateral cooperation in the field of sports.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AGEMAP0020110703e76t00002&cat=a&ep=ASEL, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/chn//pds/gjhdq/gj/fz/1206_35/1206x2/t836150.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-260385080.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Donation of technical equipment to Cameroon's post office
description: In March 2010 China's National Committee of the People's Political Consultative Conference Jia Qinglin and Cameroonian President Paul Biya signed an agreement that provided for donation of technical equipment to Cameroon's post office. Another source states that the minister for posts and telecommunication, Jean Pierre Biyiti Bi Essam, signed the protocol agreement on the donation of new technological equipment to the Cameroon postal services. Searches did not reveal further information about the start and end dates of this project, implementing agencies or the specific equipment donated.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-222396243/china-gives-cameroon-over.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.voanews.com/content/china-opening-bus-assembly-plant-in-cameroon--89119202/114675.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
recipient_agencies: Cameroon Post Office, Government Agency
contacts: Paul Biya, ; Jean Pierre Biyiti Bi Essam,

title: Donation of television station equipment
description: On August 1, 2000, Chinese Ambassador to Uganda Zhang Xujiang handed over satellite station equipment to Ugandan Minister of Information Basoga Nsadhu. The equipment was donated to a Uganda television station by Xinhua News Agency to help the Ugandan station receive news and photos from Xinhua. The amount is unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=xnews00020010818dw8100hex&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Xinhua News Agency, Government Agency
donor_agency: Xinhua News Agency, Government Agency

title: Donation of vehicles and electronics to Foreign Ministry
description: In February 2012, China donated 2 buses, 5 vehicles, 30 computers, and 15 printers to Mali's Foreign Ministry. The donation was worth 240 million FCFA. Malian Foreign Minister Soumeylou Boubeye Maiga received the donation from Guo Xueli, the ambassador's stand-in at the Chinese embassy in Mali.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020120217e82h0025u&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Soumeylou Boubeye Maiga, Mali Minister of Foreign Affairs (Government of Mali); Guo Xueli, Charge d'affaires (China Ministry of Foreign Affairs)

title: Donation of vehicles for state guests
description: On November 16, 2011, Ethiopia and China signed an agreement on trade and economic cooperation at the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MoFED) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Jiang Yaoping, Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce, signed the agreement with Sufian Ahmed, Ethiopian Minister of Finance and Economic Development, and Wondirad Mandefro, Ethiopian State Minister of Agriculture.With the agreement, China will provide a loan of 100 million U. S. dollars and donate 90 vehicles, valued at 108.4 million birr, to Ethiopia, including 65 automobiles and 25 buses (20 city buses and 5 other buses). The agreement for the vehicles was signed by State Minister of Finance and Economic Development, Ahmed Shide, and Chinese Ambassador, Xie Xiaoyan. The handover ceremony was on February 17, 2012 at the Ethiopian Finanace and Economic Development Ministry.
sources: http://in.news.yahoo.com/china-donates-90-vehicles-ethiopia-155021035.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90883/7732887.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020111116e7bg009n9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020120217e82h0025t&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofed.gov.et/English/NewsandUpdates/Pages/EthiopiasignsLoanandDonationAgreementswithChina.aspx, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mfa.gov.et/news/more.php?newsid=47, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020111116e7bg009n9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020120217e82h0025t&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Wondirad Mandefro, ; Sufyan Ahamad, ; Xie Xiaoyan, Ambassador (China); Ahmed Shide, Minister (Ministry of Finance)

title: Donation of vehicles to health ministry
description: On April 23, 2012, China donated six vehicles (two ambulances, two minibuses, and two small-sized cars) worth an estimated 200,000 USD to Burundi. The vehicles were given by the Chinese government to the Burundian public health and AIDS control ministry.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020120424e84o0036e&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.eastday.com/e/120424/u1a6511509.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Sabine Ntakarutimana, Public Health and AIDS Control Minister ; Yu Xuzhong , Ambassador to Burundi (China)

title: Donation of vehicles to the Mininstry of Foreign Affairs
description: On June 24, 2011, Equatorial Guinea signed the delivery receipt for ten vehicles donated by the Embassy of China to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Cooperation International Francophone Affairs. The ceremony was attend by Ambassador of China in Equatorial Guinea, Wang Shixiong, and the Secretary of State in Equatorial Guinea Nchama Nsue. The vehicles were used for a summit as well as other various needs of the Ministry.
sources: http://www.guineaecuatorialpress.com/noticia.php?id=1706, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_chn/gjhdq_603914/gj_603916/fz_605026/1206_605220/1206x2_605240/t833766.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Wang Shixiong, Ambassador to Equitorial Guinea (China); Victoriana Nchama Nsue Okom, Secretary of State for International Cooperation

title: Donation of water supply equipment
description: On November 14, 2008, the Comoros president thanked the Chinese government for the donation of 60 containers of water supply equipment. The equipment is supposed to be used to rehabilitate the water network in Moroni. Generators were expected to follow this donation as another facet from an energy program funded by the Chinese government.
sources: http://www.beit-salam.km/article.php3?id_article=475&var_recherche=chine, Other; http://www1.genertec.com.cn/413-1043-2114.aspx, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: Donation to Gisozi Memorial Site
description: On August 29, 2006, Wu Guanzheng, a member of the standing committee of the political bureau of the Chinese Communist Party, donated 5,000 USD to the Gisozi Memorial Site in Rwanda on behalf of the Government of China.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020060829e28t00335&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

recipient_agencies: Gisozi Memorial Site, State-Owned Company

title: Donation to Kenyan Red Cross Society
description: In 2008, the Chinese government provided $300,000 USD to the Kenyan Red Cross Society for emergency humanitarian assistance. There are no further details regarding the status of the funds.
sources: http://news.sina.com.cn/w/2008-01-19/085213288648s.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Kenya Red Cross Society, National NGO
recipient_agencies: Kenya Red Cross Society, National NGO

title: Donation to Liberian Ministry of Information, Culture, and Tourism
description: On Wednesday April 17, 2013, the Chinese Ambassador to Liberia, Zhao Jianhua, handed over several donated items from the Chinese Government to the Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism for use by the department of culture at the Ministry.The handing over ceremony took place at the Chinese Embassy in Congo Town, outside Monrovia. The items donated included: four desktop computers, seven lap top computers, 36 Universal Power Supply, 32 storage batteries, one digital duplicator machine, and one HP Laser Jet Printer. Speaking during the handover ceremony, Ambassador Jianhua said the value of the donation is put at 31,1881 USD.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020130418e94i001fc&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201304181043.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
recipient_agencies: Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism (MICAT)
contacts: Zhao Jianhua, Chinese Ambassador to Liberia (China Ministry of Foreign Affairs); Lewis Brown, Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism (Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism (MICAT))

title: Donation to Ministry of Foreign Affairs
description: On March 7, 2008, the Chinese government donated 13 vehicles and office appliances to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Charge d'affaires of China, Zhang Yangwu, handed over the vehicles and appliances to director general of Middle East Asia and Oceania with the ministry, Ambassador Mahdi Ahmad Gadid. The donation included 7 automobiles, 4 minibuses, 2 pickups, 2 motorbikes, 47 personal computers (PCs), 40 printers, and one PABX machine.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020080307e43700209&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
recipient_agencies: Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Government Agency

title: Donation to Ministry of Women and Child Development
description: On January 7, 2009, Chinese Ambassador Lin Songtian donated 10 computers and 55 sewing machines to the Malawian Ministry of Women and Child Development on behalf of the Embassy. The financial amount for this donation is unknown.
sources: http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/chn/pds/wjdt/zwbd/t530827.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LQAF000020090109e5190008f&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
recipient_agencies: Ministry of Women and Child Development, Government Agency

title: Donation to Organisation for the Empowerment of Widows/Widowers and Orphans of HIV/AIDS
description: In 2006, the Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry donated 400 blankets to the Organisation for the Empowerment of Widows/Widowers and Orphans of HIV/AIDS in Namibia (OEWONA). It is unclear what the financial value of the project is.

title: Donation to Zayedesa
description: On June 22, 2010, Madam He Xiaobing, wife of the Chinese Ambassador, met with the first lady of Tanzania, Madam Shady Karume, and made a donation to Zayedesa Center for Youth Education, Employment, and Development on behalf of the Chinese embassy. The financial amount for this project, as well as the exact projects financed with the amount are unknown.

title: Donation to government
description: In 2010, China agreed to provide Seychelles with a grant of 40 million CNY to help carry out projects to be agreed upon by both parties under an economic and technical cooperation agreement. The funds are supplementary to the China-Africa cooperation program. According to the first source, the grant agreement was signed.

title: Donation to primary school
description: On June 1, 2011, the Chinese Embassy in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia made a donation of desks, chairs, radios, computers, TV sets, projector, and soccer-balls to Tenbite-Ermias Primary School. The donation was worth 100,000 Birr. Wei Hongtian, Charge d'Affairs of the Chinese Embassy, handed over the donation. Speaking on the same occasion, Yilma Dessie, director of Tinbite-Ermias School, commended the Chinese side for the donation made to his school.

title: Donation to the Uganda Olympic Committee
description: On December 19, 2003, the Chinese government, through the Beijing Olympic Games Organizers donated 10,000 USD worth of sports equipment to local federations to help them prepare for next year's Summer Olympics in Athens. Chinese ambassador Li Qiangmin handed over the donation that included 96 basketballs, 96 volleyballs, 96 footballs, 100 tunes of badminton shuttles and 50 rackets to Uganda Olympic Committee President Francis Nyangweso.

title: Donation to train nurses and midwives (Multilateral)
description: A $500,000 dollar donation to train neo-natal nurses and midwives was handed from Chinese Ambassador to South Africa Liu Guijin to the Chief Executive of the New Partnership for Africa's Development (NEPAD), Firmino Muscavele on July 26, 2006, following Wen Jiabao's agreement for support in June of the same year. NEPAD is a strategic framework created by the African Union. The training was planned to take place at universities and other educational institutions around the Tanzania and Kenya area. The current status of this project cannot be determined.

title: Donation to transportation network
description: In 2011, China gave Ethiopia four buses, whose manufacturing would be emulated locally as part of the government's plan to deploy 500 new buses in Addis Ababa.

title: Donations of contraceptives for family planning program
description: On July 26, 2012, China donated 5,000 doses of contraceptives to Kenya worth about 4 million Kenyan shillings. The Kenyan Minister for Planning Wycliffe Oparanya received the donation, which was said to be in line with a Chinese government commitment made in February 2012.

title: Donations to Mzuzu University
description: On April 5, 2011, the Chinese embassy in Malawi held donation ceremony for the handing over of 2 million MWK to the construction of a new Department of Land Management at Mzuzu University. The donation was handed from Pan Hejun, the Chinese ambassador, to Malawi's Education Minister Peter Mutharika. The fact that the program is taking students now is used for grounds that this project has been completed. The exact dates are unknown. At time of writing, 2 million MWK equaled 13,072.70 USD.
sources: http://www.mzuni.ac.mw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=59&Itemid=64, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://mw.china-embassy.org/chn/sghdhzxxx/t771092.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/chn/gxh/tyb/zwbd/t812686.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Drinking water improvement project
description: In November 2011, China and Niger signed a cooperation agreement to improve the drinking water supply in the city of Zinder. On March 31, 2013, President Mahamadou Issoufou presided over the official launch of the project in Iyaka in the municipality of Oualelewa. The project includes the construction of production facilities in the North Ganaram wellfield, about 64km north of Zinder with new discharge pipes, new wells drilled, and 40 new water fountains. The work includes constructing and equipping 18 drilling sites of 25 cubic meters per hour, placing several discharge pipes between the well field and return stations, improving access to potable water, and constructing 2,000 public access water points and 40 hydrants. The current production of the facility is 12.5 cubic meters an hour, but the new project will increase the supply to 27.5 cubic meters an hour by 2015, the expected end date. The China Exim Bank is funding the 20.5 billion CFA francs for the project, and the China Geo-Engineering Corporation will be executing the work. This project is a continuation of the Zinder Water Supply project, started in 2002 (project ID #83).
sources: http://www.presidence.ne/index.php/316-le-president-de-la-republique-a-preside-dimanche-a-zinder-le-lancement-des-travaux-de-renforcement-des-installations-de-production-d-eau-potable-de-cette-ville, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: China Geo-Engineering Corporation (CGC), State-Owned Company
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
location_details: North Ganaram Wellfield, Zinder, Zinder Commune

title: Drought emergency food aid
description: In August 2011, the Chinese Ministry of Commerce announced that it would start shipments of food aid to northeast African countries at the end of the month. The food aid sent to Ethiopia is worth 150 million yuan (about $24 million) and includes food such as rice, wheat, flour, and edible oil from China's market. The first shipment of food was shipped in early September and arrived in October on the 22nd; this shipment was the first of two batches of emergency food assistance to Ethiopia, totaling 20,000 tons. Wei Hongtian, Charge d'Affairs at the Chinese Embassy in Ethiopia, handed over the assistance certificate to Wondirad Mandefro, Ethiopian State Minister of Agriculture, at a ceremony in the Office of Ethiopian Disaster Risk Management Food Security Sector (DRMFSS) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The handover was witnessed by Ahmed Shide, Ethiopian State Minister of Finance and Economic Development, and Qian Zhaogang, Economic Counselor at the Chinese Embassy in Ethiopia, and other officials. The first batch contained 8,139.4 tons of wheat and 715.15 tons of rice. The second batch of emergency food assistance pledged by China is expected to come in November and December. The status of the second delivery is uncertain.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=CHNDHK0020110804e7850001j&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020111022e7am008y9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.pravda.ru/hotspots/disasters/24-10-2011/119423-Ethiopia_food_aid_from_China-0/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.guardian.co.uk/global-development/poverty-matters/2011/aug/01/drought-food-crisis-africa-data, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=CHNDHK0020110821e78k00008&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2011-08/16/content_13118872.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.cpcchina.org/news/2011-10/14/content_13899403_2.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
recipient_agencies: Ethiopian Disaster Risk Management Food Security Sector, Government Agency

title: Drugs and medical equipment
description: On July 6, 2004 the Chinese ambassador to Togo, Zhang Shixian donated drugs and medical equipment worth about 35m CFA Francs to the Togolese Minister of Health, Madam Suzanne Aho Assouma. The donation was made at the office of the Economic and Commercial Council at the embassy and is meant for regional hospitals in Lome.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020040707e077002bd&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Dutlwe-Morwamosu Road [Same as Letlhakeng-Kang Phase 2]
description: Botswana's Public Procurement Asset Disposal Board approved the tender titled 'Construction of Letlhakeng-Kang Road Section II from Dutlwe to Morwamosu Request to negotiate with the contract, China State Construction Engineering Corporation' on October 06, 2004. The loan agreement with the Chinese government was revised to give 160 million CNY at 3% fixed interest to mature in 2021 (15 years from when agreement was signed in 2006). As of 2010, only 129,220,330 CNY was received by Botswana. China Construction Botswana Ltd completed the construction of the Dutlwe-Morwamosu road project. The opening ceremony was held in Boonen, a District Dutlwe. The project consists of 95.74 km of the main road (9.7 meters wide), 7.07 kilometers of roads (7.0 meters wide), 31 km of connecting roads and 119 culverts. The exact date of completion is not reported, but the article was published on December 7, 2010. This section of road was Phase 2 of the Letlhakeng-Kang road project(PPIAF) Dutlwe - Morwamosu Road Project is situated in the western part of Botswana and passes through Kweneng, Southern and Kgalagadi Districts. The area's main economic activity is subsistence agriculture, comprising principally the raising of cattle; Political/Resource Considerations: Political; Chinese Commitment: USD 16.7 Million; PPIAF-ID:47(PPIAF) Letlhakeng-Kang (Phase 2) road project.; Political/Resource Considerations: Political; Total Project Cost: USD 40 Million; Chinese Commitment: USD 18.6 Million; PPIAF-ID:46

title: E-government project
description: In 2006, the Chinese government disbursed $9 million USD to Guinea as part of an e-government program to disseminate new information and communication technology among the Guinean administration. Chinese state-owned Huawei Technologies was chosen to carry out the project. The signing of this major agreement took place at the Ministry of International Cooperation between the Chinese ambassador to Guinea and the minister of international cooperation, Mrs Sidibe Fatoumata Kaba. The current status of this project is unclear, but it does not appear to be tied.
sources: http://www.verite.press-guinee.com/Single-News.408.0.html?&cHash=b83d56bfdb&tx_ttnews%2525255BbackPid%2525255D=406&tx_ttnews%2525255Bpointer%2525255D=203&tx_ttnews%2525255Btt_news%2525255D=3330, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020061229e2ct001e1&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

donor_agency: Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd., Private Sector

title: E-government projects
description: In November 2006 Kenyan trade and industry minister Mukhisa Kituyi signed a technical agreement with the Chinese government for the support of Kenya's e-government project. The agreement appears to cover $42 million USD, and at least partially funds the Kenyan Government Unified Messaging System (GUMS) project. The GUMs project aims to address disparities in technology that lead to less efficient electronic communication among Kenyan government officials. The Kenyan State webpage describes GUMs as 'a joint effort of the Kenya and Chinese governments.' It elaborates that the project is funded through a concessional loan from the China Exim Bank, and implemented by a contract with ZTE Corporation and the Kenyan Directorate of e-government. Very little information is available about this project, although it does appear to have been completed. The lack of information possibly stems from the fact that the project partially involved ZTE corporation building a secure network for Kenyan e-Government activities, and may entail military intelligence activity.
sources: http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/investment-with-strings-attached-cables-reveal-resentment-at-chinese-influence-in-africa-a-733870-2.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.e-government.go.ke/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=104:government-unified-messaging-system-gums&catid=43:projects&Itemid=91, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020061107e2b7000f3&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

donor_agency: Zhongxing Technologies (ZTE), State-Owned Company; Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Kenyan Directorate of e-government, Government Agency

title: E5.7m for Public Works Projects
description: On December 8th, 2008, China granted Equatorial Guinea 5.7 million Euros to be used for public works projects, including some projects in the Gulf of Guinea. Chinese Vice Minister for Foreign Trade, Chao Wu-Chen, signed the agreement with the African country during an official visit.

title: Earthquake Relief
description: In February 2004, 12 Chinese medical team members began their rescue operations immediately after the earthquake and treated hundres of injured people.

title: East-West Corridor, Ring Road, Bus Way, and Harbour Bridge
description: On April 08, 2009 Zhao Jianping representing the China-Africa Development Fund and Rama Sithanen representing Mauritius signed an agreement at a joint working session for a 25 billion MUR loan for the development of roads and bridges. Specifically, this loan would fund the East-West Corridor, the ring road at Port Louis, a bus way, and the Harbour bridge. In 2011, the government of Mauritius reported that this project was currently underway, and is expected to be completed by 2015.

title: Econ/technical Coop Agreement
description: On September 5, 2005, Wu Bangguo, chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, and Moroccan Prime Minister Driss Jettou signed an agreement on economic and technical cooperation.The status of the agreement is uncertain.

title: Economic Agreement signed in conjunction with debt relief and loan agreements
description: In 2007, following the normalization of diplomatic relations between the People's Republic of China and Chad in August 2006, Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing signed a series of loan (#16265), debt-relief (#16248), and economic agreements worth $80 million. STAFF_NOTES:The financial value for this project was removed since the loan and debt-relief measures themselves total nearly $80 million.

title: Economic Aid
description: On August 7, 2003 Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao announced during talks with Niger Prime Minister Hama Amadou that China would provide Niger with 50 million yuan (about 6 million USD) in economic aid. After the talks, the two leaders witnessed the signing of an agreement on economic and technological cooperation between the two countries. The flow type and further status updates about the project and its implementation are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcapp0020030807dz8700a6q&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic Aid for anti-malarials, agricultural centers, schools, and training
description: In 2006, presumably as part of a FOCAC commitment, China decided to grant the Republic of the Congo an aid of 30 million yuan, donated anti-malaria drugs, aided agricultural demonstration centers and rural schools, providing professional and technical personnel training. Regarding the agricultural demonstration centers, sometime before 2011, at least one center of 59 hectares near Brazzaville had been completed and several experts have been trained. There may be plans for additional demonstration centers.
sources: http://www.finance-ol.com/2011/09/congo-brazzaville-praised-the-minister-of-agriculture-china-agricultural-technical-assistance/, Other; http://cg.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200606/20060602501299.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Economic Assistance
description: On November 21, 2010 China and Botswana signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement. Under the Agreement China is to provide assistance worth 40 million RMB to the Botswana.
sources: http://vlex.cn/vid/roundup-vice-president-trip-achieves-goals-230786199, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-11/21/c_13615942.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic Cooperation Agreement
description: In March of 2001, the Central African Republic and China signed an economic cooperation agreement worth 10m yuan around one billion CFA francs. The Chinese ambassador to Bangui signed the document on behalf of his country. He said China and the Central African Republic were committed to development and had similar objectives and tasks in the attainment of peace and development. It is unclear if and how the funds were used. The project was untied.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcap00020020326dy3q003ju&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic Counsellor's Office
description: China Jiangsu Construction Development Company was the contractor on the construction of the DRCongolese Economic Counsellor's Office in Kinshasa on behalf of the Chinese government. The project was in implementation as of January 2010, and was finished sometime before March 2011. The commitment year, start date, end date, and financial amount are still unknown for this project.
sources: http://www.africa-asia-confidential.com/article/id/543/All_roads_lead_to_Beijing, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ccs.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2010/03/ENGLISH-Evaluating-Chinas-FOCAC-commitments-to-Africa-2010.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

donor_agency: China Jiangsu International, State-Owned Company

title: Economic Grant
description: On June 30, 2003, the Burundi external relations and cooperation minister, Mr Terence Sinunguruza, and the Chinese ambassador to Burundi, Mr Feng Zhijun signed a 30 million CNY aid agreement. The grant will be given free of charge, and will be used to accomplish projects to be decided by both parties. Specifically, the aid is meant to 'contribute to Burundi's economic recovery.' The projects to be financed with this grant cannot be found.
sources: http://www.cnnz.gov.cn/bbxq_content/2011-02/17/content_1187064.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcap00020030703dz73006y3&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and Technical Accord
description: On December 4, 2007 the People's Republic of China and the Union of Comoros signed an economic and technical accord on 4 December. The aid amounts to 25m yuan [3.3m dollars]. The action is aimed at 'further developing friendship and economic cooperation relations between the two countries'. The Comoran side was represented by Justice Minister and Keeper of the Seals Mourad Said Ibrahim, while China was represented by its ambassador Tao Weiguang. The administrative document signed between the two parties did not specify the kind of projects which will be financed by the aid package. The aid package is a result of talks between President Sambi and his Chinese colleague.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020071218e3ci002bd&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and Technical Agreement
description: On August 26, 2002 an official Chinese delegation led by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji signed an economic and technical agreement with Algeria that regulates a USD 6mn loan with 25 years maturity from China. The implementing agency, details of the project and dates are unknown. The delegation and Algeria signed four cooperation agreements in the fields of economy, finance and culture. Other agreements provide for the construction of a newmosaics unit in Guelma #324 and for the dispatch of a Chinese medical team to Algeria #21879 .
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=menat00020020827dy8r000b5&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and Technical Cooperation
description: In 2010, China agreed to provide Tanzania with a grant of $7.1 million USD for economic and technical cooperation. An additional grant of $2.9 million USD was provided to Zanzibar, a semi-autonomous area within Tanzania. The funds from both grants will be used to fulfill the funding gap of projects to be agreed upon by the two governments.

title: Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement
description: In June of 2003, Chinese President Hu Jintao had talks with Comoros President Azali Assoumani at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing. After the talks, the two heads signed the 'Agreement of the Government of the People's Republic of China and the Government of the Union of Comoros on Economic and Technical Cooperation.'

title: Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement
description: On September 27, 2011 Liberia and China signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation agreement under which China is to provide â€œa gratuitous assistanceâ€ of approximately US$16 million to Liberia. Acting Foreign Minister Sylvester M. Grigsby signed on behalf of Liberia while Li Zhigong, Charge d' Affairs of the Chinese Embassy, signed for his government.

title: Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement
description: On Aprill 17, 2007 Jia Qinglin, Chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, met Tunisian Prime Minister Mohamed Ghannouchi in Tunis. After the meeting, Jia Qinglin and Mohamed Ghannouchi jointly attended the signing ceremony of five bilateral cooperation documents, including a China-Tunisia economic and technological cooperation agreement. More specific information on the agreement could not be found.
sources: http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-04/18/content_5990634.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020070418e34i001ur&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement
description: In June of 2001, President Tandja and PM Hama Amadou attended talks in Beijing, after which the two leaders signed an economic and technical cooperation agreement. A financial value as well as projects that may be encompassed under this agreement cannot be determined.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=xnews00020010715dx65013so&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement
description: On April 20, the Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce, Fu Ziying, met with Egypt and signed an agreement to provide the country with 60 million CNY in grant aid. The agreement is an economic and technical cooperation agreement that will help Egypt provide cash to evacuate Libya personnel, take out government loans, and enhance human resources. Along with this deal, China also agreed to provide training programs for government staff in Egypt. There are unofficial considerations in that China is expected to buy more goods from Egypt and send more tourists to the country. Information on the exact date money was transferred is yet unknown.
sources: http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2011-04/21/content_12370217.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.sohu.com/20110421/n306215962.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement and Office Supplies
description: In March of 2011, the Chinese Ambassador Kuang Weilin and Sierra Leonean Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation Mr. J. B. Dauda signed a China-Sierra Leone Economic and Technical Agreement and a Certificate of Handing over Office Supplies. The supplies are meant to improve work conditions in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation. No financial amount or updated status can be found for this project.
sources: http://www.awoko.org/2011/03/03/agreement-on-china-sierra-leone-economic-and-technical-cooperation-signed-in-freetown/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_chn/gjhdq_603914/gj_603916/fz_605026/1206_606090/1206x2_606110/t803142.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Mr. J. B. Dauda, ; Kuang Weilin,

title: Economic and Technical Cooperation for 'Agreed Upon' projects
description: In December of 2010, the governments of the Republic of Liberia and the People's Republic of China signed an Agreement on Economic and Technical Cooperation for 20,000,000 RBM Yuan. The amount will be used to finance projects that are to be agreed upon by the two governments, the Foreign Ministry reported. Liberia's Acting Foreign Minister, Dr. Toga Gayewea McIntosh, signed on behalf of the Liberian Government, while Chinese Ambassador Zhou Yuxiao signed on behalf of the Chinese Government. Project may be related to project #1723
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020101229e6ct0018p&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and Technical cooperation agreement
description: On May 19, 2010 a working session was held between Foreign Affairs Minister, Mr. Kamel Morjane and his Chinese counterpart, Mr. Yang Jiechi. The two ministers signed an economic and technical co-operation agreement, providing for a donation from the Chinese Government to the Tunisian Government worth 4 million dinars to finance a development project. The project was not specified.
sources: http://www.africa.com/news/news,TunisiaChina_Focus_On_Ways_to_Boost_Bilateral_Relations,3410.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.diplomatie.gov.tn/index.php?id=399&no_cache=1&tx_wdtreaties_pi1[action]=singleView&tx_wdtreaties_pi1[country]=CHN&tx_wdtreaties_pi1[pointer]=0&tx_wdtreaties_pi1[mode]=1&tx_wdtreaties_pi1[showUid]=838, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Economic and Technological aid
description: In 2008, Li Changchun, senior official of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) met with Mauritanian Prime Minister Zein Ould Zeidane and witnessed the signing of an agreement on economic and technological aid between the two countries. It is unclear what the terms of the agreement were or how it was implemented.
sources: http://vlex.cn/vid/mauritania-keen-traditional-friendship-198888067, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ce.cn/xwzx/gnsz/szyw/200803/26/t20080326_14964221.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and Trade Development Center
description: In 2007, Li Zhaoxing, Chinese Foreign Minister, went on a 7-nation tour, stopping in Benin to sign a variety of agreements and attend the launching ceremony of a new Chinese trade and economic development center in Benin. In 2008, construction began on Benin's Chinese Economy and Trade Development Center, a national-level aid project from the Chinese government. The center is located in Cotonou's Ganhi Business Center and is scheduled to be completed within 2008, becoming a high-end business center integrating exhibition, shopping, storage, business meetings, accommodations, and catering services. The Zhejiang Tianshi International Economic and Technological Cooperation Co., Ltd., was responsible for construction and will manage the center for the first 50 years, after which ownership will be transferred to Benin. In 2009, the center was launched with the Benin China Merchandise Show. The facility ultimately cost 50 million Yuan, with a land area of 9,700 square meters and construction area of 6,891 square meters. The building is 5 stories. Zhejiang Tianshi International Economic and Technical Cooperation, a private enterprise, said that it would build up the Center as a trade platform for Chinese products, while the center would become a bridge tower for the Chinese products entering the markets in Benin and even It is unclear exactly what the commitment year was, but it appears that it was 2007. STAFF_NOTES: This project is facilitating exports and is in support of private investment from China.
sources: http://www.zcom.gov.cn/zcomenglish/Policies%20Regulations/Finance%20Foreign%20Exchange/T238845.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinaconsulatesf.org/eng/xw/t287492.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BJEIND0020080505e4550001l&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Zhejiang Tianshi International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co., Ltd., Private Sector
donor_agency: Zhejiang Tianshi International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co., Ltd., Private Sector

title: Economic and tech coop: Personnel Training
description: On September 5, 2005, Wu Bangguo, chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, and Moroccan Prime Minister Driss Jettou signed a personnel training agreement. The status of the agreement is uncertain.

title: Economic and technical agreement
description: In 2006, Mauritanian Foreign Affairs and Cooperation Minister Ahmed Ould Sid Ahmed and his Chinese counterpart Li Zhaoxing signed a common agreement in the economic and technical spheres. It is unclear what the details of the agreement were or what its current status is.

title: Economic and technical agreement for development
description: In March 2012, the Chinese and Tunisian governments signed an economic and technical agreement which specified that China would give Tunisia a monetary grant of 80 million CNY to invest in development projects. The specific projects would be defined at a later date. The agreement was signed after a meeting with the Secretary of State for American and Asian Affairs, Hedi Ben Abbes, and the Chinese Vice Foreign Minister, Zhai Jun.
sources: http://www.diplomatie.gov.tn/index.php?id=27&L=0&tx_ttnews[tt_news]=835&cHash=d440da13dc6b270a0d304d6187096ef9, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.embassyoftunisia.com/index.php?id=7&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=80&cHash=619582b6057779a3f5cf284d6cdbd603, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Economic and technical cooperation agreement
description: In December 2012, Comoros signed an agreement on economic and technical cooperation with China for an amount of 10 million EUR. STAFF_NOTE: Source is in French.
sources: http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/dossiers-pays/comores/presentation-de-l-union-des/, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: Economic and technical cooperation agreement
description: On Friday November 23, 2012, Liberia and China signed a 15 million USD Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement. Liberia's Foreign Minister, Augustine Ngafuan, signed the pact on behalf of President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, while Zhao Jianhua represented the Chinese government at the signing ceremony. The 15 million dollars will go to a ministerial complex project, the Monrovia Vocational Training Center expansion project, and the annex at the National Legislature. It should be noted that this agreement funds Projects #1791 and #18648.
sources: http://www.mofa.gov.lr/press.php?news_id=728, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2012-11/24/c_131996735.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Augustine Kpehe Ngafuan, Foreign Minister ; Zhao Jianhua, Ambassador to Liberia (China)

title: Economic and technical cooperation agreement grant
description: On April 6, 2012 the Chinese government gave Zimbabwe a 80 million CNY grant as part of a larger economic and technical cooperation agreement worth 1.141 billion CNY. The agreements were signed during a visit by Chinese Vice Premier Hui Liangyu. Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce Chong Quan signed the agreements on behalf of China while respective ministers signed on behalf of Zimbabwe. Other agreements signed at this time included a 31.5 million CNY agreement for provision of an outside broadcasting van for the Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation, 4.5 million CNY for neonatal equipment and a loan agreement for upgrading the Victoria Falls Airport worth 1.025 billion CNY (ID #30137).
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020120406e846007k9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120407e8460005h&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sundaymail.co.zw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=28039:zim-china-in-economic-technical-co-operation-deal&catid=38:local-news&Itemid=131#.UfkX7NLvG1A, Media Report, including Wikileaks

contacts: Joice Mujuru, Zimbabwean Vice President ; Chong Quan, Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce (Chinese Government); Hui Liangyu, Chinese Vice Premier (Chinese Government)

title: Economic and technical cooperation package
description: On April 28, 2006 President Mwai Kibaki and Chinese President Hu Jintao witnessed the signing of a grant of Kshs 510,000,000 under an economic and technical cooperation agreement. Under the agreement on economic and technical cooperation, China extended to Kenya loans and grants for many projects including the Kshs 8.5 billion Northern and Eastern Bypasses road project and the Kshs 2.16 billion. This project may be connected with (and possibly the funding source for)the Northern and Eastern Bypasses road projects, #1136 and #1112
sources: http://www.statehousekenya.go.ke/news/april06/2006280401.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020060428e24s0037g&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and technological cooperation agreement
description: On the afternoon of September 8, 2004, Chinese President Hu attended a signing ceremony for an economic and technological cooperation agreement. Further information about the agreement, including financial amounts, implementing agencies, contacts and start and end dates are unknown.

title: Economic and technological cooperation agreement
description: In 2004, China and Ethiopia signed an agreement of economic and technological cooperation. The signing ceremony was attended by Chinese Premier Wen Jiaobao and Ethiopian Prime Minsiter Meles Zenawi. The status of the agreement is unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020041102e0b20050m&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and technological cooperation agreements
description: China and Togo signed a number of economic and technological cooperation agreements after talks between visiting Chinese Vice President Zeng Qinghong and Togolese President Gnassingbe Eyadema in June of 2004. The agreements include the establishment of a joint economic, trade and technological cooperation commission between the People's Republic of China and the Republic of Togo, two eco- tech cooperation accords concerning providing assistance gratis and interest-free loans by the Chinese government to the Togolese government for funding projects agreed upon by the two governments, and a framework agreement on providing preferential loans by China to Togo for realization of the Adjarala hydroelectric project.See #2170 for Adjarala hydroelectric project
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020040624e06o00669&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/200406280518.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Economic and trade cooperation
description: In October of 2003, China's Council for the Promotion of International Trade, the Macao Trade and Investment Promotion Institute and the trade promotion organizations from the seven Portuguese-speaking countries signed a cooperation agreement at a trade and investment fair. The fair was part of the three-day Forum for Economic and Trade Cooperation attended by China, Brazil, Portugal, Angola, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique and East Timor. The agreement included enhancing mutual economic and trade cooperation through the means of market research, trade exchanges, the establishment of business partnership, investment promotion, support for private enterprises, and the organizing of conferences, meetings workshops, exhibitions and seminars. No financial value is associated with this agreement.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-24689096_ITM, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020031013dzac000kd&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Macao Trade and Investment Promotion Institute (IPIM), Government Agency; China Council for the Promotion of International Trade (CCPIT), Government Agency
donor_agency: Macao Trade and Investment Promotion Institute (IPIM), Government Agency; China Council for the Promotion of International Trade (CCPIT), Government Agency

title: Economic and trade website
description: On June 7, 2007, Kenya and China signed a memorandum of understanding for the launch of a joint Kenya-China Economic and Trade website to be funded by China as a platform for sharing information on policies and regulations on trade and investment. The MOU, which was signed by Kenyan Trade and Industry Minister Mukhisa Kituyi and Chinese Ambassador Zhang Ming on behalf of Chinese Ministry of Commerce, will also enable the two countries share information on macroeconomic data, industry and market, business and products, imports and exports among others. The website was launched in April and finalized on June 7, 2007. The amount is unknown.
sources: http://www.ckc.mofcom.gov.cn/article/ckcsbdt/201008/67326_1.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BDU0000020070608e36800026&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: China Ministry of Commerce, Government Agency
donor_agency: China Ministry of Commerce, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Kenyan Ministry of Trade and Industry, Government Agency

title: Economic assistance grant
description: On September 9, 2003, an agreement on a grant of 30 million CNY for projects to be determined by both sides was signed between Chinese deputy foreign minister, Qiuo Zhonghai, and the President of Madagascar, Marc Ravalomanana. The current status of projects to be financed with this grant have yet to be determined.

title: Economic assistance grant
description: In February of 2004, Chinese assistant minister of commerce, Fu Ziying, and Malagasy Deputy Prime Minister Zaza Manitranja Ramandimbiarison signed an economic aid agreement for a grant of 20 million CNY. The projects to be financed with this grant have yet to be determined.

title: Educational Aid
description: On December 3, 2005, Ethiopia and China signed accords which enable them to work together in technical and vocational education. Education Minister Dr. Sintayehu Wolde-Michael said that Chinese teachers would soon arrive in Ethiopia to share their experiences in various fields of study to aid Ethiopian education development.The status of the educational aid is uncertain.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020051204e1c40008e&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
location_details: Chinese teachers to Ethiopia and Ethiopian professionals to China for education

title: Educational Materials
description: In 2004, China donated education materials to Djibouti, financed by $120,000 grant.The status of this project is uncertain.
sources: http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=05DJIBOUTI995, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Educational and Medical Services
description: In 2007, Chinese Vice-Premier Wu Yi called on a group of 100 Africa-bound experts and volunteers to provide good service to their African hosts. 26 volunteers were sent to work in education and medical services in Mauritius, Tunisia, and Eritrea.The status of the workers is uncertain. STAFF_NOTES: This project was left ODA-like since the Vice-Premier made an announcement for the volunteers. There is no information on which organization or government sponsored the volunteer program, but the government's approval of it creates a logical argument for ODA-like.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020071116e3bg003h2&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Egyptian remote education system Phase I
description: In August 2002, the first phase of the Egyptian Remote Education was established with the aid of the Chinese government and China's ZTE Corporation's technicians. The project was put into use for five years. The amount and location are unknown.
sources: http://wwwen.zte.com.cn/endata/magazine/ztetechnologies/2000year/no5/articles/200312/t20031212_161043.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://vlex.cn/vid/phase-remote-education-completed-inegypt-198543323, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Egyptian remote education system Phase II
description: On December 6, 2004 during a bilateral meeting in Cairo, Egypt, Egypt's Minister of State for International Cooperation Fayza Abul Nagaa and China's Minister of Commerce Bo Xilai signed an agreement for a grant of 30 million CNY to help Egypt launch the second phase of a long-distance teaching project. This second phase was completed in 2007. The exact start and end dates of the project are unknown.

title: Egyptian-Chinese Enterprise for Unwoven Cloth
description: On May 26, 2008, Egypt's Minister of Investment, Dr. Mahmoud Mohieldin, the Governor of Suez, General Seif Galal, and the Chinese Ambassador to Egypt inaugurated a 70 million EGP joint project, the Egyptian-Chinese Enterprise for Unwoven Cloth, in the third sector of North West Suez Gulf. The company employs 250 Egyptian workers and assigns 70 percent of production to export. The start date is unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=MISTNW0020080526e45q0005u&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: El Fashir - Umm Kaddada Road
description: (PPIAF-ID:266) In 2009, China Poly Group Corporation signed an agreement to construct the El Fashir - Um Kaddada road. The construction is being financed by export credits from the China Exim Bank worth 96 million USD. The project is under the Sudan 3 billion framework agreement with China. The project is last known to be in implementation. The current status and end date are unknown. The project is part of a 650 million dollar network linking Khartoum to Western states in Darfur.
sources: https://publications.worldbank.org/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=22946, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.skyscrapercity.com/showthread.php?t=1004905, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://gb.cri.cn/27824/2010/01/15/3365s2733201.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: China Poly Group Corporation, State-Owned Company
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency; China Poly Group Corporation, State-Owned Company

title: El Nahood - Um Kaddada Road
description: (PPIAF-ID:267) In 2009, China Chongqing International Construction Corporation signed a contract with Sudan to build a 211 km long road that joins Kordofan with Darfur and is part of the Western Salvation Road. The contract is financed by the China Exim Bank with export credits worth 122 million USD and is under the $3 billion framework agreement between Sudan and China. Construction commenced in January 2010. The current status and end date are unknown. The project is part of a 650 million dollar network linking Khartoum to Western states in Darfur. This project is linked to ID#852, ID#1013, ID#1051, ID#1053, and ID#1059. Alternative spellings include El Nuhud and Umkadada.
sources: https://publications.worldbank.org/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=22946, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.cq.xinhuanet.com/business/2010-01/07/content_18703648.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.skyscrapercity.com/showthread.php?t=1004905, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: China Chongqing International Construction Corporation (CICO), State-Owned Company

title: Eldibeibat - EI Fula Road Road
description: (PPIAF-ID:268) In 2009, China Chongqing International Construction Corporation and Sudan signed an agreement for the construction of the 185 km Eldibeibat - EI Fula Road in Northern and Southern Kordofan States worth 100 million USD. The project is financed by the China Exim Bank and is under the 3 billion framework agreement between Sudan and China. Construction commenced in Jan 2010. The current status and end date are unknown.Chinese source translation excerpts:After a year of preparation, at the beginning of 2009 Chongqing International Construction Corporation signed a contract for the construction of two roads, one a 211-km road from Luhude (Chinese pinyin) to Wumugeda (Chinese pinyin), and another 185-km road from Dibaibate (Chinese pinyin) to Fula (Chinese pinyin). The contract is worth $220 million.Chongqing import and export credit guarantee co., LTD provided a $20 million loan guarantee to China Chongqing International Construction Corporation as well as $66.6 million as a 'non-financial guarantee.' The project is part of a 650 million dollar network linking Khartoum to Western states in Darfur.

title: Electic generator factory
description: On May 26, 2008, Egyptian Minister for Investment Dr. Mahmoud Mohieldin announced that a factory for electric generators would be built in the North West Suez Gulf Economic Zone with an investment of 40 million USD by the Chinese African Fund for Development. The current status and start and end dates of the project are unknown. During the same announcement, the Minister for Investment announced that the Chinese African Fund for Development would also invest in a motorbike assembly factory for 13 million USD (See ID#625) and a plan for a tractor assembly for 4 million USD (See Project ID#629).
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=MISTNW0020080526e45q0005u&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.setc-zone.com/portal/index, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

donor_agency: China-Africa Development Fund, Public Private Partnership

title: Election funding
description: In 2009, China offered materials to Ivory Coast in support of the presidential elections scheduled for November of the same year. Part of the $10 million USD had been released by the Ministry of Economy and Finance as of September of 2009. The sum includes supplies ranging from cellular phones to sun lamps, but the project appears to be untied.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020090928e59s000xh&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
recipient_agencies: Independent Electoral Commission (CEI), Government Agency

title: Electrical network (Related to Project ID#65 and ID#66)
description: A complementary individual financing accord was signed in July of 2008 by the Angolan Finance minister, Jose Pedro de Morais, and the chairman of Eximbank, Li Ruogu. The accord concerns an agreement for funding of the project of rehabilitation and expansion of the electrical network of the cities of Dundo (Lunda Norte province) and Saurimo (Luanda Sul), estimated at around USD 50 million loan. OVERVIEW: New Exim Bank head, Li Ruogu, and JosÃ© Pedro de Morais sign a â€œComplementary Individual Financing MOUâ€, which sees the disbursement of a separate US$134 million loan to three communal development projects in Angola. The terms of the loan are the same as the September 2007 Exim Bank loan. The credit will fund the modernisation of the electricity system in two towns in Lunda Norte and Luanda Sul provinces, the construction of a water treatment plant and canals in the Luanda area and a road upgrade projects in two other provinces. See Project ID#65 and ID#66 for the related projects described above.
sources: http://www.ide.go.jp/English/Data/Africa_file/Manualreport/cia_11.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020080704e474000qw&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://cn.reuters.com/article/chinaNews/idCNChina-1593420080704, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Electricity grid overhaul
description: In 2011, China agreed to lend Yuan 850 million ($128 million USD) to Gabon in order to help upgrade the power transmission and distribution grid serving the capital Libreville. A bilateral agreement covering the 20-year concessional loan, to be repaid at 2.5% interest, was signed during a visit to Gabon by the Chinese Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi, according to the Gabon government. On October 18, 2010 an overhaul of the Libreville power grid began. The project involves the design of the new power grid, equipment supply, and construction. Overall, three new substations will be built on top of the expansion of four existing ones. Three new overhead transmission lines and two underground cable transmission lines will also be added. The first part of the project began on October 21 when the management workers came to the work site to start the renovation process. The project should take 2 years to complete. The Chinese have loaned Gabon the money through a $130 million US dollar loan for 20 years with 2.5% annual interest. The construction faced difficulties in acquiring adequate lands from private property, and it was thus delayed for actual construction until 2012. The status of the grid is uncertain. STAFF_NOTES: The following text is translated from a Chinese source. It is uncertain if the referenced project is related:(The project involves the construction of three new power transmission stations, four substations, three overhead transmission lines, and two underground cable transmission lines. The Endu Mu station is of the 225/90kV class, while the other transmission stations are of the 90/20kV variety. The transmission lines are of 90kV capacity and the overhead cable is 103km long, while the underground cable is 27km long. In December 2009, Chinese Sinohydro company signed a contract with the Gabonese government. The project is expected to last 24 months and will cost 97,000,000 euros; Chinese Exim Bank will provide the funding.) Concessionality is calculated assuming a zero grace period.
sources: http://www.oxfordbusinessgroup.com/news/supply-side-revamping-electricity-network, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.csdsjhw.com/qyxx/View.aspx?id=524, Other; http://www.sinodaily.com/afp/110214160409.14tba5wf.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://finance.stockstar.com/SS2011021530006474.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.csdsjme.com/typenews.asp?id=360, Other; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=PWRA000020110317e73300017&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://sg.finance.yahoo.com/news/China-finance-Gabon-afpsg-1766112932.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gabon-industriel.com//les-actions/zones-economiques/projet-belinga?ouv=4428#article4428, Other

implementing_agency: Sinohydro Corporation, State-Owned Company

title: Electricity transmission lines
description: (PPIAF) The decision to increase the Capanda dam's output of electricity has led to the construction of new electricity lines to transport power around Angola. Two power lines, Capanda-N'Dalatando and Cambambe-Luanda, are currently under construction using funding from China. The total project cost is $218 million USD, but it is unclear exactly how much funding is coming directly from China. The Capanda-N'Dalatando power line was expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2007, and the Cambambe-Luanda power line was expected to be completed in June of 2007. It appears that both lines have been completed. The contractor responsible for the project is the China Railway Construction Corporation (CRCC), and the funding came from the Chinese Export-Import Bank. PPIAF-ID:27
sources: http://content.ebscohost.com/pdf23_24/pdf/2009/WEC/01Nov09/45577094.pdf?T=P&P=AN&K=45577094&S=R&D=buh&EbscoContent=dGJyMNLe80Seqa44v%25252525252BvlOLCmr0qep7FSsqa4SLKWxWXS&ContentCustomer=dGJyMPGssk2xqLJNuePfgeyx44Hy, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://114.113.29.168/bslw/2010107745.pdf, Other; http://www.oecd.org/countries/angola/38561655.pdf, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.macauhub.com.mo/en/2007/03/06/2649/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.hydroworld.com/articles/2007/04/third-unit-of-angolas-520-mw-capanda-begins-operation.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.crcc.cn/434-1122-880.aspx, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: Electronic media equipment
description: In October 2006, the Chinese Embassy to Eritrea extended different electronic media equipment to the Eritrean Ministry of Information. Mr. Asmelash Abraha, Director General of TV in the Ministry, said the equipment would help in the day-to-day activities of the Ministry.

title: Embassy Donation
description: On March 29, the Embassy and two Chinese Business Chambers donated 80 bicycles, 50 sewing machines, 35 TV sets, 1500 footballs, 1500 radio sets, 1650 square meters of iron piva and 5 wind power generators, worth 260 million Tanzanian shillings (TZS) to the Tanzanian State House.
sources: http://tz.china-embassy.org/eng/sgxx/t679147.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Embassy Donation to Ministry of Youth
description: In 2006, the Chinese government donated 10 Television Sets, 8 Computer Sets, 8 Lexmark Printers, 3 DVD players, 5 refrigerators, 3 air conditioners, 382 backpacks, and 1072 sports equipments to the Mauritian Ministry of Youth. The estimated value of this donation is 770,750 MUR. The exact start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://www.gov.mu/portal/goc/treasury/file/annual06/statui.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
recipient_agencies: Ministry of Youth and Sports, Government Agency

title: Emergency Equipment Donation
description: After the explosion of an arms depot in Congo on March 4, 2012, China donated 480 insecticide treated mosquito nets, 80 transistor radios, and 8 solar powered streetlights. The Chinese ambassador to Congo, Li Shu Li, commented on the donation. China also donated 3 million USD to Congo to help the African country care for the victims of the blast (project ID #30708).
sources: http://www.congo-site.com/L-aide-internationale-aux-victimes-des-explosions-de-Mpila-se-consolide-davantage_a12042.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Emilienne Raoul, Minister of Social Affairs, Humanitarian Action and Solidarity ; Li Shu Li, Ambassador to the Republic of the Congo (China)

title: Emergency Food aid to Djibouti
description: On September 5, 2005, China donated emergency food aid to Djibouti. China donated 500 tons of rice, 518.25 tons of flour, 7,560 cases of oil, totaling CNY 10 million to help drought victims. According to Djibouti's Secretary of State Zara Yusuf, more than 16,000 households were expected to receive food aid. China planned to give a total of 60 million yuan worth of food to Djibouti in 2005. The second batch of food aid was expected to arrive in Djibouti on October 18, 2005.
sources: http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/i/jyjl/k/200509/20050900403264.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020060119e21j000b6&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Emergency Humanitarian Aid following Earthquake
description: On May 23, 2003 the Chinese Ministry of Commerce announced that China would offer emergency humanitarian aid worth 5 million yuan to the earthquake-hit Algeria. It is unclear how the Ministry of Commerce is involved in the project. On that same day, China sent an earthquake rescue team of 30 personnel to Algeria. The team was headed by a deputy director of the China Seismological Bureau, and provided aid for the disaster victims. The team carried 3 search dogs and rescue equipment. On May 30, the team successfully accomplished their mission and returned to China.
sources: http://www.todayonhistory.com/5/30/ZhongGuoGuoJiJiuYuanDuiFuAErJiLiYaDiZhenZaiQuJiuYuanYuanManHuiGuo.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.cctv.com/english/news/China/Politics/20030524/100092.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=xnews00020030526dz5n0000h&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://top81.jschina.com.cn/top81bbs/thread.php?cid=1&rootid=731692&id=731723, Media Report, including Wikileaks
donor_agency: China Ministry of Commerce, Government Agency

title: Emergency flood assistance
description: In a speech on September 26, 2012, the Chinese Ambassador to Comoros talked about the flood that ravaged the country in April of 2012. As many people died and infrastructure was ruined from the damage, the Chinese government has given $230,000 US Dollars to the country in financial assistance. STAFF_NOTE: One of the listed sources does not provide an amount for the monetary support China gave.
sources: http://www.beit-salam.km/article.php3?id_article=2074&var_recherche=chine, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinese-embassy.org.za/eng/zfgxss/zyjw/t966218.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Emergency food aid
description: On December 10, 2007,the World Food Program (WFP) had a handover ceremony between China and Ethiopia. The Chinese donated a total of 452 tons of lentils valued at $250,000 US dollars to the Ethiopian areas of Tigray, Amhara, Oromia, and Southern states. The donation will benefit the implementation of the AIDS assistance project helping people living with HIV/AIDS get their needed food and nutrient supply. Miguel Bali Tuo, the deputy representative for Ethiopia at the World Food Program, said that the donation will directly benefit over 100,000 Ethiopians who suffer under this disease.
sources: http://news.xinhuanet.com/newscenter/2007-12/11/content_7228893.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Miguel Bali Tuo, Deputy Representative ; Lin Lin,

title: Emergency food shortage relief
description: On November 25, 2002, the Chinese government via Vice-foreign minister, Jang Wenchang, announced that it would donate 5,000 metric tons of food aid for the drought-induced food shortage. The status of this aid is uncertain.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcap00020021125dybp006mx&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcap00020021125dybp006mx&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcap00020021125dybp0053d&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Engineers to join Darfur peacekeepers
description: On May 8, 2007, China announced that it would send an engineering unit to join a UN-led peacekeeping force in Darfur, Sudan. The first batch of 135 engineers and troops of an expected total of 315 were deployed in Darfur in November 24, 2007. Their main task was to build camps, roads and to dig wells. On January 12, 2009, the first batch of engineers left for China and were replaced by a team of 160 engineers. The third batch of 172 arrived in July 2008. In March 2011, a fifth detachment of engineers arrived to take part in the Darfur peacekeeping mission. A sixth detachment arrived in January 2012. The amount and end date are unknown.
sources: http://www.sudantribune.com/Last-batch-of-Chinese-peacekeepers,27912, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.cntv.cn/program/newsupdate/20120621/107838.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.sina.com/china/2009/0111/210788.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90776/90883/7334371.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sudantribune.com/Darfur-JEM-vows-to-not-attack,24937, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pmsol3.wordpress.com/2008/02/04/chinese-peacekeepers-in-sudan/, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020070508e358003ye&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: United Nations (UN), Multilateral

title: Ensure maintenance on Govt buildings
description: On June 24, 2011 The Liberian government and the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China signed a bilateral agreement regarding the maintenance of the Samuel Kanyon Doe Sports Complex, the elevator at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and facilities of the University of Liberia Fendall Campus. The agreement was signed by Chinese Ambassador to Liberia, Zhao Jianhua and the Liberian Foreign Minister, Dr. Toga McIntosh. In July 2013, the Chinese government $16 million for reconstruction of the stadium. The timeline for project implementation remains uncertain.

title: Equip the township of Tomegbe with a high capacity generating unit
description: (PPIAF) The Chinese embassy in Togo had equipped the township of Tomegbe with a high capacity generating unit in order to electrify the area with 25,000 inhabitants who have been living in darkness since 1990.; PPIAF-ID:290

title: Equipment Donation
description: On July 13, 2000, China donated $250,000 worth of agricultural, fishing, lumbering, and machinery-maintaining equipment to Sierra Leone. The Minister of Education, Youths and Sports Amadu Wurie spoke at the handing-over ceremony in Freetown. Chinese Ambassador to Sierra Leone, Yu Wuzhen, also attended the ceremony.

title: Equipment for Culture
description: On May 31, 2000 Tanzanian Prime Minister Frederick Sumaye and Tanzanian Minister for Education and Culture Juma Kapuya met with a Chinese delegation led by Chinese Deputy Cultural Minister Meng Xiaosi. During the day, Meng granted 20,000 USD to the Tanzanian Ministry of Education and Culture for purchasing some much-needed equipment. No further information can be found about this project.

title: Equipment for Malawi parliament
description: In September 2011, the Chinese Ambassador to Malawi Pan Hujen fulfilled his earlier pledge to furnish the new Malawian parliament building that was completed in 2010. The Chinese government donated 25 million MWK worth of equipment which included 25 desktop computers and 12 LCD TVs that will be used to digitize transcripts of parliamentary debates.
sources: http://www.zodiakmalawi.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2496:china-spoils-malawi-parliament, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Pan Hujen, Ambassador to Malawi (China Ministry of Foreign Affairs); Henry Chimunthu , Speaker of the House (Government of Malawi)

title: Equipment for the Health Sector
description: On the anniversary of Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam's historic visit to China on the 10th of July, 1972, the current Prime Minister Navinchandra Ramgoolam and Financial Minister Rama Sithanen made an official visit to Beijing in 2007 and were offered, among other things, the provision of equipment for the health sector. The current status of this project is yet unknown. The other offers made on this same visit are projects ID#1152, ID#20184, ID#20178, ID#20814.
sources: http://www.gov.mu/portal/site/pmosite?content_id=67c1259cc4d24110VgnVCM1000000a04a8c0RCRD, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Equipment to Kenya's national youth service
description: On January 29, 2010, Kenya's President Mwai Kibaki spoke at a ceremony for the arrival of equipment worth 4.3 billion KES for Kenya's National Youth Service purchased through the China Aviation Industry Corporation with a concessional loan from the Government of China. The equipment included road construction and earth moving equipment, agricultural machinery, fire fighting engines and generators, computers, radios, and other equipment. Negotiations for the equipment began in 2006. The terms of the loan and exact commitment date are unknown.
sources: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PsbB98wj78c, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020100129e61t0035x&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/newscenter/2010-01/29/content_12900852.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Equity Bank SME Loans
description: On May 17, 2010 China Development Bank (CDB) signed an agreement for a 50 million USD loan to Kenya Equity Bank. Kenya Equity Bank will use the loan to finance further loans that boost small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Kenya, especially agro-processing for exports. Kenya Equity will provide 3-7 year loans for a six-year period, advanced to SMEs at interest rates of between 3 and 7 percent. The signing ceremony was attended by Equity Bank chief executive Dr James Mwangi, The project forms part of a larger, Africa-wide project that involves a Chinese 5 billion dollar fund for the development of small and medium enterprises.
sources: http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/-/2558/923604/-/view/printVersion/-/tfrbht/-/index.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=SCEB000020101125e6bp00007&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020100517e65h007hl&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
