contacts: Gata Ngoulou, Minister of Infracture ; Gata Ngoulou, Chadian Minister of Infrastructure ; Hu Zhiqiang, Chinese Ambassador to Chad

title: Grant to Egypt
description: On December 25, 2008, Egyptian Prime Minister Ahmed Nazif and the Chinese deputy prime minister signed an economic and technical cooperation agreement between the two governments in which China offered a 50 million CNY grant to Egypt. The sector, current status, and start and end dates of the project are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=DAINEG0020081225e4cp0000b&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Grant to Epandulo Women Development Project
description: In a budget report covering 2008-2009, a monetary grant of 20,000 NAD was earmarked for an Epandulo Women Development Project. The grant was given by the Ambassador of China on March 23, 2009.
sources: http://209.88.21.36/opencms/export/sites/default/grnnet/OPDev1/Archive/AnnualReports/office_of_president_annual_report_2008_2009.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Grant to Kenyan government
description: On January 6, 2010, Chinese foreign minister Yang Jiechi announced that China would award a grant of KES 540 million to Kenya. The grant will 'finance projects of the Kenyan government's choice.' Kenyan foreign minister Moses Wetang'ula and Kenyan President Mwai Kibaki attended the ceremony. The specific programs the grant will fund, as well as their implementation dates and organizations, are unknown.The grant is linked to a grant for a Kenyan e-government project #811, also awarded at the ceremony. The ceremony formed part of the Chinese foreign minister's tour of the 5 poorest countries in the world: Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Algeria, Morocco and Saudi Arabia.
sources: http://www.afdata.cn/html/qydtxx/20100107/16004.html, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.tianjinwe.com/rollnews/201002/t20100221_529982.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE6050JO20100106, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020100107e6170003l&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Moses Wetang'ula, ; H.E. President Mwai Kibaki, CGH, MP, ; Mr Yang Jiechi,

title: Grant to Pay Maize Farmers (needs confirmation)- completion
description: On April 24, 2002 China extended a $3 million grant to the Kenyan government to help it pay outstanding debt owed by the Kenyan State Cereals Agency to local farmers and ease a crisis in the maize sector. Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji and Kenyan President Daniel Arap Moi signed the grant. A letter of intent from Kenya to the IMF in 2009 states that as of May 15 Kenya had received $3 million from China to assist the maize crisis. The exact locations and dates of the project are unknown.
sources: http://www.imf.org/external/np/loi/2009/ken/051509.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=lba0000020020424dy4o00upp&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
recipient_agencies: National Cereals & Produce Board, Government Agency

title: Grant to President's efforts in supporting vulnerable children
description: On January 8, 2009 in Kigali, China's Ambassador to Rwanda, Sun Shuzhong presented a grant of 70,000 USD to Foreign Affairs Minister Rosemary Museminali for Rwanda's President Paul Kagame's personal efforts in supporting vulnerable children. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020090108e518003e9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Grant to aquaculture development
description: In 2010, China offered N$15 million to Namibia to assist with aquaculture development. It is unclear how the funds were used.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAP00020100128e61s00336&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: China Ministry of Agriculture, Government Agency
donor_agency: China Ministry of Agriculture, Government Agency

title: Grant to assist refugees
description: On June 7, 2000, Sudan's Minister of State for External Relations, Mr Ali Abd al-Rahman al-Numayri, received a check of 30,000 USD from the Chinese government and the Chinese Red Cross society. The donation was to express solidarity with the Sudanese people and government following the influx of refugees into eastern Sudan as a result of the Ethiopian-Eritrean war. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcmep0020010804dw6700ip5&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Chinese Government, Government Agency; Red Cross Society of China, National NGO
donor_agency: Chinese Government, Government Agency; Red Cross Society of China, National NGO

title: Grant to be Used for Agreed Upon Projects
description: On March 30, 2011 Liberia's Minister of Foreign Affairs Toga Gayewea Mcintosh signed a Cooperation Agreement on behalf of the Government of the Republic of Liberia with China's Vice Minister of Commerce Fu Ziyang, for a Grant of 50 million RMB Yuan. According to a Foreign Ministry release the grant will be used for projects to be agreed on by the two governments. This grant was used for installation of solar powered lights in the capital of Monrovia (project ID#1799).
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201103310858.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofa.gov.lr/press.php?news_id=352, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://tnrliberia.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=293:monrovia-gets-solar-traffic-lights-soon&catid=64:general&Itemid=49, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.coema.org.cn/oenews/industry/20091012/213633.html, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.inprofiledaily.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7065:chinese-company-clarifies-delay-in-solar-system-traffic-lights-project-&catid=1:headlines&Itemid=56, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Toga Gayewea Mcintosh, (Ministry of Foreign Affairs); Fu Ziyang, (Ministry of Commerce)

title: Grant to boost rice production
description: On October 17, 2001, the Chinese government donated 1.6 billion RWF to help in growing rice in Kagitumba valley in Muvumba of Mutara Province. The agreement was signed between the Ministry of Agriculture and a Chinese government official in Rwanda. The growing of rice in the 300 ha valley will take 22 months. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcae00020011014dxa700002&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Grant to boost trade
description: In August 2011, China, represented by Gao Hucheng, Chinese Deputy Commerce Minister and international trade representative, gave Rwanda a 50 million CNY grant to boost trade between the two countries. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.At the same time, China gave Rwanda an interest-free loan to boost trade (See Project ID#2021).
sources: http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/China+targets+Rwanda+infrastructure+projects/-/2558/1229816/-/view/printVersion/-/nqny1az/-/index.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gov.rw/New-article,453, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Grant to construct the Third Bridge for Mali in Bamako
description: In August 2007, China agreed to provide a grant to construct the 'Third Bridge' for Mali in Bamako. The project will be built by China Gezhouba Group International. The total project cost was approximated at $51.5 million. The bridge was built 10 km from downtown Bamako, and is 2.3 km long and 24 m wide with four traffic lanes, according to Ma Jiangquan, deputy engineer general of the No 2 Co of the China Gezhouba Group International. President Amadou Toumani Toure inaugurated the China-Mali Friendship Bridge on September 22, 2011.(PPIAF) In August 2007 China government confirmed to provide the grant to construct the 'Third Bridge' for Mali in Bamako.; Total Project Cost: USD 51.5499254843517 Million; PPIAF-ID:182

title: Grant to rehabilitate Darfur
description: In 2005, China and Sudan signed an agreement for China to give Sudan a grant worth 10 million CNY for humanitarian aid for Darfur. The start and end dates of the project are unknown.This may be part of five bundles of humanitarian aid that China gave to Sudan for Darfur since 2004. (See Project ID#2164, Project ID#1575, Project ID#2405, and Project ID#2288)
sources: http://www.gov.cn/misc/2007-08/16/content_719116.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article15173, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Grant to rehabilitate Darfur
description: On 20 April, 2006, the Chinese ambassador to Sudan and Sudan's Minister of International Cooperation, Dr. Al-Tjani Salih Fudayl, signed an agreement for China to give Sudan a grant worth 10 million CNY for humanitarian aid for Darfur. The start and end dates of the project are unknown.This may be part of five bundles of humanitarian aid that China gave to Sudan for Darfur since 2004. (See Project ID#14113, Project ID#2164, Project ID#2405, and Project ID#2288)
sources: http://www.gov.cn/misc/2007-08/16/content_719116.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article15173, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Grant to rehabilitate radiotherapy hospital
description: On September 21, 2002 in Khartoum, Sudan, Sudan's Minister of International Cooperation, Yusuf Takana, and China's Deputy Minister of Foreign Trade signed an agreement for a grant of 2.5 million USD for the rehabilitation of the Radiotherapy Hospital among other services and development projects. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcmep0020020922dy9m0073l&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Grant to resettle refugees
description: On May 15, 2008 the Chinese government gave Kenya 200 million shillings (3.2 million dollars) to help resettle hundreds of thousands of villagers who were uprooted from their villages by the political turmoil following Kenyan elections. The Chinese government granted 1 million USD in cash as well as around 2 million USD in corrugated iron for housing. The project is linked to a 200 million shillings loan of the same nature, Project #1133. Further details about the project are unknown due to difficulties in obtaining data.
sources: http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/ce/ceke/chn/zt/zkjl/t515317.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://news.dayoo.com/world/57402/200809/28/57402_4250338.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020080515e45f004vv&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Grant to support economic projects
description: On April 12, 2012, China and Egypt signed two agreements under which China will provide aid worth 19.3 million USD to Egypt in a support of the its economic projects. According to Chinese Ambassador Song Aiguo, China will offer a 90 million CNY grant to fund a number of Egyptian projects. The two nations also signed an agreement where China will build a park in southern Egypt's Luxor city, an investment of some 32 million CNY (ID #30726).
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020120412e84c00b41&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120417e84g00067&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020120412e84c00b41&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120417e84g00067&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Grant to support the Defence and Security Sector Reform Programme
description: In 2010, the President of the ECOWAS Commission, Amb. James Gbeho reported that China promised to support Guinea-Bissau with 10 million EUR. This increased the total funding support available to fund the Defence and Security Sector Reform Programme (DSSRP) for Guinea-Bissau to 42 million EUR. This is half of the estimated amount needed to implement the DSSRP. The United Nations and the ECOWAS Mediation and Security Council have pursued the implementation of the Defence and Security Sector Reform Programme (DSSRP) to increase political stability, improve professionalism in government, and increase deference to civil authority among the armed services in Guinea-Bissau.
sources: http://news.ecowas.int/presseshow.php?nb=182&lang=en&annee=2010, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://fmi.gov.ng/latest/2467/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
recipient_agencies: Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), Multilateral

title: Grants for HIV/AIDS care
description: On August 14, 2003, China provided 33,745 LSL in funding for HIV and AIDS care to the Office of the First Lady in the Lesotho government. An additional source indicated that China has continued to provide funding, but no evidence of this can be found.
crs_sector_name: Population Policies / Programmes and Reproductive Health
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/200308250320.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ipsnews.net/2009/03/health-lesotho-migration-calls-for-cross-border-health-policies/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Grants for economic development
description: In 2006, China pledged 20 million Yuan in grants to Rwanda for economic development. It is unclear exactly how the funds were used. Further details are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020061113e2bd000v0&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Grants of financial assistance for the Sudanese Government
description: On June 12, 2008, Awad Ahmed al-Jaz, Sudanese Minister of finance and national economy, and Shi Quangsheng, Chinese Minister of Trade, signed an agreement for China to provide two grants of financial assistance to the Sudanese government. The ceremony was attended by Ali Osman Mohamed Taha, Sudan's Vice-President and Xi Jinping, China's Vice-President. The amount and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCMEP0020080612e46c003e9&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://world.people.com.cn/GB/1029/42359/7370503.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Guinean gym
description: In 2011, China agreed to assist with the construction of a Guinean gym. It is unclear how much the facility is worth or if construction has commenced.
sources: http://news.alibaba.com/article/detail/international-trade-special/100469219-1-5th-china-guinea-joint-commission-commerce.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Fu Ziyang, Vice Minister of Commerce ; Mustafa Sanu,

title: Gymnasiums
description: On November 1, 2006, Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao met with Guinea Bissau President Joao Bernardo Vieira. Wen said that China had helped Guinea Bissau in agriculture and social welfare projects, including building hospitals, gymnasiums, and houses. The location and commitment/completion dates of this project are unknown.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-153667458/president-assures-pm-wen.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Gyneco-Obstetric and Paediatric hospital
description: In January 2007 Hu Jintao and a group that includes the Chinese minister of commerce, Bo Xilai, the foreign minister Li Zhaoxing and other senior policy makers, signed eight accords with Cameroon, including a concessional loan agreement to build a gynecological, obstetric and pediatric hospital in Douala. In February 2007, China donated equipment and pre-construction studies of more than one hundred million francs from the Chinese government to the Gyneco-Obstetric and Paediatric hospitals in Yaounde and Douala #22839. The project is being implemented by China Building Technique Group Co., Ltd. (CBTGC). It does appear that the project has begun early stages of implementation. STAFF_NOTES:Project #343 was originally in Mandarin. When translated, it was discovered to be financing this project and the project records were merged.
crs_sector_name: Population Policies / Programmes and Reproductive Health
sources: http://cm.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200909/20090906516225.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ccs.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/CCS-Central-Africa-Briefing-Paper-August-2009.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://news.cameroon-today.com/president-paul-biya-of-cameroon-visits-china/7263/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://cm.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200708/20070805003842.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.reuters.com/article/2007/01/31/africa-china-idUSL3173715420070131, Media Report, including Wikileaks

donor_agency: China Building Technique Group Co., Ltd. (CBTGC), State-Owned Company

title: Gyneco-Obstetric and Paediatric hospital equipment and studies donation
description: In February 2007, China donated equipment and pre-construction studies of more than one hundred million francs from the Chinese government to the Gyneco-Obstetric and Paediatric hospitals in Yaounde and Douala. In January 2007 Hu Jintao and a group that includes the Chinese minister of commerce, Bo Xilai, the foreign minister Li Zhaoxing and other senior policy makers, signed eight accords with Cameroon, including a concessional loan agreement to build a gynecological, obstetric and pediatric hospital in Douala Project ID #314.

title: HIV/AIDS health experts and medical equipment
description: On October 17, 2007, during a meeting with Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni at the state house in Uganda, Chinese vice minister for national population and planning, Wang Piyang, announced his government would donate medical equipment to Uganda and provide health experts while assisting in HIV/AIDS related issues and other health matters. The amount, current status, and start and end dates are unknown.
crs_sector_name: Population Policies / Programmes and Reproductive Health
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020071017e3ah000rt&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/newscenter/2007-10/17/content_6895151.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Wang Piyang, Vice Minister for National Population and Planning ; Yoweri Museveni,

title: Hanhe Uganda Hebei Farm
description: In 2009, Hebei Hanhe Investment Co., under the direction of Qiu Lijun, began trial planting and experimentation in Uganda. African Development Fund under the China Development Bank assisted in funding the Hanhe Uganda Hebei Farm. In 2011 the Hanhe Uganda Hebei farm started cultivating vegetables on a large scale, covering 2,600 mu (173 hectares) of land in Uganda, with plans of expanding to 260,000 mu (17,333 hectares) in the future. The farm had an initial capital of 9.9 million CNY and a reported total area of 20,000 acres in 2010, but it is unclear what portion of this 9.9 million CNY is from the CDB. The farm prepares the following products for export: cotton, coffee, leather, African handicraft clothing, marine products, rosewood, and ebony.
sources: http://www.chinaafricarealstory.com/2012/04/zombie-chinese-land-grabs-in-africa.html, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://www.ecns.cn/in-depth/2011/10-10/2859.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ccpithebei.com/Directory%20of%20Exporting%20Commodities%20for%20CCOIC%20HeBei%20Chamber%20of%20Commerce/2010-03-16/3406.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
implementing_agency: Hebei Hanhe Investment Co., Ltd., Private Sector
donor_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency; Hebei Hanhe Investment Co., Ltd., Private Sector
contacts: Qiu Lijun, (Hebei Hanhe Investment Co., Ltd.)

title: Hardap Island Inland Aquaculture Centre Reconstruction Project
description: In 2012, Namibia and China signed an agreement for the implementation of the Hardap inland aquaculture center reconstruction project and a Memorandum of Understanding for cooperation in fisheries. The Vice-Premier of the State Council of China Hui Liangyu and the Namibian Deputy Prime Minister Marco Hausiku signed the agreement for their governments. Four other agreements were signed at the meeting, including Project ID #30405 and Project ID #30407.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020120404e844001e3&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.namibiansun.com/content/business/nam-china-sign-deals, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.nbc.na/news_article.php?id=7050&title=Namibia%20and%20China%20sign%205%20agreements., Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Hui Liangyu, Vice-Premier of the State Council of China ; Marco Hausiku, Namibian Deputy Prime Minister

title: Health Care Staff
description: In 2010, China was to dispatch a 27-staff health care team to Mauritania, in addition to pharmaceuticals and medical consumables (Project ID#12532). Mauritanian Health Minister Cheikh Ould Horma signed a two-year renewable convention on the health assistance with Chinese Ambassador to Mauritania Zhang Xun. The health-care personnel will assist local doctors in the hospitals of the capital city, Nouakchott, eastern Kiffa and Selibaby on the River Senegal, as well as in research centres. It is unclear if the team arrived.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=APASENE020100610e66a0008i&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Health support to areas afflicted by floods
description: In 2012, China agreed to give Tunisia 1.3 million USD to upgrade local hospitals and health care centers in areas affected by flooding. Hedi Ben Abbes, Tunisian Secretary of State in charge of American and Asian relations at the Foreign Affairs Miinistry, said that the money is meant to upgrade local hospitals and health care centers.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNHA000020120228e82s00001&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNHA000020120228e82s00001&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNHA000020120228e82s00001&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNHA000020120228e82s00001&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Hedi Ben Abbes, Secretary of State for the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Americas and Asian division

title: Highway Project to connect Guinea & Sierra Leone
description: In 2011, a Sierra Leone delegation to China led by the President of the ECOWAS Commission, James Victor Gbeho reached an agreement with China Gezhouba, including the Makeni-Kamakwie Highway Project under the first phase of the Makeni-Kamakwie-Finonia-Madina Woula road scheme to link Sierra Leone with neighboring Guinea and other ECOWAS member states. This project took place under the framework of the TransAfrican Highway Project. The status of the project is uncertain.
sources: http://sl.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200310/20031000138936.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFBZ000020110826e78100009&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: China Gezhouba Group Company Ltd. (CGGC), State-Owned Company
donor_agency: China Gezhouba Group Company Ltd. (CGGC), State-Owned Company

title: Hospital Equipment
description: On September 13, 2005 during a visit to Gitega, Burundi, Qinghai's vice-governor, Mr Deng Ben Tai, promised to rehabilitate the hospital equipment of Gitega hospital. The amount, current status, and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020050915e19f002bd&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Hospital Upgrade
description: In April 2012 China donated a 150-bed facility worth 12.5 million USD to the Federal Staff Hospital in Abuja, Nigeria. The donation was part of agreement reached under the China-Africa Cooperation adopted in 2006. The contract for the National Staff Hospital was signed on August 7, 2009. Construction commenced on May 20, 2010 and was completed by April 2012. The Nigerian government donated the 4.85 hectares of land where the hospital was built and also provided the necessary infrastructural facilities which included portable water, electricity and temporary access roads.
sources: http://www.dailyindependentnig.com/2013/02/chinas-12-5m-hospital-donation-to-nigeria/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://fmi.gov.ng/fg-committed-to-providing-affordable-healthcare-services-to-nigerians-vice-president-sambo/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://allafrica.com/stories/201301290271.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Nigerian Federal Staff Hospital, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Nigerian Federal Staff Hospital, Government Agency
contacts: Deng Boqing, Chinese Ambassador to Nigeria (China)

title: Hospital at College of Medicine and Allied Health Sciences campus
description: In 2008, China agreed to construct a modern hospital near the College of Medicine and Allied Health Sciences campus at Kossoh Town, Hastings in Freetown. The project was as a result of a memorandum of understanding signed in Freetown by the government of Sierra Leone and the Chinese government. The hospital will have 100 beds, a hostel for the Chinese medical team, an equipment room, laboratory, theaters, a dialysis and intensive care units, surgical and medical departments, mortuary, a funeral parlour, X-Ray department among other facilities. He said the proposed construction site has been geographically designed free from natural disaster, adding that the two story hospital building would be rectangule shaped with a functional motor-way, a security post, an administrative building, boundary walls, two 400 KVA generators, a canteen, kitchen and other important components. It appears that the project was completed but the details are uncertain.
sources: http://www.weyonepress.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101:new-imc-chairmans-call-for-development-journalism-to-take-precedence-is-in-place&catid=38:economics&Itemid=69, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.cntv.cn/20110517/107737.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.qq.com/a/20090419/000458.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/200806070078.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Hospital deal with Sinopharm and Kenya's international hospital
description: In 2012, China Sinopharm International Corporation and Kenya's international hospital signed a cooperation agreement over the formation of a hospital with capital of intent of 200 million USD. The current status of the project is unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=SCISB00020120919e89j00007&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Academic Journal Article
donor_agency: China Sinopharm International Corporation , State-Owned Company

title: Hospital on the Island of Anjouan
description: On October 1, 2010, the Comoros Minister of Foreign Affairs said that the Chinese and Comoros governments exchanged letters for the construction of a referral hospital in Anjouan. On February 5, 2011 the Comoros authorities agreed on a site for a major hospital to be donated by China. The Chinese hospital will have a capacity of more than a hundred beds will be built on the island of Anjouan, for a cost of FC 2 billion (â‚¬4 million). Four years ago, Paris had planned to build a hospital on Anjouan in order to stem the flow of medical evacuations from the Comoros to the nearby French island of Mayotte, but the French eventually abandoned the plan. The work on the hospital officially started in May of 2012 in the village of Bambao on Anjouan.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=IOLET00020110309e72500007&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.beit-salam.km/article.php3?id_article=1121&var_recherche=chine, Other; http://www.beit-salam.km/article.php3?id_article=2074&var_recherche=chine, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.panapress.com/China-grants-Comoros-4.6-million-euro-for-hospital--13-751124-17-lang2-index.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Wang Leyou, Chinese Ambassador to Moroni

title: Hospital with equipment, instruments, and doctors
description: China Jiangsu Construction Development Company started construction in 2004 on the N'Djili Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital after a donation from the Chinese government. The hospital was officially handed over in a ceremony on June 6, 2006. The hospital was handed over complete with modern equipment, instruments, and a team of 18 doctors. The yearly cost of this equipment, medicine, and doctor salaries totals 50,000 euro per year. It covers an area of almost 8000 sq. meters, has 150 beds, and is designed to handle 400 patients at full capacity. The financial amount for this project is yet unknown.
sources: http://vlex.cn/vid/china-hands-over-hospital-to-congo-197731359, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://hiva.kuleuven.be/resources/docs/vorming/20111206_IgnacePollet.pdf, Other; http://www.ccs.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2010/03/ENGLISH-Evaluating-Chinas-FOCAC-commitments-to-Africa-2010.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

donor_agency: China Jiangsu International, State-Owned Company

title: Hospitals
description: On December 28, 2009, the Republic of the Congo received a 3.5 billion XAF donation from China to update their health facilities. The agreement was signed between Congolese Finance Minister Gilbert Ondongo and Chinese Ambassador Li Shuli. The Mfilou Hospital in the 7th Brazzaville district, the Landini Hospital in the Pointe Noire region, the TalangaÃ¯ hospital in the 6th Brazzaville district, and the Owando hospital in Cuvette were cited as some of the projects to have been completed by the Chinese government.
sources: http://congo-story.skyrock.com/609645706-Congo-Chine-un-modele-de-cooperation-Sud-Sud-Congo-China-a-model-of.html, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020091229e5ct001jl&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Housing Project in Guinea-Bissau
description: In a 2007 CSIS report, a Beijing-funded 1000-unit public housing project is referenced as being built. This possibly is connected to a 2004 news report that stated housing projects in Central African Republic, Algeria and Guinea-Bissau were all built with China's help. No dates or costs regarding the project could be found.
sources: http://www.macauhub.com.mo/en/2006/10/31/1975/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://csis.org/publication/guinea-bissau-china-sees-risk-worth-taking, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020040127e01r001l8&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Housing complex
description: In November of 2007, the Minister of Equipment Harouna, Mayor Abdoulaye Issa of Niamey Commune IV, and Governor of Niamey Tahirou Amadou gave speeches that referenced 'recent, ongoing, and future' projects. One of such projects was a housing complex. The commitment year for this project or whether it has been started yet are still unknown, but it may be related to a housing complex for staff built as part of a new embassy.
sources: http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=10NIAMEY120, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/subject/zhcjd/subjectd/201005/20100506925141.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://leaks.hohesc.us/?view=07NIAMEY1359, Other

title: Housing project
description: The handing-over ceremony for a housing project given as a gift by the Chinese government to Zanzibar happened on January 4, 2004. President Karume praised the Chinese for their support. The project includes four three-story residential buildings, one shop, one pump house, exterior roads, and fences, covering 3162 sq. meters. The total project cost was donated by the Chinese government. The financial value, start date, and commitment year for this project cannot be found.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020040104e0140012x&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Housing project and Greater Abuja Water Project
description: On December 30, 2009, Nigeria's Federal Capital Territory Administration (FCTA) Minister Adamu Aliero and Chinaâ€™s CGC Nigeria signed a Memorandum of Understanding worth 1 billion USD for the construction of houses and the distribution of water throughout the Federal Capital Territory (FCT), including Abuja. The two projects were due to commence in early 2010 and were planned to be financed through two commercial loans of 500 million USD to be obtained by CGC. Each loan was to be backed by FCT land as collateral. The mass housing project was planned to be carried out on a 1,212 hectare area of land near Gwarinpa Estate in Abuja and is expected to be provided with full infrastructure, including roads, electricity, water, and sewage among others. The water supply project will deal with the provision and extension of primary water lines in parts of the FCT including Lugbe and the Kuje regional water supply. Discussions between FCTA and CGC commenced in 2010 over the water supply project, but were not concluded until 2012. In 2012, CGC offered to execute the project at a cost of 575 million USD. If approved, the China Exim Bank would provide a loan facility for the majority of the cost, and the Nigerian Government would provide the rest in the form of counterpart funding. In 2012, FCTA Minister Senator Bala Muhammed directed CGC Nigeria Limited to produce a detailed feasibility study for the â€œGreater Abuja Water Projectâ€. When completed, the project would supply more than 60% of FCTAâ€™s 8,000 square km with potable water. The FCTA also announced that it would embark on the â€œGreater Abuja Water Projectâ€ through a Public Private Partnership with a Chinese company and the World Bank. The current status of the project is unknown.
sources: http://www.fct.gov.ng/index16_02_12p.html?option=com_content&view=article&id=286:fct-ministers-wife-reaffirms-support-for-the-needy&catid=:latest, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.businessdayonline.com/NG/index.php/news/latest/33269-chinese-company-tipped-for-abuja-water-project, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=PMPLUN0020091231e5cv000xf&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/gwarinpa-estate-residents-say-city-s-being-reduced-to-slum/125843/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://s3.amazonaws.com/china_resources/16062/2013-06-08_03_30_02_-0400_%3Fp%3D30, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: CGC Overseas Construction Co., Ltd. (CGCOC), State-Owned Company
donor_agency: CGC Overseas Construction Co., Ltd. (CGCOC), State-Owned Company

title: Hu cancels Cameroon debt
description: In 2007, Hu Jintao and his team, including Minister of Commerce Bo Xilai, Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing and other senior policy makers, signed eight accord with Cameroon, and cancelled Cameroon's debt to China-- whose value was not specified.
sources: http://politics.people.com.cn/GB/1026/5352525.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.reuters.com/article/2007/01/31/africa-china-idUSL3173715420070131, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Li Zhaoxing, ; Bo Xilai, ; Hu Jintao,

title: Hubei Province Agricultural Twinning
description: In mid-2007, Hubei province in China and Gaza province in Mozambique signed a twinning-agreement that stipulated ensuring rice production in an area of 300 hectares, modernizing farming infrastructure, sending agricultural experts, and building a canal. Reports have indicated that China agreed to send $800 million for agriculture, canals, dams, and experts, but it is unclear what portion of this amount is going specifically to the twinning agreement provisions. It is likely that a majority of those funds are represented in projects ID#1197 and ID#1215, The agreement was to develop 300 hectares to demonstrate irrigated rice, but as of 2009/2010, only about 35-40 hectares had been developed, and an application for more land has been placed.
sources: http://www.chinaafricarealstory.com/2012/01/zambezi-valley-chinas-first.html, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/ian-birrell-this-massive-invasion-will-benefit-the-continent-1802828.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/201112272506.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.macauhub.com.mo/en/2010/05/14/9086/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinafrica.asia/china-shows-substantial-interest-in-african-agriculture/, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Global-Issues/2009/1231/Africa-from-famine-to-the-world-s-next-breadbasket, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/world/2011-09/19/c_131147121.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Vasco Lino, Ministry for Science and Technology

title: Human Resources Development Loan
description: On December 7, 2006, the Chinese government granted Mauritius 5 million CNY to be utilized for projects related to human resource development and other projects to be mutually decided with the Human Resources Department. The projects funded with this grant have yet to be identified.
sources: http://dspace.cigilibrary.org/jspui/bitstream/123456789/32406/1/MauritiusInvestmentRelations.pdf?1, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy

title: Human resource development and capacity building
description: On November 25, 2002, the Ethiopian minister of state for finance and economic development, Mekonen Manyazewal, and the Chinese vice foreign minister signed a 10 million birr agreement for cooperation in human resource development and capacity building. The statuses of the projects are uncertain.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcap00020021125dybp0053d&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Humanitarian Aid
description: On October 31, 2007, China signed an agreement in Kenya to provide $1.5 million in aid to Somalia. The agreement was signed by Somali President Abdullahi Yusuf and Chinese Ambassador in Kenya, Zhang Ming. It includes $500,000 in humanitarian aid.The status of the projects is uncertain.
sources: http://www.hiiraan.com/news4/2007/sept/4146/china_provides_aid_to_somalia.aspx, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Humanitarian Aid
description: On March 24, 2009, Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister Zhai Jun donated humanitarian aid for refugees in the DRC worth 4 million RMB. The agreement was signed between Zhai and his DRCongolese counterpart Ignace Gata Mavita. The exact start and end dates for projects associated with this donation are yet unknown.
sources: http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2009-03/24/content_7610892.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Humanitarian Aid for Flood
description: On January 12, 2006, China's foreign minister, Li Zhaoxing, visited Senegal and gave $200,000 in humanitarian aid for victims of a recent flood that damaged thousands of homes in the Dakar area in September 2005. The current status of this project cannot be found.
sources: http://news.sohu.com/20060113/n241425418.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LBA0000020060112e21c00213&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Humanitarian aid
description: On March 20, 2011, China's Ministry of Commerce decided to offer 1 million USD in emergency humanitarian aid to Egypt to alleviate issues caused by Libyan refugees in the country. The start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=UMCIN00020110320e73k00002&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Humanitarian aid for Darfur
description: On August 16, 2007, the fourth of five batches of humanitarian aid from China to Sudan for humanitarian aid for Darfur was shipped out of Tianjin. The batch included pumps, tents and blankets, and was worth 20 million CNY. The date of the commitment for the aid and the actual end date are unknown. This is the fourth of five bunches of humanitarian aid that China gave to Sudan for Darfur since 2004. (See Project ID#14113, Project ID#2164, Project ID#1575, and Project ID#2288)
sources: http://www.gov.cn/misc/2007-08/16/content_719116.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Humanitarian aid grant for Darfur
description: On August 16, 2004 in Khartoum, Sudan, China's Assistant Foreign Minister Lu Guozeng met with Sudanese President Umar al-Bashir and pledged to offer Sudan 5 million CNY in humanitarian aid for Darfur. The current status and start and end dates of the grant are unknown.This may be part of five bundles of humanitarian aid that China gave to Sudan for Darfur since 2004. (See Project ID#14113, Project ID#1575, Project ID#2405, and Project ID#2288)
sources: http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:http://kms1.isn.ethz.ch/serviceengine/Files/ISN/98943/ipublicationdocument_singledocument/d304424f-0db4-47b0-a87c-dc1f1e76e44b/en/PAPER158.pdf, Other; http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-13018476_ITM, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Humanitarian aid to Darfur
description: On June 1, 2009 in Khartoum, Sudan, the Chinese special envoy for Sudan for the Darfur issue, Liu Guijin, met today with the Sudanese President Omer Al-Bashir to attend the signing ceremony of a humanitarian aid grant for the three states of Darfur of 20 million CNY. The aid agreement was signed by Sudan's State Minister at the Ministry of International Cooperation, Elias Niamlel, and the Chinese Ambassador to Sudan, in the presence of Liu Guijin. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article31358, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCMEP0020090531e55v0040h&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Humanitarian aid to alleviate pressure of refugees
description: In April 2011, China sent $4.6 million worth of in-kind humanitarian assistance to Tunisia, including 1,500 tents, 22 tonnes of medicine, 1,000 sets of solar-powered lights, 23,000 blankets, some 25 tonnes of food. China also sent 2 million US dollars in cash, presumably to Tunisia's National Defense Ministry (see end of last source). This assistance is aimed to alleviate the pressure of refugees from Tunisia's neighbor, Libya. The supplies were flown to the island of Djerba from Beijing. The first batch of materials was sent on April 7th, and the second batch was shipped on April 9th.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AGETAP0020110425e74l00011&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/newsrelease/significantnews/201104/20110407488611.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://english.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/newsrelease/significantnews/201104/20110407491174.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90776/90883/7343816.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=UMCIN00020110320e73k00002&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020110410e74a000dy&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=PAKBNK0020110409e749000b8&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020110318e73i0038q&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pm.gov.tn/pm/actualites/actualite.php?id=3253&lang=ar, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
donor_agency: China Ministry of Commerce, Government Agency
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AGETAP0020110425e74l00011&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=UMCIN00020110320e73k00002&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020110410e74a000dy&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=PAKBNK0020110409e749000b8&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020110318e73i0038q&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Humanitarian aid to cyclone victims
description: On March 16, 2004, the Chinese government provided humanitarian aid to Madagascar, which was hit by a tropical cyclone earlier in March. The supplies included eight tons of rice, 300 blankets, 300 mosquito nets, 300 boxes of candles, and 200 boxes of soap.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020040317e03h00106&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Hydroelectric Dam in Port Loko
description: In 2009, China agreed to construct a dam in Port Loko in Sierra Leone, about 75 miles from the capital Freetown. It appears that construction may have started, according to a news report. It is possible this is not the same project, but it looks to be so. Construction started in April of 2012.
sources: http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/38039, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LBA0000020090519e55j000xl&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: O. Robber-Coker, ; Martin Bash Kamara, ; Dr. Kandeh Yumkella,

title: Hydropower Dam
description: In 2006, China upgraded a hydropower dam in Guinea. The Kinkon Dam at Pita, about 400 km from Conakry, was upgraded for $2.5 million USD and increased its capacity from 3.0 mW to 3.4 mW. It is unclear what companies were responsible for the rehabilitation and when construction started and completed. There is some confusion as to an update from 2011, indicating that other construction was taking place.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-254003550/guinean-website-assesses-ties.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.becgc.net/chinese/show.php?itemid=106, Other; http://uk.reuters.com/article/2006/07/19/idUKL1962913520060719, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: ICT Training Course
description: On November 26, 2009, China provided the Mauritian Central Informatics Bureau with a training course on Information Technology at the Shanghai Internet Economy Consulting Center. The value for this project is unknown.
sources: http://www.gov.mu/portal/goc/treasury/file/annual09d/STATU.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
implementing_agency: Shanghai Internet Economy Consulting Center, Academic, Training and Research
donor_agency: Shanghai Internet Economy Consulting Center, Academic, Training and Research
recipient_agencies: Mauritius Central Informatics Bureau, Government Agency

title: IT Human Resources Training
description: On September 28, 2009, the Chinese government held a handing-over ceremony for an Information Technology human resources training project. The Chinese government handed over 7 sets of video-phone equipment and trained 40 Batswana. The financial value for this donation is unknown.
sources: http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/chn/gxh/tyb/zwbd/t615971.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Ideological Schools
description: Following a tour of China in September 2006, the CCP (Chinese Communist Party) agreed to provide financial and technical assistance to the ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM, Revolutionary Party) in order to build two ideological colleges in Iringa and Tunguu in Zanzibar. The colleges would be used to mould outstanding cadres for the CCM, with courses of study ranging between three and one years. It is likely that the school in Tunguu is the new campus for the State University of Zanizbar (SUZA) to be completed by the end of 2011 referenced in the CCM education document, but no references could be found for the school in Iringa (although it is likely in Dar es Salaam). The current status of this project is yet unknown.
sources: http://planipolis.iiep.unesco.org/upload/Tanzania%252520UR/Zanzibar/Zanzibar_ZEDP_2007.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020060914e29e003xq&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Chama Cha Mapinduzi Party, Political Party
recipient_agencies: Chama Cha Mapinduzi Party, Political Party

title: Imboulou Dam
description: In January of 2004, the China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation (CMEC) started work on a 120 mw dam to supply power to Brazzaville. The total project cost was estimated at $280 million for the dam, and construction was expected to be completed in 2009. Seller's credits of $238 million were provided by the Export Import Bank of China to the China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corp. A PPIAF consultant said that this loan was backed by oil guarantees. On May 7, 2011, the dam was finally inaugurated by the president, Denis Sassou Nguesso. In the end, the project cost $340 million to complete, which included a 60 km access road and workers housing. PPIAF-ID:84
sources: http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=48941&oldaction=liste&regpay_id=0%252525252525252520&them_id=0&cat_id=4&ss_cat_id=15&LISTE_FROM=0&select_month=05&select_year=2011, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.china5e.com/show.php?contentid=72683, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mbendi.com/indy/powr/af/co/p0005.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://cg.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200304/20030400079454.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=EIUBF00020040131e01g0000d&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agency: China National Machinery and Equipment Import & Export Corporation, State-Owned Company
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency; China National Machinery and Equipment Import & Export Corporation, State-Owned Company

title: Implementation program under cultural agreement
description: In 2004, China and Namibia signed an implementation program under a cultural agreement. It is unclear what the terms of the cultural agreement are and how the program will be implemented.
sources: http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200702/06/eng20070206_347748.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Increase in Grant for Development Projects
description: In December 2011, a signing ceremony was held for an economic and technical cooperation agreement between Lesotho and China. According to the agreement, China would increase their development aid and interest-free loans from 10,000,000 ZAR to 15,000,000 ZAR, with most of the increase going to fund highways in eastern Lesotho to KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa. An updated status on this project cannot be found.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=sapa000020011212dxca00193&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Increased number of student scholarships
description: In President Mugabe's visit to China in July of 2005, China increased the number of scholarships given to the Zimbabwean students by eight. In 2004, eleven students had been studying in China, so the expectation was that up to 19 scholarships would be given out in 2005. Information regarding the completion of this commitment, the amount these scholarships cost, and contact information are still unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020050727e17r0018i&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinaembassy.org.zw/chn//xwdt/t365264.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Information Exchange
description: On June 22, 2010, Morocco and China signed an agreement to reinforce bilateral cooperation in the cultural field. Under the three-year agreement, the two contries will consolidate cooperation in the fields of culture, publishing, education, and Islamic affairs. China will grant 15 scholarships to Moroccan students, while Morocco will grant 10 scholarships to Chinese students. (ID#2063) They also agreed to exchange expertise and information in the field of historical sites rehabilitation, and consolidate cooperation between Morocco's Institute of Archaeological Sciences and Heritage and equivalent Chinese institutions.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AGEMAP0020100623e66m00004&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: National Institute of Archaeological Sciences and Heritage, Foundation
recipient_agencies: National Institute of Archaeological Sciences and Heritage, Foundation

title: Information and Communications Technology cooperation agreement
description: In 2002, South African and China signed an Information and Communications Technology (ICT) cooperation agreement. The agreement, signed by Communications Minister Ivy Matsepe-Casaburri and the Peoples Republic of China's Information and Industry minister Wu Jichuan at a Cape Town ceremony, entails sharing expertise on various ICT areas. This includes an exchange of information on satellite and other communications networks, human resource development and radio frequency spectrum management tools such as computer assistance. The department said the parties further agreed on forming a separate training agreement to ensure co-operation in human resource development, training, and research and development. It is unclear how the agreement was implemented.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=sapa000020020919dy9j002sa&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.topsage.com/english/2010/0225/abroad_14819.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Information and Computer Technology Facilities for Interior Ministry
description: On November 27, 2008, the government of China donated $1.5 million worth of computer equipment to the Tanzanian Ministry of Home Affairs. The donation given by China's Deputy Minister for Public Security, Cai Anji, and to the Ministry of Home Affairs Deputy Minister, Khamis Kagasheki, consisted of 50 desktop computers, 30 laptops, scanners, and digital cameras.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020081129e4bt0028m&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Cai Anji, Deputy Minister ; Khamis Kagasheki, Deputy Minister

title: Infrastructure Grant
description: On November 21, 2003, China announced a grant of 3 billion XAF to the Republic of the Congo with the purpose of rebuilding the county's war-torn infrastructure. Chinese ambassador Wo Ruidi was quoted as saying that a Chinese team was in the country evaluating the construction needs. The projects funded with this grant and their statuses are yet unknown.May be connected with ID#447 and ID#23762.
sources: http://www.irinnews.org/printreport.aspx?reportid=47380, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: Infrastructure Grant including Bukavu highway
description: In 2006, China granted $4.5 million US dollars of aid to the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The money was meant to improve the infrastructure in the country. It was based on a pledge at the Forum on Sino-Africa Cooperation Summit in which Beijing promised to double its aid to Africa by 2009. The projects included highway construction in Bukavu and other infrastructure projects. The China Communications Construction Company (CCCC) is the contractor on the Kavumu Airport Road, which is financed by this donation. The road, when finished, will connect Bukavu to the Kavumu airport, and will stretch 35 km long. The work was launched in Bukavu on May 26, 2008, and the most recently found status is implementation as of January 2010. The current status is yet unknown.
sources: http://www.skyscrapercity.com/showthread.php?t=958428, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://www.ccs.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2010/03/ENGLISH-Evaluating-Chinas-FOCAC-commitments-to-Africa-2010.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://kaifangzhan.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/g/i/200902/20090206028952.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=DJI0000020061114e2be001in&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: China Communications Construction Co., Ltd. (CCCC), State-Owned Company
donor_agency: China Communications Construction Co., Ltd. (CCCC), State-Owned Company

title: Infrastructure Improvement through technical, economic cooperation
description: On January 17, 2006 China signed an agreement with Guinea-Bissau on economic and technical cooperation. The agreement was signed in Bissau by China's Ambassador to Guinea-Bissau Tian Guangfeng and the African nation's Secretary of State for International Cooperation, Tibna Sambe Nawana. The cooperation programs included in the agreement will help improve Guinea-Bissau's infrastructure. Under the agreement, the Chinese government will assist the African country in several programs, including the rebuilding of a hospital. Likely referiring to one of these hospital projects ID#745 or ID#882
sources: http://vlex.cn/vid/signs-technical-agreement-guinea-bissau-197483327, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Infrastructure development
description: On October 16, 2009 Chinese Premier Wen Jinbao announced that the Chinese Government had given Kenya 600 million Kenyan shillings to fund the development of infrastructure. The infrastructure projects would be determined based on a list of priority projects given by the Kenyan government. The amount would come in addition to the Sh1.08 billion given to Kenya by his government for the expansion of Thika Road. Present at the talks for the agreement were the Kenyan Prime minister and Kenyan ministers Franklin Bett, Amos Kimunya and Chris Obure, as well as assistant Minister Charles Keter. Unfortunately, research did not reveal further information about the infrastructure funds. It seems likely that the funding supported infrastructure projects already included in this database, possibly projects #16960 #16202 #1267 #1279 #16392 #1265 #16115 and #1285.
sources: http://www.statehousekenya.go.ke/news/oct09/2009061001.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://news.0513.org/html/44/n-233744.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020091016e5ag001cs&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Raila Odinga, ; Premier Wen Jiabao, ; Hon. Christopher Mogere Obure, EGH, M.P., ; Franklin Bett, ; Charles Keter, ; Amos Kimunya ,

title: Infrastructure for mines barter deal (Sicomines): 2008-2012
description: On September 17, 2007, China and the Democratic Republic of the Congo signed an agreement for a 9 billion USD loan deal from the Exim Bank of China. However, the loan was reduced to 6 billion USD in October 2009 because the IMF expressed concerns over the DRCâ€™s national debt. The loan was meant to improve Congolese infrastructure and to develop mines in the Mashamba basin, the Dima basin, the Dik Colline D syncline, and Kolwezi. In return, the Congolese state copper company GÃ©camines would concede a number of deposits containing up to 10.6 million tonnes of copper, of which approximately 6.8 million tonnes were confirmed. GÃ©camines also promised between 425,000 and 625,000 tonnes of cobalt and access to all other potential mineral substances. The loanâ€™s infrastructure component totaled 3 billion USD at a 4.4% interest rate. Sicomines Mining Joint Ventureâ€™s loan for developing mines includes a 2.13 billion USD loan at 6.1% interest and a 1.07 billion USD loan at 0% interest. Although the project was originally owned by Sinohydro Corporation (25% share), China Railway Engineering Corporation (CREC) (43% share), and GÃ©camines (32% share), the CRECâ€™s investment is currently resting on an appeal to the China's National People's Congress Standing Committee. As of May 2013, Chinese enterprises owned 62%, and the rest belonged to GÃ©camines. The Congolese Infrastructure Minister Pierre Lumbi reported that 3 billion USD will be spent on infrastructure, including 2,000 miles of railway between Sakania and Matadi, a 2,000-mile road linking Kisanganiand and Kasumbalesa, a motorway between Lubumbashi and Kasumbalesa, 31 hospitals, 145 health centers, two international-standard universities, and 5,000 government housing units. The motorway between Lubumbashi and Kasumbalesa was constructed by the CREC between March and November 2008, totaling 72 km of road. The transportation projects were planned to be completed within 36 months. As of March 2013, 458 million USD have been released for infrastructure projects, and 540 million USD have been disbursed toward the mining operation. Of the 540 million USD, 350 million USD were used for a signing bonus, the rest for feasibility studies. The initial deal promised to provide China with copper and cobalt over the next 25 years. There are reportedly a total of 13 infrastructure projects implemented with the 458 million USD disbursed under the Sicomines agreement between 2008 and 2012: 1. Refurbishment of 5.3 km of Boulevard du 30 juin, Kinshasa. Status: completed. Cost: 24.1 million USD. 2. Refurbishment of 2.5 km of Boulevard du 30 juin, Kinshasa. Status: completed. Cost: 19.3 million USD. 3. Refurbishment of Esplanade of the People's Palace, Kinshasa. Status: completed. Cost: 19.7 million USD. 4. Refurbishment of 7.25 km of Avenue du Tourisme, Kinshasa. Status: completed. Cost: 24.3 million USD. 5. Refurbishment of 4.3 km of Boulevards Triomphale et Sendwe, Kinshasa. Status: completed. Cost 29.2 million USD. 6. Construction of a 450 bed hospital, Kinshasa. Status: completed. Cost: 99.9 million USD. 7. Refurbishment of Lutendele road, Kinshasa. Status: implementation. Cost: $21 million. 8. Refurbishment of 66 km of Beni-Luna road, North Kivu. Status: completed. Cost: 57.8 million USD. 9. Grading of 137 km of national road between Lubumbashi and Kasomeno, Katanga province. Status: completed. Cost: 50.5 million USD. 10. Asphalting of national road between Lubumbashi and Kasomeno, Katanga province. Status: implementation. Cost: 87.5 million USD. 11. Donation of solar panels by Sinohydro. Status: completed. Cost: 11 million USD. 12. Donation of generators. Status: implementation. Cost: 6.5 million USD. 13. Factory to build prefabricated houses, Kisangani. Status: implementation. Cost: 7.5 million USD. The loanâ€™s ODA-like nature is disputed. Deborah Brautigam argues that despite changes to Exim Bank's variable interest rate of the above-mentioned loan, the deal should still not be counted as ODA. Johanna Janson argued that because the interest rate of Exim Bank's loan fell from 6.6% to 4.4% in a 2009 revised loan agreement, the deal should be labeled as ODA as the IMF- and OECD-calculated grant elements would rise to at least 42%. This fluctuation in the interest rate was included in the deal signed between the consortium of companies, not the Exim Bank. The initial interest rate was set at set at LIBOR plus 100 basis points. The Chinese companies are responsible for paying the difference between the 6.6% and 4.4% interest rates.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=WDAN000020070918e39i00031&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sarwatch.org/component/content/article/126-headline-news-for-the-drc/258-china-eyes-congos-treasures-.html, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.ccs.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2010/03/ENGLISH-Evaluating-Chinas-FOCAC-commitments-to-Africa-2010.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://news.hexun.com/2008-04-23/105493340.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; title: Infrastructure in exchange for preferential oil right bidding
description: On April 26, 2006, Chinese President Hu Jintao and Nigerian President Olusegu Obasanjo signed an agreement to exchange four oil drilling licenses with China for a commitment of $4 billion in infrastructure. Under this agreement, Nigeria will grant China the first right of refusal to China National Petroleum Corp. (CNPC) on four oil exploration blocks at an auction next month.China wanted to buy a controlling stake in Nigeria's 110,000 barrel/day Kaduna oil refinery and reconstruct Kaduna's facilities for $2 billion. However, in 2007 China failed to win the auction for Kaduna's stakes. The status of the power station is currently undetermined. The status of the promised infrastructure is unknown.STAFF_NOTES: This oil deal may be connected to an earlier (inactive) $7 billion export credit guarantee by SINOSURE in 2004 (ID#1542). Update: The are three projects attached to this initial agreement as part of Nigeria's 'oil for infrastructure' plan. The 1315 Lagos-Kano section railway, the rehabilitation of the Kaduna oil refinery, and the building of the Mambilla hydroelectric power station. All three projects were put on hold in 2007 after Musa Yar'Adua came into power. These projects are listed under 195, 1999, 1818, and 1990. The Mambilla hydroelectric plant is back under way (1990). A Nigerian news source stated that a Japanese company, Chiyoda Corporation, is rehabilitating the Kaduna refinery. A Chinese firm, Messrs China Civil Engineering Construction Company Nig Ltd, is rehabilitating the railway. This portion is worth approximately $1.487 billion USD with a construction period of 36 months starting in mid 2012 (see project 195).
sources: http://www.jamestown.org/programs/chinabrief/single/?tx_ttnews%25252525252525252525255Btt_news%25252525252525252525255D=4197&tx_ttnews%25252525252525252525255BbackPid%25252525252525252525255D=197&no_cache=1, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LBA0000020060426e24q000tz&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.google.co.za/#output=search&sclient=psy-ab&q=4+billion+China+Nigeria+Infrastructure+oil+2006&oq=4+billion+China+Nigeria+Infrastructure+oil+2006&gs_l=hp.3...336624.405497.0.405672.63.53.7.0.0.0.295.4538.31j13j3.47.0...0.0...1c.1.18.psy-ab.BB9ZQNdErQM&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_qf.&bvm=bv.48572450,d.dmQ&fp=18c4154a0af92d76&biw=1185&bih=726, Academic Journal Article; http://newnigerianews.blogspot.com/2013/03/fg-to-rehabilitate-kaduna-port-harcourt.html, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; allafrica.com/stories/201207190156.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.eastday.com/eastday/node81741/node81762/node132242/userobject1ai2006227.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Infrastructure loan
description: In 2003, the Chinese government granted a loan to Angola worth roughly $300 million USD to be used in the rehabilitation of railway, electrical energy network, drinking water system and other areas. It is unclear exactly how the funds were used. Further details on the loan are unclear.
sources: http://www.sadocc.at/news/2004-173.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://business.sohu.com/20060321/n242398146.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Infrastructure projects- overlaps/includes 1544
description: On Dec 31, 2010 Mali Finance Minister Sanoussi Toure signed agreements for 103.2 billion CFA francs in loans from China to finance road, bridge and telecoms projects. Reports state that the money would be used to finance infrastructure projects. These projects include work on the Bamako-Segou Highway, listed as project #1554. (Note: there is likely an overlap in the numbers given for funding of this umbrella project and the project for the bridge along, and determining the exact amount that went to each project should be further explored in future searches.) Another project, a bridge in Bamako, has already completed construction in September 2011, and been dubbd the China Mali friendship bridge. Searches for the listed feasibility study for a University in Kabala and a fibre optic communications upgrade both do not show any updated results.
sources: http://wadr.org/en/site/news_en/2039/Mali-China-bridge-opened-in-Bamako.htm, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/12/31/mali-china-loan-idAFLDE6BU0DW20101231, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gzbgj.com/english/article.aspx?menuid=1385&tab=tab_e&tabid=1207, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
location_details: Road: Bamako-Segou, bridge: Bamako, University in Kabala

title: Installation and commissioning of Global Open Trunking Architecture (GOTA) security communications
description: The Chinese government pledged $5 million for ZTE to set up and commission a global open trunking architecture in Nigeria. The status of this agreement is uncertain.
sources: http://www.tradeinvestnigeria.com/news/637633.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://publications.worldbank.org/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=22946, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

donor_agency: Zhongxing Technologies (ZTE), State-Owned Company

title: Installation of generators
description: In a speech on September 26, 2012, Ambassador of China Wang Leyou mentioned that the installation of generators would start soon in Comoros. The ambassador said the generators were given to compensate for the lack of energy supply in the country. STAFF_NOTE: Unable to find additional sources confirming this project.
sources: http://www.beit-salam.km/article.php3?id_article=1797&var_recherche=chine, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.beit-salam.km/article.php3?id_article=2074&var_recherche=chine, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Installation of solar panels in Tunisian ports
description: In 2012, China agreed to fund the installation of solar panels in Tunisian ports that will provide lighting to marinas. This project was signed at the same time as ID #30329 and ID #30323
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120229e82t0008s&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.embassyoftunisia.com/index.php?id=7&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=90&cHash=054b9a0c39a4f2c8820c11db2cf983b7, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Hedi Ben Abbes, Secretary of State for the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Americas and Asian division

title: Installation of solar traffic lights
description: On March 30, 2011 Liberia's Minister of Foreign Affairs Toga Gayewea Mcintosh signed an Exchange of Notes on behalf of the Government of the Republic of Liberia with the Vice Minister of Commerce Fu Ziyang, for the installation of solar traffic lights throughout the City of Monrovia. By January 24, 2013 the second of 19 lights had been installed, with installation of the remaining 17 expected over the next month.
sources: http://tnrliberia.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=293:monrovia-gets-solar-traffic-lights-soon&catid=64:general&Itemid=49, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.coema.org.cn/oenews/industry/20091012/213633.html, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://allafrica.com/stories/201103310858.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.inprofiledaily.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7065:chinese-company-clarifies-delay-in-solar-system-traffic-lights-project-&catid=1:headlines&Itemid=56, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020130124e91o000q3&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Interest Free Loan for Hospital
description: In May 2001, a Chinese economic and trade delegation signed economic accords on cooperation and debt reduction with the Angolan government during a three-day visit to Luanda. The Chinese government extended an interest-free line of credit totaling about $6 million. Angola's Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, George Chicoty, signed the agreements with China's Vice Minister of External Trade and Economic Cooperation, Zhang Xiang. It was inaugurated in February 2006. A Deborah Brautigam China in Africa blogpost from April 21, 2011, stated that 'The decision to build the 100-bed $8 million Luanda General Hospital was made in 2002, and after tenders in China, COVEC won the bid and constructed the building between July 2004 and February 2006.' Moreover, after cracks developed in the walls of the hospital in 2010, Brautigam wrote that officials from China and Angola met for several rounds of talks. 'The Chinese side will build some temporary wards and sewage systems for patients to ensure the operation of the hospital. Then the maintenance work and expansion of the hospital will begin.' The Chinese government will finance the new construction.'
sources: http://repository.up.ac.za/bitstream/handle/2263/17253/Kiala_China(2010).pdf?sequence=1, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020040528e05s00105&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcae00020010710dx5o000dk&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=afnws00020021107dx6s01wmb&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinaafricarealstory.com/2011/04/chinese-aid-and-luanda-general-hospital.html, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs

title: Interest Free Loan for Social Housing Project (linked to Project ID#30570)
description: On February 15, 2012, China and Cape Verde signed an agreement for a 12 million USD interest-free loan as part of a 63 million USD project to construct 1,600 social housing units for 6,500 citizens. The Cape Verdean Foreign Ministry highlighted the Chinese governmentâ€™s positive response to the request by Cape Verdeâ€™s government for special project financing conditions, combining a subsidised loan with another interest-free one so that the state treasury is not burdened during the amortisation phase. Cape Verde's Ambassador to China, JÃºlio Morais, and vice-director general of the Subsidised Loan Department of the Export Import Bank of China, Wang Fade, signed the loan agreement on behalf of their respective government.

title: Interest free loan
description: In 2006, China granted one million euros in an interest-free loan to the Ivory Coast. The Ivorian Foreign Affairs Minister, Youssouf Bakayoko was present at the signing. It is unclear how the funds were used, but the project appears to be untied. This loan comes along with debt cancellation and a grant from the Chinese.

title: Interest free loan for construction of food research facility
description: On January 18, 2001, Ugandan Vice President Wandira Specioza Kazibwe and current Chinese Vice President Hu Jintao signed an agreement for China to extend 40 million USD in interest-free loans and grants for the construction of a food research facility in Kampala, Uganda. The exact terms of the loan, the current status, and the start and end dates of the project are unknown.

title: Interest free loan for economic and technical cooperation
description: In 2006, China agreed to provide Ghana with an interest-free loan worth $4 million USD for economic and technical cooperation. It is unclear how the funds were used. The project does not appear to be tied.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-147813393/ghana-china-sign-socio.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Interest-Free Development Loan
description: On May 24, 2001, Chinese deputy economy minister Zhang Xiang signed an agreement that included, among other things, an interest-free loan of 3 billion XAF slated for development. The projects financed with this loan have yet to be determined.The other part of this same agreement is ID#334
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=lba0000020010712dx5p02y3r&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Interest-Free Loan
description: The Chinese government has decided to grant Angola a new loan worth 50 million yens, approximately 6.3m dollars, interest free, with a view to strengthening bilateral relations. The agreement was signed by Chinese Vice-Premier Zeng Peiyan and Angolan Prime Minister Fernando da Piedade Dias dos Santos. One source reported that the agreements were oil related and to be used for 'technical projects.'
