recipient_agencies: Ethiopia Revenue and Customs Authority, Government Agency
contacts: Chen Deming, ; Gu Xiaojie, ; Sufyan Ahmed,

title: Loan for development projects
description: On April 18, 2011, China agreed to provide 80 million CNY in loans and grants to Ethiopia. The grant is for 50 million CNY, and loan is for 30 million CNY. The deal was signed in the Ethiopian capital between China's Vice Minister of Commerce Fu Ziying and Ahmed Shide, Ethiopia's state minister for finance and economic development. The money is designated for five projects: feasibility study for hydroelectric dams, potable water project, bio-gas energy, solar energy, and a malaria prevention program. The grant component of the project can be found under Project #30552.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LBA0000020110418e74i001e1&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ertagov.com/en/etv-programs/313-meles-holds-talks-with-chinese-vice-minister-of-commerce-.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofed.gov.et/English/Resources/Documents/Public%20Sector%20Debt%20Statistical%20Bulletin%20-%20No.7%20(2006-07%20-%202010-11).pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/i/jyjl/k/201104/20110407512622.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://english.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zt_fuva/lanmua/201104/20110407516572.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Ahmed Shide, Minister for Finance and Economic Development ; Fu Ziyang, Vice Minister (China Ministry of Commerce)

title: Loan for development projects
description: On June 23, 2006 the Tanzanian Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation and China's Minister of Trade Bo Xilai signed a loan agreement of about 80 million yuan to assist in the implementation of different projects in the country. Although unclear, this likely is a duplicate or suspended, as no further information can be found about the project, including in lists of other projects undertaken and agreements signed.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-147815770/china-gives-tanzania-10m.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan for development projects
description: On September 21, 2011, during a visit for the inauguration of a bridge built in Bamako, the Chinese Assistant Minister of Commerce Yu Jiahua signed an agreement with Mali's Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation Soumeylou Maiga BoubÃ¨ye. One portion of the agreement was an interest-free loan worth 3.6 billion CFA francs (XOF). The total agreement was worth more than 54 billion CFA francs. The loan was projected to be used to finance projects identified by the Malian government to improve the population's living conditions. At the same time, the ministers signed two other agreements. The first was a grant agreement for development projects amounting to 70 million CNY (See Project #30613) and the second was a concessional loan for 619 million CNY for the construction of a hydroelectric plant (See Project #30225).
sources: http://www.primature.gov.ml/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7648:cooperation-mali-chine-bonification-continue&catid=19&Itemid=100092, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.thechinatimes.com/online/2011/09/1325.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Yu Jiahua, Assistant Minister of Commerce (China Ministry of Commerce); Soumeylou Maiga BoubÃ¨ye , Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation

title: Loan for e-governance and national backbone infrastructure
description: (PPIAF-ID:298) On January 13, 2009, Ugandan Minister of Foreign Affairs Sam Kutesa and Chinese Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi signed an agreement for a concessional loan for the construction of a country-wide e-governance project. The project was delayed in January, 2010 after the completion of Phase I of the three stage project when the project was projected to cost substantially more than the initial 60 million USD and following allegations of fraud and mismanagement by the project implementer, Huawei Technologies. After establishing the National Information Technology Authority Uganda (NITA-U) to oversee the implementation of Phases II and III, the project was continued with a cost of 106 million USD, which was funded by concessional loans from the China Exim Bank to be repaid within 20 years. By February 7, 2011, Phases I and II of the project had been completed and operationalized, and Phase III was slated to begin work soon. The first two phases cost US$91 million with 30m spent on Phase 1 and 61m spent on Phase 2. The last phase would begin once EXIM Bank released the final funds.
sources: http://nita.go.ug/index.php/news/latest-news/136-government-launches-national-data-transmission-backbone-infrastructure-and-electronic-government-infrastructure-nbiegi, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www3.fmprc.gov.cn/chn/pds/gjhdq/gj/fz/1206_45_7/1206x2/t438655.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://publications.worldbank.org/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=22946, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAP00020070705e375000gp&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://isiafrica.net/?p=850, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90776/90883/6573470.pdf, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://opm.go.ug/manage/pdfs2013/GAPR2011_12V1.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

contacts: Mr Yang Jiechi, Chinese Foreign Minister ; Sam Kutesa, Minister of Foreign Affairs ; James Saaka,

title: Loan for economic and technical cooperation
description: In 2010, China provided a 70 million CNY loan to Mali. This was recorded in a document on budget programs: 'Agreements for Economic and Technical Cooperation between the Government of the Republic of Mali and the Government of the People's Republic of China'.
sources: http://www.finances.gouv.ml/loi_des_finances_2012/docs/bp_realis.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.sourcejuice.com/1412904/2010/12/31/Economic-technological-cooperation-between-China-Mali-Bamako-other-agreements/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://i.ifeng.com/video/news?aid=10222428, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan for energy and construction of hospitals and water treatment plants
description: On July 7, 2012 Angola and China Exim Bank signed 17 loan agreements totaling over 500 million USD to be used for the construction of hospitals, energy, and water treatment plants across eight of the country's provinces.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020120707e877006en&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.macauhub.com.mo/en/2012/07/09/angola-takes-out-us500-million-in-loans-from-china-exim-bank/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.angolahub.com/index.php/en/angola-news/1202-angola-contraiu-500-milhoes-de-dolares-em-emprestimos-junto-do-banco-exim-da-china, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan for extension for electrification
description: In a line itemized budget from the Ghanaian government in 2013, the state-owned China International Water & Electric Corporation was listed as signing a non-concessional loan with Ghana for the extension of electrification in the Upper Western region of the country. The loan was signed on February 9, 2012 and included provisions of a 15 year maturity with 5 year grace period, Libor plus .8% interest rate, and a total amount of 162 million USD. No information on when the project started was included in the report. This may be an update for Project #151, but the details are slightly different making it unclear. STAFF_NOTE: May be related to Project ID #2027.
sources: http://www.mofep.gov.gh/sites/default/files/budget/2013_Budget_Appendix_Tables.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mofep.gov.gh/?q=news/151211_2, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mofep.gov.gh/sites/default/files/news/2011_Annual_Progress_Report.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://english.cwe.cn/show.aspx?id=1931&cid=74, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: Loan for fiber optics and telecommunications modernization
description: In February 2011, the Malian Council of Ministers adopted a bill authorizing a loan agreement between Mali and China's Exim Bank. The concessional loan, worth 276.8 million CNY, will finance Mali's fiber optics and telecommunications modernization project. The project will include the supply and installation of approximately 942 km of fiber optics in Bamako, Gao, Tin ZaouatÃ¨ne, Ansongo, and Labezanga. Applications will be transmitted and surveilled from monitoring systems in Bamako and Kidal. The loan will also finance a video conferencing system, a Trustar system, and a data center in Bamako. STAFF_NOTE: Possibly referenced in Project ID #1544.
sources: http://www.primature.gov.ml/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=6877:communique-du-conseil-des-ministres-du-mercredi-18-mai-2011&catid=79:les-communiques, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.primature.gov.ml/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7167:assemblee-nationale-plus-de-20-milliards-de-francs-pour-pres-de-950-km-de-fibre-optique&catid=39:ministere-charge-des-relations-avec-les-institutions-&Itemid=100134, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.primature.gov.ml/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5967:cooperation-mali-chine-un-financement-de-103-milliards-fcfa&catid=19&Itemid=100092, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
location_details: Bamako, Gao, Tin ZaouatÃ¨ne, Ansongo, and Labezanga

title: Loan for infrastructure
description: In 2008, China offered Nigeria a 2.5 billion USD loan for rail, power, or telecommunications projects. The terms of the loan and the status of the railway upgrade and hydroelectric project remain uncertain. Nigerian President Umaru Yar-Adu claimed that repairing decaying infrastructure was a national priority. STAFF_NOTE: The article mentions that this loan is similar to another loan prior to 2007 that failed to turn into oil blocks, presumably this is referring to ID #1844 and the failure of the Kaduna deal, but it is not entirely clear whether that means the $4 billion loan associated with that ID is also cancelled. PPIAF-ID:414'
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=FTFT000020080422e44m0004u&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.google.co.za/#output=search&sclient=psy-ab&q=4+billion+China+Nigeria+Infrastructure+oil+2006&oq=4+billion+China+Nigeria+Infrastructure+oil+2006&gs_l=hp.3...336624.405497.0.405672.63.53.7.0.0.0.295.4538.31j13j3.47.0...0.0...1c.1.18.psy-ab.BB9ZQNdErQM&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_qf.&bvm=bv.48572450,d.dmQ&fp=18c4154a0af92d76&biw=1185&bih=726, Academic Journal Article; http://newnigerianews.blogspot.com/2013/03/fg-to-rehabilitate-kaduna-port-harcourt.html, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://money.163.com/08/0422/09/4A4FUPTJ002524SC.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan for medium and low cost houses
description: On December 8, 2004 Botswana and China signed a P117 million loan agreement. The Minister of Finance and Development Planning, Baledzi Gaolatlhe, said the amount would enable the Botswana Housing Corporation (BHC) to construct 725 medium and low cost houses in Maun, Jwaneng, Gaborone, Lobatse, Francistown, and Palapye. The loan is payable in 15 years at an interest rate of four per cent per annum (debated b/w media report and Botswana gov. document) with a grace period of four years. Other sources reported that The China Overseas Engineering Group Co., Ltd (COVEC) built 424 affordable houses in 2005, which was financed by a concessional loan from the Chinese government. The Botswana government report indicates that 75,703,802 CNY was delivered for the Francistown, Gaborone, and Palapye projects. It is unclear what the current status of the project is.
sources: http://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?sid=10&aid=357&dir=2012/March/Wednesday14, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://bw.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200408/20040800259996.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LQAF000020041210e0c80003v&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.finance.gov.bw/templates/mfdp/file/File/DEBT%20PUBLISH.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

recipient_agencies: Botswana Housing Corporation, State-Owned Company
location_details: Maun, Jwaneng, Gaborone, Lobatse, Francistown and Gaborone

title: Loan for neonatal equipment
description: On April 6, 2012, the Chinese Vice Premier Hui Liangyu signed a series of economic and technical cooperation agreements with the government of Zimbabwe. One of these agreements was a 4.5 million CNY loan for the purchase of neonatal equipment. The current status of the project is unclear on whether or not the government of Zimbabwe has received the promised equipment.
crs_sector_name: Population Policies / Programmes and Reproductive Health

contacts: Hui Liangyu , Vice Premier of China ; Xin Shunkang , Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe

title: Loan for office equipment and vehicles
description: On December 5, 2012, Mali and China signed a loan agreement worth 700 million FCFA for the provision of office equipment and vehicles for the Malian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The loan agreement was signed in Bamako, the Malian capital, by Malian Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation, Tieman Coulibaly, and Chinese Ambassador to Mali Cao Zong Ming. The same day, an agreement was signed for a loan for priority projects (See Project #30409).
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFMAEN0020121208e8c700004&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Tieman Coulibaly, Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation (Government of Mali); Cao Zong Ming, Chinese Ambassador to Mali (China Ministry of Foreign Affairs)

title: Loan for priority projects
description: On December 5, 2012, Mali and China signed a loan agreement worth 16.8 billion FCFA to finance priority projects to improve the people's standard of living in Mali. The loan agreement was signed in Bamako, the Malian capital, by Malian Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation, Tieman Coulibaly, and Chinese Ambassador to Mali Cao Zong Ming. The same day, an agreement was signed for a loan to purchase office equipment and vehicles (See Project #30410).
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFMAEN0020121208e8c700004&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Tieman Coulibaly, Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation (Government of Mali); Cao Zong Ming, Chinese Ambassador to Mali (China Ministry of Foreign Affairs)

title: Loan for public works and human resources
description: On December 19, 2012, the Chinese Ambassador to Equatorial Guinea, Wang Shixiong informed Equatorial Guinean Minister of Public Works and Infrastructures, Juan Nko Mbula, that China had agreed to fund a loan that Equatorial Guinea's Executive had requested. The loan was requested during the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, for the construction of public works and human resources training. The status and amount of loan are unclear.
sources: http://www.guineaecuatorialpress.com/noticia.php?id=3321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Juan Nko Mbula, Minister of Public Works and Infrastructures ; Wang Shixiong, Ambassador to Equitorial Guinea (China)

title: Loan for purchase of aircraft for anti-piracy
description: In 2008, China signed an agreement with Seychelles to provide a loan from the Export-Import Bank of China to purchase two new Chinese-made light aircrafts to be used for anti-piracy efforts. The Y-12E aircraft is produced by China National Aero-Technology (CATIC). To become familiar with the Y-12E, a group of Seychellois engineers and pilots will leave in August for a 45-day training course in Harbin, where the plane is produced. As of May 2011, the pilots were still being trained in China. Delivery of the planes was expected in June of 2011. The aircrafts were successfully delivered.
sources: http://www.defpro.com/daily/details/946/print/?SID=dc3a0d38a0c65bbfe5463dde4efe8a11, Other; http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-252537970/china-give-seychelles-military.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/awx_09_22_2011_p0-372600.xml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.defenceweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=15556:china-donating-two-y-12-aircraft-to-seychelles&catid=35:Aerospace&Itemid=107, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020080504e454001jl&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan for purchase of non-intrusive scanners
description: In 2009, the China Exim Bank provided the Zambian government a concessional loan for the purchase of non-intrusive scanners. The loan amount was for 45.8 million USD at 2% interest rate, with a 15 year maturity period, 5 year grace period, and 10 year repayment schedule. There was a .5 percent commitment fee as well as a .75 percent service charge attached to the loan.
sources: http://www.mofnp.gov.zm/index2.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=194&Itemid=152, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&frm=1&source=web&cd=2&ved=0CDEQFjAB&url=http%3A%2F%2Feaz.org.zm%2Fdownloads%2Ffile%2F201202020618460.THE%2520STATUS%2520OF%2520ZAMBIAS%2520DOMESTIC%2520DEBT%2520AND%2520EXTERNAL%2520DEBT%5B1%5D-1.docx&ei=PC5LUumLMqj_4AP77YG4Dw&usg=AFQjCNG6GXf__X_JeCMccBTCmS1kXFU0Dg&sig2=FMtrUFbzR6PZA-7Z_SVfmw&bvm=bv.53371865,d.dmg&cad=rja, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy

donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Loan for rebuilding roads
description: In 2010, the Export-Import Bank of China agreed to loan Angola $500 million USD to rebuild roads to help the African nation recover from a three-decade long civil war that ended in 2002. It is unclear how exactly the funds were used.
sources: http://www.angolahub.com/index.php/en/angola-news/1202-angola-contraiu-500-milhoes-de-dolares-em-emprestimos-junto-do-banco-exim-da-china, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LBA0000020100709e67900165&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/07/09/ozatp-angola-china-loan-idAFJOE6680JK20100709, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/fortune/2010-11/20/c_12796734.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Loan for sanitation and road equipment in Kampala
description: On May 15, 2008, the Ugandan Parliament approved a loan from the China Export Import Bank worth 10 million USD for road and sanitation equipment for Kampala City Council. The loan has a maturity period of 20 years and seven years of grace. The interest is two percent on the disbursed and outstanding loan. The grant element of the loan is approximately 41.96 percent. The equipment will be supplied by China First Automobile Works. The current status and end date are unknown.
sources: http://www.parliament.go.ug/hansard/hans_view_date.jsp?dateYYYY=2008&dateMM=05&dateDD=15, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020080517e45h000rt&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan for security communications system
description: On January 19, 2008, Uganda's Minister of Security Amama Mbabazi launched Tetra Communications System, a state-of-the-art communications system to be used by police, army and intelligence agencies. The 5 million USD system was purchased after acquiring a loan from China. The start date is unknown.

title: Loan for sugar manufacturing and refining
description: On June 30, 2011, a loan was signed by the China Exim Bank and the Ethiopian Government worth 123 million USD for sugar manufacturing and refining projects. The loan had terms of Libor 6 months plus 2.35% interest, a 3 year grace perios, and a 12 year maturity.

title: Loan for textile factory expansion
description: In 2001, the Chinese ambassador Ai Ping said that the Chinese government supplied an interest-free loan of nearly 2.4 million dollars and 1 million dollars to a textile factory in Awassa, capital of the Southern National Nationalities Peoples' state, in support of its production expansion program.'The status of the project is uncertain.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=xnews00020010715dx1500ukh&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=xnews00020010715dx6l015hl&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan for the construction of fiber-optic infrastructure
description: In 2007, Uganda and the Exim Bank of China signed an agreement for a loan worth 106 million USD for the construction of the National Data Transmission Backbone Infrastructure (NBI) and the funding of the Electronic Government Infrastructure (EGI) initiative (some earlier sources have indicated the loan was for 120 million USD). The loan has an interest rate of 2%, a grace period of 5 years and a maturity of 20 years. The loan is being used to fund the construction of a fiber-optic infrastructure linking the country to surrounding countries as well as government ministries to each other. The project is being implemented by China's Huawei Technologies in three phases. The first phase was concluded in 2007, connecting 27 government ministries in the Kampala Metroplitan Area, and Entebbe, Jinja, Mukono, and Bombo as well as 5 transmission sites. The second phase was concluded in 2011, constructing a datacentre, beginning a pilot project for messaging and collaboration tools, and laying, 1,548 kilometers of fiber-optic cable linking Luwero, Nakasongola, Masindi, Gulu, Nimule, Lira, Soroti, Kumi, Mbale, Tororo, Malaba, Busia, Hoima, Kyenjojo, Fort Portal, Kasese, Bushenyi, and Mbarara, including 17 transmission sites. The third phase will lay 307 kilometers of cable connecting Katuna, Kabale, Ntungamo, Masaka, and Mutukula through 3 transmissions sites, linking Uganda with Rwanda and Tanzania.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020061113e2bd000tf&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.columbia.edu/itc/sipa/nelson/newmediadev/china.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); www.cbcglobal.org/images/uploads/library/Minister_presentation.pptâ€Ž, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ugandaradionetwork.com/a/story.php?s=15075, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://mydl.itweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1848&Itemid=36, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://www.biztechafrica.com/article/uganda-powers-national-internet-backbone/1247/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020061113e2bd000tf&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan for unspecified purposes
description: In an Ethiopian budget report from 2011 (Table 1.10), the Chinese government was reported to have provided a loan for 30 million CNY. The loan agreement was signed on September 1, 2010 at an interest-free rate with a 10 year grace period, and 20 year maturity. It is unclear what the funds were intended for.
sources: http://www.mofed.gov.et/English/Resources/Documents/Public%20Sector%20Debt%20Statistical%20Bulletin%20-%20No.7%20(2006-07%20-%202010-11).pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Loan for water distribution project
description: The project began in December 30, 2009, when the Cameroonian Ministry of Energy and Water Resources signed an agreement with a Chinese firm, China Machinery & Equipment Import Export Corporation (CMEC) to carryout a 16 month feasibility study for a project to supply the city of Yaounde with potable water from River Sanaga. On December 15, 2010 Cameroon secured a 366 billion CFA franc loan from the Export-Import Bank of China to go forward with the water distribution project. The loan partially funds the project's total estimated cost of 430 billion CFA, with the remainder coming from Cameroon's government. Cameroon's government hired the China National Machinery and Equipment Corporation on a 28-month contract for the water project, which will involve construction of a 56-kilometer pipeline from the Sanaga River. The ultimate goal is for the pipeline to harness water from the Sanaga river, bringing an additional supply of 100,000 cubic metres of water daily to the town. The program will reach 2 million people in the capital city Yaounde and villages along the pipeline. Water and Energy Minister Michael Tomdio estimated that the project would begin in January of 2011. Updates on the project's progress are currently unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AFNWS00020100204e6240010z&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.foods1.com/content/1118278/, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE6BE0DO20101215, Media Report, including Wikileaks

donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency; China National Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) , State-Owned Company

title: Loan for water equipment
description: On August 18, 2003, the Chinese company Yushan signed an agreement with Sudan to extend a 10 million USD loan to Sudan to finance the purchase of water pumps and water equipment. Part of the financing will be earmarked for the construction of a workshop to offer maintenance for water pumps locally. Yushan pledged to produce the water pumps for Sudan. The loan was extended by the People's Bank of China and is to be paid back in half-year installments in a four-year period. The loan has a one-year grace period. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=sudand0020030818dz8i00001&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: People's Bank of China (PBC), Government Agency
implementing_agency: Yushan
donor_agency: People's Bank of China (PBC), Government Agency; Yushan

title: Loan for water well project phase 1
description: On November 16, 2011, Ethiopia's Finance and Economic Minsiter Sufyan Ahamad and the Chinese deputy minister of commerce Jiang Yaoping signed 171m-birr [10m dollars] loan agreement for the third phase of the Addis Ababa Deep Water Well Project. The drilling of the three deep water wells will be undertaken in Akaki water fields which can produce 10,000 cubic metres of water a day. The project is expected to serve 100,000 people living in Addis Ababa city. It was inaugurated in March of 2012.

title: Loan from China Development Bank for the Mansa-Luwingu Road
description: On December 28, 2012, the Zambia Road Development Agency and China Henan International Corporation signed a contract for the Mansa-Luwingu road. This stretch of highway will connect Mansa province with Luwingu province, and is expected to take 40 months to complete and will cost a total of 207 million USD. According to a document on the Zambian Eleventh National Assembly the China Development Bank will provide funding for the project. STAFF_NOTE: It is unclear what portion of the project is being financed by the China Development Bank.

title: Loan of ZMK 32b
description: In 2010, China signed an agreement to provide Zambia with an interest-free loan agreement of K32 billion. The funds will be used in the fight against poverty and other projects to be agreed upon by the two countries. It is unclear exactly how the funds were used.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=MENREP0020111215e7cf0001k&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan servicing agreement with export credits
description: Multiple Memorandums of Understanding were signed in a trip to Beijing by President Mugabe in July of 2005. Part of the agreements gave Zimbabwe a new loan servicing process of having 25% of the country's export credits go towards the loans from China. This gives China access to a rich natural resource supply of a country facing starvation and malnutrition. This would account for a total of $40 million Us dollars in export receipts. Most of the loans were insured by Sinosure, a Chinese Export and Credit Insurance Corporation. The Zimbabwe Minister of Finance, Dr. Herbert Murerwa signed the agreement with the Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce. Exact dates of when the loans were received or trades thereof are yet to be determined.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020050812e18c000t8&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020050727e17r0018i&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://kaifangzhan.mofcom.gov.cn/article/g/i/200902/20090206029262.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

recipient_agencies: Zimbabwe Iron and Steel Company (ZISCO), Public Private Partnership

title: Loan to Build/Equip Hospitals
description: On December 3, 2002, Morocco and Export-Import Bank of China signed a CNY 150 million preferential loan agreement in Rabat to build and equip eight private general hospitals in various regions of the kingdom. The agreement was signed by Moroccan Economy, Finance, Privatization and Tourism Minister Fathallah Oulalou and the Chinese ambassador in Raba, Xiong Zhanqi. The status of the project is uncertain.

donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Loan to Help in Agricultural Projects
description: In November 2008, the Mozambican and Chinese governments signed three agreements in Maputo under which China is to provide a total of 43 million dollars in loan and grant finance. One loan of 18 million US dollars was to support agricultural projects in the Zambezi Valley. The agreements were signed by Mozambican Finance Minister Manuel Chang and the Chinese ambassador, Tian Guangfong, under the terms of the Cooperation Protocol signed in February, during the visit to China by Mozambican President Armando Guebuza. It is possible that this commitment is related to the Agricultural research centers, ID#1215.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AFNWS00020081118e4bi0018o&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan to West Africa Development Bank
description: In 2004, China made its first capital contribution to the West Africa Development Bank in the form of an 8 billion FCFA loan. This loan made China the second largest partner of the Bank behind France. The loan specifics are unknown. This project was discovered from sources for Project #19671 in which the China Development Bank provided the loan; it can be assumed that the bank provided this one as well.
sources: http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2011-08/19/c_131061753.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.africareview.com/Business---Finance/US-in-West-Africa-bank-deal/-/979184/1405468/-/hfojrez/-/index.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan to boost economy
description: Algeria and China signed a $3 million USD interest-free loan, China's contribution designed to boost the Algerian economy. The agreement was signed by the secretary-general of the Algerian Foreign Ministry, Mr Abdelaziz Djerrad, and the Chinese vice-minister at the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, Zhou Keren. It is unclear exactly how the loan will be used.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcmee0020020117dy1g0000d&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan to construct ore terminal to facilitate salt export
description: On November 20, 2012, the Djibouti government and the China Exim Bank signed a loan agreement worth 64 million USD for the construction of an ore terminal to facilitate export of salt from Lake Assal. China Harbor Engineering Company Ltd, a subsidiary of China Communications Construction Company Ltd, is to complete the project over two years. According to an estimate, the completion of the construction work will enable Djibouti to export 5,000 tons of salt annually to Southeast Asian countries.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020121120e8bk004sb&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://hornofafricanews.blogspot.com/2012/03/mineral-port-to-be-build-in-djiboutis.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan to finance economic cooperation
description: On June 17, 2002, Sudan's Council of Ministers endorsed, in its regular meeting chaired by First Vice-President Ali Uthman Muhammad Taha, a technical and economic cooperation agreement between Sudan and China granting Sudan a loan of about 30 million CNY to finance economic cooperation projects. The exact commitment date, current status, and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcmep0020020617dy6h00004&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Bad-al-Din Sulayman, ; Ali Uthman Muhammad Taha,

title: Loan to refurbish Victoria Falls airport
description: In 2012, China gave a 162 million USD concessional loan to Zimbabwe to refurbish a key airport ahead of the United Nations World Tourism Organization (UNWTO) summit. Before the Zimbabwean government could access the Chine Exim Bank funds, they had to repay some of the nationa's debt to Exim and other Chinese institutions. The renovation started in April 2013, at an estimated cost of 1.25 billion CNY and includes extending the current runway and building a second 4,000 meter long runway, a 100,000 square meter tarmac, a 20,000 square meter new terminal, and a car park. The widening of the airport road to Victoria Falls Town should be completed by December 31, 2014, while the construction of the new runway is expected to be complete by April of 2015. There is a financial discrepancy between the 162 million USD Exim bank loan and the supposed 202 million USD needed for the completion of the project.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=APASENE020120113e81d000ru&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90883/8204505.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.zimtreasury.gov.zw/143-zimbabwe-pays-external-debts, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://victoriafalls24.com/blog/2013/06/15/victoria-falls-airport-renovations-underway/, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://harare24.com/index-id-news-zk-13953.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.zbc.co.zw/news-categories/top-stories/30331-govt-secures-us150mil-for-airport-refurbisment.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
funding_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Loan to resettle refugees
description: On May 15, 2008 China gave Kenya an interest-free loan of 500 million shillings to help resettle hundreds of thousands of villagers uprooted by political turmoil following Kenyan elections. The project is linked to a 200 million shillings grant of the same nature, Project #19014.
sources: http://www.tianjinwe.com/hotnews/txjj/200805/t20080516_22729.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020080515e45f004vv&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan with grants for the construction of bridges
description: On June 29, 2011 in Beijing, President Umar al-Bashir and his Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao witnessed the signing of an agreement on loan grants for the eastern Sudan (Darfur region) development fund and construction of bridges on River Atbara between the Chinese Deputy Minister of Commerce and the Sudanese Minister of Finance and National Economy, Ali Mahmud, at a cost of 132 million CNY. The aid will go toward reconstruction in eastern Sudan and economic and technical cooperation projects. The aid is partially in the form of a grant and partially in the form of an interest-free loan. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://www.arabnews.com/node/362007, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sunanews.net/english-latest-news/17766-sudan-china-sign-two-agreements-at-160-million-chinese-yuan-for-boosting-economic-cooperation-humanitarian-assistance.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-260133147/china-jintao-sudan-al.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loan without profit for unidentified projects
description: On November 19, 2009, Sudan's Minister of Energy and Mining, Al-Zubayr Ahmad Al-Hasan, and CCP officials signed an agreement for a Chinese loan without profit of 80 million CNY to Sudan. The deal was signed in the presence of the Sudanese Vice President Ali Uthman Taha and the visiting Member of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, Chu Yong Kang. This loan was signed along with other agreements with the government and CNPC. The sector, current status, and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://www.sudanvisiondaily.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=51460, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article33188, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Al-Zubayr Ahmad Al-Hasan, ; Ali Uthman Taha,

title: Loans and loan guarantees
description: On January 4, 2004 in Khartoum, Sudan, Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing and Sudanese Foreign Minister Mustafa Osman Ismail signed two economic cooperation agreements securing 60 million CNY in loans and loan guarantees to Sudan. The sector, current status, and start and end dates of the project are unknown.

title: Loans for Cote d'Ivoire
description: In June 2011, Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Zha Jun and Ivory Coast Foreign Minister Daniel Kablan Duncan signed documents that granted Ivory Coast loans and cancellation of debt (project #148). The status and specifics of the loans are uncertain.
sources: http://vlex.cn/vid/deeply-fighting-poverty-cote-ivoire-323722219, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90883/7570832.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loans for Egyptian manufacturers to import from China
description: On October 29, 2007, Egypt's Trade Ministry announced that China would provide Egyptian firms a 200 million USD credit line for importing production lines and technology transfers from China. The line has a 7-year grace period and interest rates of no more than 2 percent. It is unknown whether any firms took advantage of the offer. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LBA0000020071030e3au002d4&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Issue/straitstimes20071225-1.aspx, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Loans for defense college
description: On May 11, 2011, officials signed a 98 million USD loan agreement from Exim Bank of China for the construction of the Zimbabwean National Defense College along Mazowe Road in Harare, Zimbabwe. The implementing agency for the project is Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Group Corp. Ltd, a public construction company under Chinaâ€™s Ministry of Construction. The project's loan has a grace period of 2 years, repayment period of 13 years and is payable at a 2% interest rate twice a year. Another source gave the same loan details but listed the maturity as 20 years. Diamond proceeds from the Zimbabwe Mining Development Corporation and Anhui Foreign Economic and Construction Group's private corporation joint venture, Anjin Investments, will be used to repay the loan. Construction of the College began in 2011.

title: Loans for infrastructure development
description: On November 2, 2010, China announced it would loan Uganda 100 million USD to be used to upgrade and maintain Uganda's road network. The concessional loan was repayable within 40 years with a 10-year grace period. Sometime around July 2012, Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni presided over the first batch of equipment purchased with the loan entering the country for the work on the Uganda's road network, including 159 graders, 257 tipper trucks, 12 wheel loaders, six dozers, seven excavators and two loaders. These machine form part of a total of 1,400 units to be procured with the loan. The current status and end date are unknown.

title: Lome Hospital Construction
description: In September of 2005, it was announced that China would construct a hospital in Togo's capitol city of Lome. Construction was set to begin in 2006. On June 17, 2009 Togolese Health Minister Comlan Mally (L) and Chinese Ambassador to Togo Yang Min signed the handover document of the Lome Central Hospital in Lome, marking the completion of the civil engineering work of the building. The hospital was sponsored and built by the Chinese government and covers an area of 5,934 square meters. The hospital was scheduled to open at the end of the year.
sources: http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90783/91300/6681588.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-135836646/china-give-togo-politically.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Li Jinzhang, ; Yang Min, ; Comlan Mally,

title: Low income housing
description: In 2009, Tida Egypt secured financing from the Chinese government to construct a low-income housing compound in Ain Sokhna, Egypt. The amount, current status, and start and end dates are unknown.

title: Low interest loans
description: In 2010, Wen Jiaobao announced that from 2010 to 2013 China would set aside $1 billion for a financial cooperation fund (Project #797) and provide low-interest loans worth 1.6 billion yuan between Asian and African nations within the seven Portuguese states. The status and intent of these loans is uncertain. STAFF_NOTES: All projects that mention low-interest loans or concessional/soft loans without specific information on rates or terms have been classified as OF-vague. Without specific rate information, we cannot classify the project as ODA, but it does not necessarily fall under OOF either, so vague is the most appropriate and accurate classification at this time.

title: Low medium income housing projects
description: On November 7, 2006, Kenyan President Mwai Kibaki and China Development Bank governor Mr. Chen Yuan met and agreed to sign a framework between the bank and the government of Kenya to expedite the funding of a project for low and medium income housing. The project came in response to Kenya's substantial housing deficit. On December 6, 2006, China Development Bank announced that it would provide a 10 million dollar concessionary loan for the housing project, to be repaid in 15 years. The Development Bank of Kenya plans to provide long-term finance of up to 15 years to low and middle income housing project customers. On May 30, 2008 the ground-breaking ceremony of the housing project occurred. The entire project is expected to last about fifteen years (until 2021) or later, but may last longer due to slow progress accredited to court injuctions and land scarcity. As of 2012, only 2,000 housing units have been completed comared to the 40,000 planned for completion.Implementation of the project's first phase involves the production of 720 housing units for sale and appears to have been successfully completed. As of January 2011, the implementing agencies have concentrated their efforts on Phases 2 and 3. The implementation of the project has so far been carried out by implementing agencies China Wu Yi Corporation Limited and Ederman Properties. Construction efforts in the 'Greatwall Apartments' Complex have successfully provided Kenyan citizens with 528 apartments, as well as facilities including shops and school. Another 105 houses have been constructed as part of the Kileleshwa Park Apartments. Further construction efforts include building 700 housing units in Ngara. 1,000 units in Kibera, 700 units in Madaraka and Nairobi West and 105 units in Lang'ata. The project is linked to the Development Financial Cooperation Framework Agreement (DFCFA) signed by the Kenyan government and the China Development Bank in December 2008. As per the DFCFA, the project will operate in accordance with market principles rather than traditional aid.Funding for the package came as part of a 20 million USD credit for housing, education and health care from the China Development Bank.Contacts who have publicly commented on the project include Chinese Ambassador to Kenya Zhang Ming, general director of the Africa Project Development Team Zhu Qingdong, managing director of the Erdemann Property Limited Yang Zeyun and Housing minister Soita Shitanda. The project may be linked to further low-cost housing projects according to senior comissioner Zhu Qingdong. Qingdong states that the China Development Bank plans to work with the Government of Kenya, Kenya Development Bank, and other financial institutions to support these additional low-cost housing projects.

description: In 2004 China built 150 low-income housing units in the Zimpeto, Maputo. The project cost 3.9 million US dollars. Conflicting data is given on the flow type. When the project actually started and was completed remains unknown. Organization that completed the project remains unknown. Amount obtained from graph on p. 30 of second URL PDF.

title: Low-cost housing units
description: On January 12, 2011, the Export-Import Bank of China signed agreements for two project loans, including 33 billion CFA francs for building 1,500 low-cost housing units. The status of the project is uncertain.

title: Lusaka Stadiums commence
description: In 2011, construction and rehabilitation of the 50,000 capacity Lusaka and Independence stadiums commenced. The expected total of the projects is $94 million USD. The Lusaka stadium was expected to be completed in 2013. The Shanghai Construction Group of China is responsible for the construction. The Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) supplied power to the site. The project were made possible by the concessional loan from the Chinese government. The project is currently under construction and is expected to be completed in October of 2013, 3 months ahead of schedule. China is also keen to train stadium managers for the project.

title: Lusaka-Chirundu road reconstruction
description: On November 1, 2005, the China Henan International Construction Co. signed a construction contract for the full repaving of 34.7 KM of the Lusaka-Chirundu Road. The road was jointly funded by the Chinese government and the World Bank.The Lusaka-Chirundu Road Rehabilitation Project was scheduled for completion in March 2008 but due to the heavy rains experienced in 2007/08 rain season, rehabilitation work on the Lusaka â€“ Chirundu Road was completed in July 2008. The total contract sum was listed as 110,655,185,204 ZMK, but it is unknown what portion of this contract amount came from China and what came from the World Bank. A World Bank document listed their commitment as 15 million USD in 2010, and this project may be related to Chinese funding provided in ID#2222.

title: MA60 Deal
description: On November 4, 2004, Acting Finance and Economic Development Minister, Herbert Murerwa, and Chinese Vice-Minister of Commerce, Mr. Wei Jianguo, exchanged letters on a grant for an MA60 aircraft in exchange for purchasing two of the aircrafts from China Aviation Industry Corporation (AVIC) as negotiated by Transport and Communications Minister Christopher Mushohwe and China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC). The purchase occurred and China received the third plane as a gift as promised. The 60-seater propeller planes will fly domestic and regional routes. Since the cost of purchasing two planes together was $22 million, the amount of the contribution must be approximately $11 million. This project may be considered concessional as an 'export credit' of sorts with a concessionality of 33%, however, the exact terms of the agreement are unclear.
sources: http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=140977, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020050727e17r0018i&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020050504e15400b19&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LQAF000020041106e0b40000f&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: MOU Tourism

The first agreement was a Memorandum of Understanding between the Moroccan Ministry of Tourism and the national department of tourism in the People's Republic of China. The status of this agreement is uncertain.

title: MOU for the establishment of a Malaria Prophylactic Therapeutic Demonstration Centre
description: In 2006, Ghana and China signed a series of agreements regarding socioeconomic development in the African country. Among the agreements was the establishment of a Malaria Prophylactic Therapeutic Demonstration Center. It is unclear how much the facility was worth, where it is located, if construction commenced, or if it has been completed.

title: MOU on industry, trade, and investment
description: In May of 2008, Malawi and China signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on industry, trade, and investment. The agreement was signed on behalf of their governments by Ministry of Commerce, Gao Hucheng, and Malawian Industry and Trade Minister, Henry Mussa. One of the goals of the agreement included providing more opportunities for Malawian businesses that would thus increase their exports to China as well as the rest of the world. A report stated that since that date, trade has doubled, however than might just be evidence of the two countries reopening diplomatic ties. The current status of this project and how and whether it was implemented is yet unknown.
sources: http://www.guardian.co.uk/global-development/2011/may/07/china-puts-mark-malawi-presence, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNHA000020080514e45e0002t&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.moafsmw.org/ocean/docs/General%20Documents/MGDS%202008%20Annual%20review%20FINAL.pdf, Other

title: MOU w/ Ministry of Agriculture
description: In 2000, Beijing Urban Construction Group signed an MoU with the Sierra Leone Ministry of Agriculture. It is unclear what the terms of the agreement were or how it was implemented.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=qedcer0020010815dw2s0001f&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
donor_agency: Beijing Urban Construction Group Co., Ltd., State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: Sierra Leone Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security, Government Agency

title: Maize Flour Mill Project
description: In 2009, the Chinese Embassy handed over a Maize Flour Processing Project in Bomet Constituency. It was funded by the Chinese government. The facility will have an average daily production rate of 500,000 tons. It is unclear how much the facility is worth.
sources: http://books.google.com/books?id=E3j5wFbRfWEC&pg=PT12&lpg=PT12, Other; http://www.aercafrica.org/documents/china_africa_relations/Kenya.pdf, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://ke.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200905/20090506267742.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Maize Food Aid
description: On June 8, 2006 China donated an estimated 2,500 tonnes (~50kg) of maize to Togo with the purpose to stabilize maize prices on the local market. Chinese Ambassador to Togo, Zhang Shixian presented the donation to the Minister of Agriculture, Animal Husbandry and Fisheries, Charles Kondi Agba. Zhang Shixian said the donation was within the framework of cooperation with Togo.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020060608e268002uu&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/newscenter/2006-06/09/content_4669058.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Makeni Hydroelectric Dam
description: In 2009, China agreed to build two hydro electric dams in Sierra Leone. The two dams would be built over three years in the northern city of Makeni, Koroma's home base, and in Port Loko (project ID#2259), 75 miles (120 km) from the capital Freetown. It is unclear if construction has commenced.
sources: http://www.cnki.com.cn/Article/CJFDTotal-GCZX200906033.htm, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=LBA0000020090519e55j000xl&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Malabo City Grid Rehabilitation
description: (PPIAF) In June of 2008, Equatorial Guinea held a groundbreaking ceremony for the rehabilitation of the Malabo City Power Grids. The project worth $300 million USD is being funded by China's state-owned Export-Import Bank. CMEC served as the prime contractor and Jilin Province Power Transmission Substation Project Co. served as the subcontractor. A company press release suggested that Phase I of the project was completed sometime before December 2010, where at least the construction on Phase II of the project was completed in May 2011. Additionally, an official Chinese source reported than an official ceremony for the addition of street-lamps to the city grid was held on June 4, 2012. STAFF_NOTE: It is possible that this Ex-Im bank loan is linked to $2 billion line of credit from Ex-Im Bank issued in 2006 (Project ID# 484). PPIAF-ID:109
sources: http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:SiW2x7-sTnMJ:www.sinomach.com.cn/templates/T_news_en/index.aspx%2525253Fnodeid%2525253D322%25252526page%2525253DContentPage%25252526contentid%2525253D3030+&cd=2&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us, Other; http://gq.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/ztdy/200806/20080605585648.html?2381724598=4161195480, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.noodls.com/viewNoodl/11806158/sinomach---china-national-machinery-industry-corporation/equatorial-guinea-malabo-power-grid-phase-ii-project-commenc, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://jlsbd.jl.sgcc.com.cn/department/gjgs/english/jnxm/jndt13.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: Malabo Power Plant Expansion
description: (PPIAF) In 2009, China National Machinery Equipment Import & Export Corp. (CMEC) agreed to expand the Malabo Power Plant partially funded by export credits from China and partially funded from the government of Equatorial Guinea. The total investment was 99.61 million EUR, but it is not known how much of the project was Chinese funded. In May of 2012, the project was completed. A delegation led by Political Counselor Lin Ji, Charge d'Affaires at the Chinese Embassy inspected the newly completed plant. STAFF_NOTE: It is possible that this Ex-Im bank loan is linked to $2 billion line of credit from Ex-Im Bank issued in 2006 (Project ID# 484). PPIAF-ID:102

implementing_agency: China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC)
donor_agency: China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC)

title: Malaria Control Center
description: China assisted in setting up and renovating a malaria control center in Maputo, Mozambique. China renovated Influlen Hospital's laboratories and training rooms, provided equipment, and sent a group of doctors to train the staff. According to the Mozambican Ambassador to China, Antonio Inacio Junio, China helped conceive the infrastructure for the new center. The center was officially handed over on November 25, 2009 with Mo Garrido, Mozambican Minister of Health, and Tian GuangFeng, Chinese Ambassador, in attendance.
sources: http://www.focac.org/eng/zxxx/t832788.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.macaomagazine.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=174:full-speed-ahead&catid=44:issue-9, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.igh.pku.edu.cn/PDF/China-Africa%20Health%20Cooperation%20Study%204_China-Africa%20Collaborative%20Project%20on%20Malaria%20Control%20and%20Elimination%20(English).pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://www.sourcejuice.com/1279806/2009/11/27/Ambassador-Mozambique-Tian-Guang-Feng-Yuan-malaria-prevention-treatment/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Malaria Prevention
description: In 2006, China spent $623,000 fighting malaria in Nigeria. Part of this amount was spent on training 50 Nigerians and medical staff. The agreements were signed in Abuja.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020060427e24r002gy&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.topix.com/forum/world/nigeria/TGJEITMOLKV1U83LM, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Malaria Treatment Center
description: At the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC) in November 2006, China pledged to construct a malaria prevention and treatment center later designated to be built for Burundi. In a report on the implementation of the promises made in the FOCAC summit, it was reported that the center had been completed on March 17, 2008 in Bujumbura, Burundi. The amount and start date are unknown.
sources: nai.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:399727/FULLTEXT02, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.focac.org/eng/ltda/dscbzjhy/FA32009/t459449.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020071011e3ab0015p&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Malaria medication
description: On April 17, 2007, Chinese and Senegalese officials signed an agreement for the donation of 2 million CNY worth of malaria medicines. The medicines were reported as delivered, however the exact end date for this project is yet unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020071223e3ca002xn&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://vlex.cn/vid/senegal-sign-accord-medical-envoys-198454943, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Malaria research center
description: In 2009, China donated a malaria research center housed by Yaounde's Hospital of Gynecology, Obstetrics, and Pediatrics. The center cost $400,000 and was inaugurated in March 2009.
sources: http://www.ccs.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/CCS-Central-Africa-Briefing-Paper-August-2009.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

title: Malarial Donations
description: As part of a FOCAC commitment, China has made two donations of Malarial drugs in addition to the drugs donated with the N'Djili hospital and those donated in 2010. These two drug disbursements were made in 2008 and 2009 respectively. The financial amount and exact start and end dates are still unknown.The other two malarial donations occured in ID#438 and ID#454

title: Malarial Treatment Drugs
description: In 2008, the department in charge of Asia at Burundi's Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced that the supply of anti-malarial drugs by China was a central part of Sino-Burundian cooperation. The amount, start and end dates, and current status are unknown.
sources: http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-187338543/china-diversifies-cooperation-burundi.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Mambilla Hydroelectric Project
description: In 2007, Nigeria awarded China Gezhouba Group Corporation (CGGC) and China Geo-Engineering Corporation (CGC) a $1.46-billion contract to construct a hydroelectric project on the Mambila plateau in the north-east of the West African country. The contract is explicitly for civil work and the steel hydraulic structure of the dam, and is for 60 months. The project is expected to add another 2,600MW to Nigeriaâ€™s national grid. According to Feng Jun, the Vice Director of the Beijing liaison office, the plant will cost around $5 billion, mostly financed by the Nigerian government and accented by a $300 million loan from the Export-Import Bank of China. The project was scheduled to be completed by 2012. However, Sunrise Power and Transmission Ltd, a bidder shortlisted on bidding for the project, initiated legal action against the Federal government in 2007, which stalled the project. The federal government insisted on finishing the project by the end of the president's administration in 2015, which the contractors openly contested as impossible. In 2012, the project capacity increased to 3,050 MW, and President Jonathan said the project design was complete. According to a 2012 article, EXIM Bank of China promised 75 per cent of the project cost, with counterpart funding in the sum of $309 million from the Nigerian government. According to a June 2013 report, the government of Nigeria had just approved counterpart funding for a 3050MW Mambilla hydroelectric plant located in Taraba State, which would cost a total of $3.2 billion, and be built China Gezhouba Group Company and Sinohydro. There is some disagreement in sources on the current implementing agencies of the project. The project will generate revenue to repay the loan. Sinohydro will build the power plant at its expense and operate it for nine years before transferring ownership to the Nigerian government.

title: Manpower development
description: In November 2002, when Chinese Vice-Foreign Minister Jang Wenchang was visiting Ethiopia for the China-Africa Cooperation Forum, he announced that China was ready to donate 10 million yen for manpower development in Ethiopia. The statuses of the donation and the project are uncertain.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=bbcap00020021125dybp006mx&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Maputo-Catembe Bridge
description: In October of 2011, Lourenco Sambo, the Mozambican Investment Promotion Centre's general director, announced that China would finance a bridge from Maputo to Catembe. The bridge will be 3km long and 48 meters high so that ships can continue to travel below. China would take over financing from Portugal, which could no longer fulfill the commitment. On June 1, China Exim Bank extended a $72.5 million credit for bridge construction, however it later expanded its commitment to $681.6 million and to include construction of the Catembe-Ponta do Ouro (100km) and upgrading of the Bela Vista-Boane roads. On Wednesday, July 19, 2012, the official loan agreement was signed by Mozambican Finance Minister, Manuel Chang, with the Export Import Bank of China. Construction will take 3 years to finish putting the estimation to 2015; China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was awarded the contract for construction. Overall costs add up to $725 million US dollars with the Exim Bank subsidizing 95% of it and the state government of Maputo putting in 5%. The total amount of the Exim Bank loan was $681.6 million, with a maturity of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, and an interest rate of 4%. The bridge will have four tolls to help pay for the loan. The first brick of the bridge was supposedly laid on September 20, 2012, but according to the latest report from April 24, 2013, construction will begin in the second half of the year. The first shipment of construction materials was delivered on June 11, 2013.
sources: http://www.macauhub.com.mo/en/2012/07/19/china%2525E2%252580%252599s-exim-bank-grants-mozambique-more-money-to-build-maputo-catembe-bridge/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020111024e7ao001hw&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.macauhub.com.mo/en/2012/09/18/first-stone-of-maputo-catembe-bridge-due-to-be-laid-thursday/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120602e8610004k&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.macauhub.com.mo/en/2013/04/24/construction-of-the-maputocatembe-in-mozambique-due-to-begin-in-second-half/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.namnewsnetwork.org/v3/read.php?id=MjMzOTY5, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.clubofmozambique.com/solutions1/sectionnews.php?secao=business&id=26079&tipo=one, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://allafrica.com/stories/201209220255.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Marburg fever medicine
description: In 2005, the Chinese government offered to send in medicine worth 1 million Chinese Yuan in order to aid the efforts in combating the spread of the Marburg hemorrhagic fever in Angola. It is unclear if the medicines were ever received, and if so, how they were used.
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/200504070567.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Master Loan Program for Development Projects Phase I
description: On November 7, 2006, one day after the conclusion of the China-Africa Cooperation Forum in Beijing, Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jiaobao pledged $500 million for various development projects in Ethiopia, including the Amarti Nashe Hydroelectric Power plant and the expansion work of the Mugur Cement Factory. The loan is referred to as the 'Master Loan Program.' On September 24, 2007, the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $208 million loan agreement to finance the expansion of the Muger Cement Enterprise and the construction of Fincha Amerti Neshe multi-purpose projects, including hydro-power generation and irrigation. The agreement was signed by the CBE President Abie Sano and Export-Import Bank of China President Li Ruogu. The Ethiopian government will cover the remaining $68 million of the project's $276 million total cost.The Muger Cement Enterprise expansion project began on April 21, 2012. Construction was delayed for more than two years for several reasons, including the 24 month delay of the EX-IM Bank of China loan, power interruptions, and logistical problems while transporting construction materials from Djibouti port. In December 2006, the Ethiopian Electric Power Corporation (EEPCo) and the China Gezhouba Group Corporation (CGGC) signed an agreement to construct the 100 MW Amarti Nashe Hydroelectric Power plant on the Neshe River. International Rivers reported that this dam was completed in 2011 for a total cost of $142 million, financed 85% by China Exim Bank. The cost was taken out of the original $500 million for the total costs of this project. He also pledged that day to allow additional Ethiopian agricultural projects to China duty free (Project #12635).
sources: http://nazret.com/blog/index.php/2007/09/25/ethiopia_gets_208_mln_china_loan_for_pow, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ertagov.com/erta/erta-news-archive/37-erta-tv-top-news-addis-ababa-ethiopia/879-china-eximbank-grants-500-million-loan-to-ethiopia.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.hydroworld.com/index/display/article-display/articles/hrhrw/News/China_bank_funds_Ethiopias_100-MW_Finchaa-Amarti-Neshe.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://ertagov.com/erta/erta-news-archive/38-erta-tv-hot-news-addis-ababa-ethiopia/1629-muger-cement-inaugurates-17-billion-birr-expansion-project.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://nazret.com/blog/index.php/2007/09/24/ethiopia_cbe_signs_208_mil_usd_loan_with, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://nazret.com/blog/index.php/2011/08/17/china-has-lent-ethiopia-500-million?blog=15, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://allafrica.com/stories/200611070975.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ethiopiainvestor.com/index.php?view=article&catid=1%252525253Alatest-news&id=2289%252525253Afan-hydropower-project-starts-generating-power-&option=com_content, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.yikuo.com/news/2009-09-03/84_200993113003849133292.shtml, Other; http://www.internationalrivers.org/resources/china-overseas-dams-list-3611, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; https://publications.worldbank.org/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=22946, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: Master Loan Program for Development Projects Phase II
description: In 2011 China signed Phase II of a 'Master Loan Program,' which began in 2006. The first phase, Project ID# 725, gave a $500 million loan for development projects. In April 2011, China Ex-Im bank and the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia signed the second round agreement, awarding another $500 million to Ethiopia. The Minister of Finance and Economic Development, Sofian Ahmed who also signed the loan agreement on behalf of the Ethiopian government said that the money will be used to implement 15 development projects, which have already been designed by the government. The status of the projects is uncertain. There is evidence that the second phase may include railway construction.

title: Masters in Public Policy and Public Administration
description: In 2009, China provided the Mauritian Ministry of Civil Service AR with two Masters degree programs in China. One was a one year International Masters in Public Policy at Tsinghua University, and the other was a one year International Masters in Public Administration at Peking University. The project cost was 400,000 MUR, and the exact start and end dates are unknown.

title: May 2009 Grant (Preceded December 2009 Grant)
description: The Chinese government has given Botswana a grant amounting to 20 million yuan (P19.2 million) to help Botswana implement some of its priority projects in National Development Plan (NDP 10). The agreement follows another one amounting to 10 million yuan that was signed between China and Botswana in May this year. Matambo said consultations were still ongoing regarding projects to be implemented with the earlier grant.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020091204e5c4000ph&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: Medical Assistance
description: In January 2012, China agreed to send a medical team to South Sudan to provide health services. This agreement was reached during Li Yuanchao, a senior member of the CPCâ€™s Politburo, visiting President Kiir and SPLM Secretary-General Pagan Amum in Juba. He pledged aid and discussed a resource-backed loan. In addition to a preliminary framework on economic cooperation, his delegation also signed bilateral agreements on oil, capacity-building in the petroleum sector, water and health. The dispatch of medical teams to South Sudan was included in these bilateral agreements.
